Blog.post: My urlLink Mac OS 10.2 package is still being held at the my building's front desk due to bad timing on my part, but this weekend, the change will happen! Just a few very brief things before my Pennsylvania governor's race discussion. Check out this very cool link. I sent an e-mail to a bunch of random people I know, but now I'll share it with the rest of the world. It's from a urlLink story I read at The Register - a tech site from the United Kingdom. Unfortunately, as I'm typing several days after reading the story, it no longer works. What a waste. My second gripe, very quickly: The Israel-Palestine situation. The United Nations essentially created Israel. (This is according to a urlLink CIA Web site , which also doesn't list any terrority that Israel seized during its wars as terroritory belonging to the country.) For this very simple paragraph, that makes Israel the child and the United Nations the mother. Now, the mother says don't do that. A good, respectful kid listens. Not Israel. They continue the trouble, like a bad kid. Also, along this line: Israel is breaking a U.N. resolution to cease and desist their seige of Arafat's compound. Does this mean Bush is going to take up a war against Israel? ** Most of my discussion regarding the Pennsylvania governor's race - pretty much just urlLink Mike Fisher (R) (Link is dead) and urlLink Ed Rendell (D) (Link is dead) - has been brewing for quite some time. I could get into the other two, but seriously, they don't stand a chance. Unfortunately with the American government we are currently stuck with just two parties. What third parties do, is push their agendas and hope to get enough public support so that in the end, the two major parties implement Green, Libertarian, etc. issues. I do have to mention The Philadelphia Inquirer urlLink story saying that the environment should be a big issue with this election. Will it be? So far it doesn't look like it. Also, for all the issues check out urlLink IssuesPa . What it has been about for quite some time is Rendell's track record with education in Philadelphia. He's been attacked for not having done anything about it and for letting the problem worsen. Well, guess what, if Ed Rendell didn't have to spend his time as mayor dealing with a nearly bankrupt city, he could have spent more time dealing with education. Or, he could have ignored the other more pressing matters and fixed education, only to have the entire city go under. There are trade-offs, this is not new. Because the city is now in a much better situation, education can be dealt with head on. What is now facing Pennsylvania was what Ed Rendell faced in Philadelphia when he won the mayor's race. He turned the city around. Pennsylvania needs turned around. It has to clean up its environment; it has to balance its budget; it has to retain workers; and attract college students. All of these, sans the environment, were either directly or indirectly dealt with and changed due to Rendell when he served as mayor. How could someone with all of the experience needed for Pennsylvania be kept from the governor's position? Am I glad Fisher filed a suit attempting to block the Hershey Chocolate sale? Yes. I'm glad he did it. The board can claim they didn't get a good enough asking price for the company, but the state and protesters cracking down on the board ultimately forced them to back down from the sale. How does this qualify Mike Fisher for the serious job of turning a state around? I don't think it does. I am unable to attribute much of his work to my well being. I can attribute a lot to Ed Rendell. While not everyone reading this is in Philly and can say that, the people of Philly can. I don't want to say "take it from us," but we've had experience with the man and it went pretty well. As for the issues of gambling and abortion stances, these don't affect me. I don't gamble, though I had a great time losing in Atlantic City once, and I don't have to worry about an abortion. More importantly, I pro-choice in 75% of all cases, limiting it or leaving it unchanged doesn't pull me in any direction. There's a few other issues, but I have time to get to them. Election isn't until Nov. 5. Also in the future, the music industry's big names are taking on music piracy in a big way, but honestly, they should just suck it up and work on changing their industry.

So it seems I'm finally updating on a regular basis. I just had to work out a few kinks, but now I've got things working. Something weird to ponder at urlLink CNN.com (Link is dead) . Two points to make before my little tirade: It is possible for the United States to be on the offensive - against terrorism, countries deemed dangerous - without war. And, it's a good day because California is proposing a rail initiative to transport people rather than building more highways, thereby wasting land and most likely forcing people from their homes. Today, I'm talking about the Israel-Palestine situation. I'm happy that Jews have a homeland all their own, one that has been given to them by their God and one which they inhabited for many centuries. But they hardly seem to be good neighbors. Neither are the Palestinians, but give me a second. My understanding of the situation is that a religion got a country in an area that was divided by government, not religion. This is partly why religion and government don't mix. It never works. Sort of the like the failed creation of Yugoslavia. You don't take battling groups, make them neighbors and tell them to get along. Palestinians also should clean up their act. Their religion is essentially born of Judaism - this is what your doing wrong, kind of thing. It goes beyond that, yes, but they all go back to Abraham and since they both have their start with the man, the Muslims must know that a certain land was given to the Jews. Now that I have my overly simplistic - thereby slightly incorrect - beginning, let's move on to Israel's latest raid on Arafat's compound. It's a stupid move on Israel's part. It does nothing to further any process of peace and simply feeds the militant Muslims' desire for more suicide bombings. It also takes away Arafat's ability to maintain any kind of control, so how will he and his government stop future attempts? It can't. Israel is setting up the self-fulfilling prophecy that Arafat cannot control his people. The most irksome aspect to the situation came across in a story I read today. The latest seige results from (and I quote) the "Tel Aviv bus blast claimed by Arafat's militant rivals..." Why not go after those rivals, the Hamas, instead of Arafat. Or even, why don't Arafat and Israel join to stop the Hamas? If this group is Arafat's rivals, they aren't going to listen to him or his mandates. How can you suddenly go on the offensive against your attackers rival and not the attacker? Where is the mantra, the enemy of my enemy is my friend? The second aspect to the Israeli attacks on Muslims comes from the same article. It's also happened many times previously, but I can only just now mention it. "... near the town of Rafah, on the Egyptian border, Israeli troops fired on stone throwers, killing 2 and wounding 25 others." Stone throwers vs. guns. Does this sound extreme? Yes, it is. Does it only feed Arabs' hatred for Israel? Yes, it does. So, in the end, nothing has been accomplished. Though, Palestinians' plea for help from the United Nations will hopefully result in something. The United Nations did create Israel, I think Israel needs to listen. It also brought the expected terse and slightly empty yelling from the United States. Well this has been especially short, but the next will deal with the governor's race in Pennsylvania and why Ed Rendell is better and Mike Fisher needs to admit this and move on. I'm updateing to Mac OS 10.2 this weekend. That should be fun. The bubonic plague was a nature's version of population control, and probably so is homosexuality.

Just what exactly does Bush think he is doing? Even after Iraq has decided to allow U.N. weapons inspectors to return - political ploy or not - Bush's actions are not necessary. What he is doing is creating a self-fulfilling prophecy of failure in Iraq. A recent urlLink article in urlLink The New York Times ' article reported that our Secretary of Defense, Donald Rumsfeld, thinks the United States needs to take immediate action - essentially overstepping the U.N. Security Council - because Iraq could strike. Seriously, why is Rumsfeld our Defense Secretary? I've read in other columns that Saddam Hussein would be a fool to force a strike, and Saddam is not a fool. One wrong step and the United Nations and NATO - essentially the entire world - would come down on him swifter than the United States did in Afghanistan. I'm also still waiting to hear exactly how this ties into the war on terrorism and when the United States was authorized to police the world on its own. In the previously stated article Rumsfeld also makes a very vague reference to "a number of countries" who would help with United States's preemptive strike on Iraq. Britain is already in, this much is obvious. That leaves just one more country to make it plural, justify his statement and suddenly it seems the United States has broad international support. Odd, didn't every sane world leader just last week make calls for inspectors and not war? Either someone is lying or those sane leaders were swayed by Bush's comments at the U.N. General Assembly. I wonder how much longer Bush will ignore the protests against him all across his country - one is set for his Trenton visit - which maybe, just maybe, might make his political ploy backfire. He certainly hasn't brought any certainty back to the economy. I don't know if the economy is even a priority of his. Certainly the stock market isn't. Those numbers, which rule your 401(k) and set the tone for the world markets, continues its downward spiral each day that Bush brings his frail country to the brink of war. I've recently taken to letter writing campaign to my U.S. Senators, you can do the same urlLink here . Contacting my U.S. Representative has been less than fruitful. Apparently the only way to do so is through the mail, but recent account say land mail takes up to two weeks to get to the addressed person. Let your representatives know what you want, if enough people are against something, the official will have to sway to public opinion or lose reelection. Let's hope this is the case for Bush. ** To spare Bush from my contempt - briefly - I do support his decision to not back down to Caterpillar and other heavy machinery manufacturers who want to lift the self-imposed nitrous oxide omissions cut they signed years ago. I'm also happy that he is essentially our first leader to openly state - and repeatedly, no less - his desire for a Palestinian state. I just hope the latter hasn't been a ploy to win favor with Arabs and Muslims during the war on terror and human rights violations he and United States have committed stateside.

OK, so the last post was rather long, I apologize. I'm slowly getting the hang of having all of this free space to fill. It appears I'm on a slight environmental kick this week with this post and the last. Sure, I've got plenty to say about Bush, but thank god people like Colin Powell and Senator Biden from Delaware have working heads on their shoulders. They are more level-headed and are keeping me from going off about the Bush-Iraq situation since they propose more diplomatic methods to alleviate the confrontation, which I might add seem to be getting somewhere much quicker than "let's go blow the hell out of this country." But today, I'm discussing the drought crisis and Philadelphia's desire for an exemption. I've been sitting on this one for a bit and now it's raining, but this is still fairly relevant. While the city is making the partly legitimate excuse that because the water used is pulled from the bordering rivers and not groundwater, it should be exempt, it's still a very short-sighted excuse. Just to be very brief: water works in a cycle. It fall to the earth, some seeps into the underground resevoirs and the rest runs off into streams and lakes. Underground resevoirs also feed rivers, so by pulling the same amount of water from rivers, the level still drops because less and less water is feeding the river. A recent urlLink story that crossed my desk the other day reported on how urban sprawl is depeleting the water table. The urlLink report (Link has changed) that led to the story put Philadelphia in or just outside of the Top 10 sprawling cities in America that result in increased water table loss. It was also put in the Top 10 cities capable of saving land and thereby green space, through better development. Where am I go with this? The city is partly responsible for the exacerbated drought and should take it's part in helping solve and alleviate the problem. More importantly all levels of government should do something to fight drought. We're a wasteful society, this isn't news. It's not hard to cut back, yet we do only when forced to. Very few people apparently are learning much. Since this is a drought that has been around for at least a year and looks to continue, water restrictions should be kept regardless, both to alleviate the water crisis and work on bettering our mentality. It also wouldn't hurt to to fight urban sprawl through all levels of government. Urban sprawl prevents water loss because rainfall cannot get into the ground. Highways and parking lots drain water into pipes that empty the water into streams and rivers, not expanses of forests or lawns that need it. Yet highways grow at an astonishing rate and park lots, rather than parking garages, are the norm. If the billions of dollars that flowed into the production of highways and parking lots were put towards increasing density, more open land would form outside the cities, thereby feeding the water table. When will this happen? I have no idea. We can only wait and see. And trust me on this one: You'll read stories in the paper or watch them on TV that say the most recent rain did little to help the drought situation. It's not difficult for people to conserve water on their own, by refraining from car washing or lawn watering (at least during the daytime) or long showers ... the list goes on. It's a start and from there, it's your voice that has to be heard at all levels of government, so without further ado: You can find your state's officials at the state's Web site (most likely state.[postal abbreviation].us). Write to you U.S. Senators, after identifying them urlLink here and your U.S. Reps urlLink here . I do know that I'm voting for Ed Rendell for mayor (more about him in a later post), and urban sprawl and the drought should be made a serious issue in government. So regardless of who you're voting for and which race it is, let your government officials know what needs to be done, what matters to you, no the to business funding them.

Thanks to the people who responded. Sure, you're all my friends, but someday, an outsider will join... If you are interested in more reading about the last topic, check out the urlLink City Paper 's recent series of articles finally (and still one of the few) raising the questions we need to ask and answering some of them. I was hoping to spruce up the Web site a little bit, but I can't understand the code that put this thing together. Neither can Jigsha, so I figure it's not real code; I'll just deal with it for now. Someday, it'd be nice to have people respond to posts on the site, but, one step at a time, please. Someday I'll also have lots of links jumping everywhere so that people online can practically stalk me and model themselves after me. ** Well onto a less caustic post, which deals with my other interest: Cities and Urban Studies. This week marks the beginning of a urlLink pilot program , (Link is dead, alternate story at urlLink The Philadelphia Inquirer ), in Philadelphia that is run by the Fannie Mae Foundation that is trying to rebuild neighbors. Fannie Mae is officially known as a The Federal National Mortgage Association and is a quasi-governement entity that ticks a lot of other mortgage companies. Quasi-governmental organizations are difficult like that. The program aims to bring people back into homes near transportation hubs, such as bus stops and rail stations. Noting the damage that cars have done to the American landscape and how they are congesting our cities, the ultimate purpose is to curb car use. It's finally time someone took notice of the traffic jams, deaths and fumes the car culture has caused in America. Bush would only like to increase oil dependency by killing the national rail system, but that?s a topic for another day. Thankfully, Philly is still one of the few largely pedestrian-friendly cities left in America, and it looks like things will continue in that way if the pilot program works. Yeah, we can complain all we want about public transportation in the city, but it's convenience still beats car driving anyday. And seriously, less cars on the roads would only improve the transportation network because double-parked cars wouldn't block trolleys and jammed streets wouldn't prevent buses from making turns on their routes. The savings add up both environmentally and financially. Imagine what you could do with the extra $20,000 or more (plus interest) you'd be able to keep and spend on any number of other things you need in your life. We're talking money saved for college (if you are one of the under 18 people who feel they need a car), for trips, for an actual home to own or rent in a nicer part of town. SEPTA might be the second most expensive base fare public transportation in the country, but any sensible person would just buy a TransPass. Instead of $1.60 per trip, you pay $18.75 for unlimited riding for a week. I buy a TrailPass each week to use Regional Rail to Trenton and I pay $34.50 a week for unlimited train, subway, bus and trolley rides. With the travelling I do, a motorist would spend twice that just on gas. It doesn't make sense just wasting so much, including your time. Ever feel to tired to get up for work, then nap on the train or sleep in and eat breakfast on your way to work. When was the last time you read a good book? Read on the bus instead of moving at 25 mph with honking horns and drivers cutting you off. How about last minute meeting preparations, all while looking out the window at the snarled traffic you left behind. Furthermore, an increased use of public transportation doesn't mean giving up your car, if you don't want to. Chances are, if you live in suburbia near a transportation hub, you'll need to get to the hub, somehow. Most rail station make heavy use of parking, so you'd save on gas and insurance. It'd be nice if they were more like parking garages instead of eating up acres of grass, but I can't expect Utopia just yet. Taking advantage of all of these benefits requires foresight and our country's mentality ignores a lot sometimes. It also doesn't help that automobile companies feed the car addiction with pointless vehicles like the ever deadly SUV. Cars are designed low to the ground because they are safer and more efficient that way, but no, let's raise the vehicle, making it less stable and less efficient and charge more money. I could better stand SUVs if they didn't show up in my city. How unnecessary are these gas-guzzling monsters? I'll leave this for you to think about... (This is my take on a passage from the "EcoCities" book. I don't own the book, so I'm not sure of the exact wording, but you get the drift.") All of those beautiful artistic commercials with the tinted-window vehicles driving through the wilderness, handling the turns and dangers so well: 100% of America used to look like the lush green back drop those cars drive against. But urban sprawl - a vicious cycle the car feeds - destroys it at an appalling rate. Replaces it with four lane highways. Kills it with fumes and other pollution. Buying more cars increases manufacturing with feeds all the above mentioned problems meaning that 100% continues to drop and drop... ** A rather extreme group of people would like to see cars cut completely, an idea Richard Register pushes in his book urlLink "Ecocities," but let's face it, that isn't going to happen. Curbing cars is a far more logical and plausible step. Another book to check out, which is less extreme than Rogers is urlLink "Asphalt Nation" by Jane Holtz Kay. Both are available at the bookstore I work at as well (Wow, that was a big advertisement.) If you're interested, it's the urlLink AIA Bookstore on 17th & Sansom. You might be able to order it on the web, but maybe not. We don't have everything up there. Oh, and I'm not really trying to be commercial, I'm just using lots of links because I can do that easily, and hopefully it'll feed traffic back to me at some point.

Well everyone, welcome to my blog. This is just one big experiment that my friend Jigsha suggested because she didn't think I'd make it as a columnist for a newspaper. And like I could handle that job anyway. I'd love to hear what you have to say about what I've written or even personal suggestions, pats on the back or vicious torrents against my ideals. I'm hardly HTML savvy, so just copy bswope@att.net and send me some feedback. I guess I'll just start with a brief introduction. I'm a recently graduated Journalism major from urlLink Temple University in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania - my new "hometown." I now work as a copy editor for urlLink The Times of Trenton. That basically means I do a lot of clean up, all while reading up to 20 stories a night. This gives me plenty to vent about - considering Bush is president and Sept. 11 is still being pushed around as an excuse for taking away privacy and civil liberties and instigating war with whomever we choose. ** My latest complaint with America surrounds the Sept. 11 nonsense and how far British Prime Minister Tony Blair is up President Bush's ass. I guess they both go hand in hand seeing as how Bush's attempt to finish what his father failed all stems from the rather uncowardly attack on New York and Washington. OK, so very conveniently a urlLink story comes across my desk about how Saddam Hussein is working to further his grasp on nuclear armaments. After weeks of no solid evidence, European nations refusing to stand behind Bush and protests on American soil. Does it seem a little convenient? Yes. I wouldn't have jumped to that conclusion so soon, but Blair is citing satellite photographs of construction at previous nuclear sites as evidence. Would Saddam be so obvious? More importantly, let's say that Saddam does have weapons of mass destruction. What better reason does he have to use them then against an attack instigated by us? Sure, in the end Bush can say "I told you so," but then we'd have a large number of troops and others dead by radiation or whatever biological weapon Saddam chose to launch against us. I'm also still waiting to find out exactly how he is going to justify an attack. Continuing with the presumption that Saddam has nuclear weapons how does that justify America's sudden tirade on the country? Hasn't he been "well behaved"? Bush has yet to provide any evidence linking him to terrorism. Bush is just using our frenzy and energized and wrongly-placed "patriotism" to continue coming up with ways to take the attention away from his crumbling country and justify a wholly unneeded defense spending increase. Why have our efforts been turned away from Afghanistan, al-Qaida and Osama bin Laden? When was the last time that was his goal in the newly expanded world policing efforts? Bin Laden's name only shows up in stories related to his terrorism network anymore and the random "Is he alive or dead" brief. Bush has left so many open holes, the only way he'll be able to cover any of it up is to launch a full scale attack and leave America rallying for our win, because regardless of whether we support the effort or not, very few people are going to support a loss on our part. I should state now, as self-incriminating evidence, that should these "wars" escalate any further I am skipping any draft attempt made by the government. ** As for Sept 11, it's hard for me not to be cold about it. It hasn't affected me in anyway except for loss of privacy and, though it hasn't happened yet, the government's ability to take my rights away from me for "special circumstances," which have yet to be fully put in ink. Since the attacks and the crumbling of the economy I have found a second job, one in my college major that I have used to put my former job as back up. I have received ample raises, am lowering my debt and getting along just fine. I'm actually better off now than I was one year ago. I only had to deal with the anthrax attack at one time and that was some extremist anti-Semite who was exploiting fear. That was during my time as editor in chief of the urlLink Temple News . Contrary to a rather annoying column published in the Sept. 8 issues of The Times of Trenton, I don't fear my mail. In fact, I got a job in Trenton where the original anthrax mail was sent from. I do not look up at planes wondering if they will crash into Liberty One or Two and I will not spend my life reliving that day. In fact, it won't even go down at one of the Top Ten most memorable days of my life. Sept. 11 may have had more power in my life had things changed. But no, Americans became zealot patriots who only pushed their hatred and distrust of blacks, asians and whomever else we (dislike, distrust, etc.) onto anyone who they deemed of Muslim decent. America hardly stood united as many people have claimed. We pushed our hatred onto another group. We infringed on other people's rights to freedom, happiness and all the other fragile concepts deemed to our citizens in the Constitution. Our new found "patriotism" was quickly picked up by business and government interests who sold their wares - some, unfortunately, successfully - and destructively, respectively. Do we need to hang the Red, White and Blue in our windows to be patriots? Did our Afghanistan mission need to be so extensive and forced? Did so many Afghanistan civilians have to die in our "successful" airstrikes. Did we have to muscle around the rest of the world into support for fear of them being deemed terrorist-friendly? America hardly grew from the Sept. 11 experience. What it did do, ultimately, was cement a deep hatred for people who weren't like us, give us reason to direct our anger and ignorance at people who didn't deserve it and lead to the cancellation of Bill Maher's "Politically Incorrect." Just to finish with more about my thoughts, David Letterman kicks Jay Leno's ass, Apple's are far superior to Wintels and please give up your car for public transportation or railway whenever possible. Has all of this maybe been a little bit choppy? Did my logic jump some? Well, it's 2:15 on a Sunday morning. More later. Brian

Happy Halloween!! Maybe, maybe not. The following urlLink story from The Times of Trenton , which in the beginning few grafs, refers to canceled or almost canceled Halloween events because parents complained for religious reasons. The story focuses more on safety this time of year, but also from living and talking to the "male parental unit" in my family I know that there are others out there with the preposterous religion claim. So what follows is a defense of the holiday. Not that it needs any. In the United States it's lost all meaning and has become a time for chocolate and a reason for toilet papering the neighbor’s trees. I guess throwing eggs at people can be fun to. Vampires, witches and ghosts, none of these are related to the Devil. Witches can be, but their origination is a pagan past and they fall into the good and bad categories. So let's say you want to look beyond the glossed over holiday version. You'll have to go back more than 2,000 years to the Celts and their Druid priests. Celts definitely weren’t Satanic, of course they weren't Christian either, which is where most the complaints of religious questionability start, I'm sure. The Celts believed that on their day of Samhain - not our Oct. 31 - the dead would return to Earth. Now depending on the where you want to take your information ( urlLink The History Channel or urlLink History and Customs of Halloween , or any other myriad of choices) the scary costumes were part of a fortune telling rite or a way to scare the dead from possessing people. The Roman conquest of much of Europe by 100 A.D., merged Samhain with the Roman holiday of Feralia, which also honored their dead, and the following day to honor Pomona, the Roman god of fruits and trees. Following the rise of Christianity, Pope Boniface IV created a Catholic holiday to honor the dead and probably replace a pagan holiday. Without going to far on a tangent, the Christian Church incorporated a lot of holiday to coincide with pagan and other religious days as a way of incorporating new followers. Trick-or-treating actually started as a Christian addition to the earlier festival, according to the urlLink Customs site. The Jack O'Lantern began as a legend, but it's purpose was to scare away evil spirits, according to the urlLink History Channel site. All of this doesn't seem evil at all, and it makes for one evening. So what's all the ho-hum about? Nothing. People who aren't as educated as they think about something that spans 2 millennia. Sure, some things have gotten out of hand, but that's hardly reason to kill of a holiday or ruin it for anyone. It's actually a great learning experience. This is one of the few blogs that required me to do serious research and checking and double checking of facts and there's more interesting stuff, I’m sure. And so to the associate pastor of the Fountain of Life evangelical church in The Times story, it’s hardly a "glorification of Satan’s kingdom," when the U.S. version is based on money and chocolate and when the real Halloween was about scaring away evil to protect one's self.
Since SatireWire is no longer, The Onion is once again my favorite funny site. Especially the info box on the urlLink site with the Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon connecting him to al-Qaida.

Well, what a weekend, both personally - blah, blah, blah - and internationally with an antiwar protest spanning the globe. What I have to say today is indirectly related to said protests. It's about a 33-page document titled urlLink "National Security Strategy of the United States." The New York Times has a lengthy urlLink article covering it. Unfortunately the page will force to you view an MSN ad. I apologize. The United States' regime (hey, the Rev. Jesse Jackson referred to Bush that way just this weekend) has taken the stance that this country is No. 1 and will not accept challenges to its authority. Wow. Where is the reality? Where is the levelheadedness? Why did we not take the events of Sept. 11, 2001 and afterwards as a wake up call, that this kind of attitude was not acceptable last century and isn't in the 21st Century? The problem that the fundamental Islamic nations have with the United States is this exact mindset. The problem they have is the walking all over the globe asserting American beliefs and our way of life on cultures that: a) don’t share these views and b) don’t understand these views. In our bid to be No. 1, to rule the globe, we shove capitalism down everyone's throats like it's the only way, like it's the correct way. Guess what, it's not. Capitalism results in race and class clashes. Capitalism is why the minimum wage is $5.25 per hour and why urlLink the average CEO makes 411 times the salary of an average worker. I'm not a religion buff, but capitalism sure goes a long way to killing religion as well, something that doesn't go over very well with fundamental religious nations or sects, militias and whomever wants a nation based on religion. Capitalism is why the environment comes third or fourth on a list and the dollar comes first. Capitalism is why I have to turn on the radio and hear created boy bands. Capitalism does have some good points to it, but this is pure capitalism we’re talking about, not the mixed (add any other -ism) version that is more true to life. More importantly, doesn't this whole mindset seem a little anticompetitive and don't we have laws in this country to stop that because it's wrong? Also, doesn't the stance have a ring of anticapitalism to it? Ah, the confusion that is the United States. Isn't is also quite obvious from the Saturday protests that many people within in this country and elsewhere do not support such actions? I am not saying that this country suddenly needs to drop its stance and let everyone else walk over us. Hardly. In a world of diplomacy and understanding (the ever-impossible Utopia) military supremacy isn't needed. More diplomacy and less muscle-headed force means a lot less confrontation. In turn less of a need for military and in turn more money to put to the failing education system that is the United States. Not to mention a hundred other other forgotten facets of the United States’ budget. In closing, all I'm saying is that our might could be better expressed and better used. With our might, we should be a leader in cutting pollution and fixing the environment. As a leader we should raising up other peoples, countries, technologies, whatever rather than doing the opposite. My god, do I sound like an aging hippie? I need to get away from the computer, sit back and listen to some Beatles...

The media’s relationship with the those that feed it and read it never ceases to amaze me. 2 perfect examples: 1) ‘76er Allen Iverson’s expletive laden tirade last season when he went back and forth between attacking the media’s coverage of him, and then offering understanding, saying the journalists were just doing there job. This just highlights the celebrity/media relationship, which usually is fairly aggressive and abusive to each other. Take Michael Jackson’s “Leave Me Alone” song from the Bad CD. In it, and in subsequent similar songs or subsequently inferior CDs (after Dangerous ), Jackson takes on the media’s “lies.” In actuality, Jackson fed quite a number of stories to the tabloids. Namely the hyperbaric chamber story. There’s others I’m sure, but that’s one that I’m certain of from reading. A recent anthrax story dealing with American Media (aka The Enquirer, Star, etc.) a year later quoted the editor who said that a majority of their stories come right from the horse’s mouth. Not a surprise, when you think about it. 2) The authorities behind the sniper case have been back and forth on their media relationship. One day criticizing the media for reports on the tarot card and another day making very public pleas (i.e. press meetings for TV, radio and newspaper) to the sniper and calling on all media to get the word out. Guess how the media is supposed to work in the United States? It’s not a government entity. The media reports on what there is to report (for the most part.) It’s not a pick and chose thing. *** While on the sniper story, let me share my outrage with TV media on this night, as the sniper case unravels for the whole world to see. 1) CNN and Philadelphia’s Channel 6 ABC, you are reporters. You are talking to other reporters. You are not experts, don’t posit theories and make assumptions because then it’s not news, it’s speculation (which can be lies) and it’s the reason that the media has lost it’s credibility. It’s also why in my Theories of Communication final project, my research showed that TV news is seen as the least credible now, was not very credible before and no one expects it’s credibility to improve. If a news entity has an ‘expert’ there, then ask these questions of the person. But if one isn’t present, it’d serve the media entity better to just shut up and report what is known. 2) Channel 6 ABC, in all of its zealous bid to break the unraveling story first, made a big boo-boo. Above an info graphic, which listed the names of the 2 suspects and license plate number for the car they were last seen in, was the erroneous title: Suspects. Err, wrong. They were ‘material witnesses’ and after a commercial break the station had to make an apology. Furthermore, every station on TV was reporting on the situation as if the 2 were suspects who were on the run. This may turn out to be the case, but that’s the future and the future isn’t news. It will be later, but report on the news happening now and that’s it. Also, should they turn out to not even be legitimate 'material witnesses' then all the speculating will be more incorrect (if that's possible) and the entire segment of coverage can be blasted for any number of things from bias to racism to unethical journalism. The negatives seem to outweigh the positives, but will that stop anyone?

I'm stepping out of the urban, liberal setting for a brief jaunt through the mass-suburbia, conservative world of Lancaster County. When I return, and following a much-needed Tuesday Happy Hour, I'll have something to put on the site.

Hmm, well there’s plenty of political shit to go on about, but I need to get this urlLink story through from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution because it goes off on Sunday or Monday. It deals with green architecture in Atlanta. More specifically, in educational institutions in that area. The notable aspect to this? There's 2. First, urlLink Metropolis magazine listed that city as one of the 100 worst inventions/things of the last century because of it's sprawl and maybe because the city seems rather boring - both go hand in hand. Second, it's generally the cash-strapped educational institutions that are leading the way with sustainable architecture in the city. God, if only Temple University had done this with its newest dorm and Student Center renovations. Putting sustainable architecture in these venues serves as a teaching tool for students at the school. While it’s also more expensive at first, the building pays for itself over the years with utility savings. Also, how else does a technology advance? By being used, tested and studied so improvements can be made. More importantly, these buildings make for interesting settings, something cool to show off to students and parents. It gives a cutting edge to cookie cutter cities and cities which are lacking. This technology can put a city map. I hardly expect Philadelphia to suddenly pick up cutting-edge technology and do something to increase the city’s status - it’s part of the Quaker mentality battling the (thankfully) Democratic mentality. OK, so there’s the new Robert Stern building, which takes the environmentally conscious route, but not as far as it could go. One aspect of sustainable architecture obviously is energy saving; the other side of it was covered by Metropolis magazine, but the story isn’t available. That story covered Toyota’s facilities in California and how they took sustainability to the extreme. While it’s not available, a basic breakdown is available at the car company’s urlLink Web site under the headline “Campus building expansion showcases...” The second side covers materials and where they come from. It’s safer, more environmentally friendly to rehabilitate old buildings rather than demolish them. It’s friendlier to use local wood or stone rather than have wood cut from a forest or stone mined and transported here from other countries. Toyota is also an auto industry leader with environmentally friendly cars. Where Ford has failed and other companies have delayed, they are pushing the technology and setting higher standards for sales. At least a company is looking to protect their investment for the future. One other company doing this BP, whose solar power devision sees a huge market and is taking advantage of it now. While yes, I generally dislike cars, it’s nice to go for a ride/drive when I make my way back to sprawling Lancaster County, but American cars have generally gone bland. My sister is all about Volkswagen and besides them, it’s the Japanese manufacturers with the interesting cars and the more interesting commercials. All of this because they are a more interesting company. And I’m not just hawking this now. My insane green mentality is really only a few years old - since I came to Philly and learned there wasn’t anything worth my time outside of urban life (except the occasional trip to see the night sky and breathe slightly better air) - but I've felt this way for quite some time.

OK, so I said I would have something yesterday, but it's here today. Sort of like at The Times when deadline is 9:30 p.m., but stories still come in at 11, and when layout for the first zone is 10:30, but the papers doesn't hit the presses until midnight. The urlLink race story covers Unity Day at Rider University and the story is only available for 2 weeks. Now, I'm about to go out on a limb, but the part I'm commenting on covers religion. Spanish actor/activist Edward James Olmos told the crowd about a speech he made at Brigham Young University. He made the audacious (!) claim that Jesus was a man of color and half of the auditorium walked out on him. Olmos' reasoning: "since Jesus lived on the Mediterranean and was a Jew, and since the first Jews were from North Africa, he could not have been white." Makes sense to me, but I guess that takes part of the superior nature away from the white population. "Dogma," makes the assertion that Jesus was a black man, maybe not completely accurate, but it still touches on the issue of color and it gives a reason to put Chris Rock in as "Rufus, the 13th Apostle." Just to keep myself out of hot water on that issue: While Egypt was part of Africa, there is a definite difference between the color/race of Egyptians and those living in the rest of Africa. More importantly, Olmos' statement still stands: Jesus was a Jew and Jews originated in Middle East. "Dogma" also makes the correct the statement that God isn't male or female. God is just "I am." Of course this doesn't fit into a lot of other religions so well, but lets stick with most gods being generally sexless. Without jumping to heavily into conspiracy theory, which I read on occasion, there are plenty of other choices for religion's basis. The last part of urlLink Rule By Secrecy covers alternative creation themes. Since I'm all about having options, I really enjoyed this portion of the book because of it's challenges. But, more importantly, it weaves a common theme through at least 4 civilizations, 2,000 years and at least 3 different languages. And just so no one thinks I'm a crazy conspiracy type: I support teaching creationism in schools. I think that if people look hard enough - open their minds or whatever - the two can help explain each other to a point. Olmos also decries a United States without a national holiday for people of color. He notes the one day: Martin Luther King Jr. Day, which has to be a catch-all for the man different people living here. I'm not sure if Native Americans actually have holidays, but it would make sense that if they did, something would filter into the holiday calendar for the country. A Mexican holiday other than Cinco de Mayo would be nice as well, wouldn’t it? Sure, $1 Coronas are nice, but there's a little bit more to it than that. Of course, a lot of the citizenry's ignorance comes from a failed public school system that doesn't attribute significant contributions to people other than whites. Blacks get a few, but from there it completely drops off. More importantly what do our schools teach us regarding our neighbors? What do people really know about Canada and Mexico? Thank some higher power for my history classes in college, which both got closer to real history than anything I've previously had. I actually finished a full year of history at Temple learning that some of the stuff I was taught before was wrong. Only in our education system could this happen. Does this 'great' (ha) country have far to go or what? Oh, and I welcome everyone to the beginning of a long, drawn out confrontation with Iraq, which will certainly expand to more of the Middle East and most certainly we will feel backlash on our soil. OK, so I've spread rather far from the beginning, but I did a half-ass job weaving it all together, right?

An almost brush with fame: Kevin Smith's new movie "Jersey Girl" was filming just a block away from my bookstore. I didn't see anyone really famous, of course, except some extras, but they were there, I know it! They also started shooting at the insane hour of 7 a.m., which doesn't work for me. Personally, I'm a fan of "Dogma," though it obviously is short of many of the things that made his previous movies cult hits. That's what I get for jumping on the wagon late. Today, let’s consider my topics briefs, though the total length of them may get unbearable. It’ll help to come back repeatedly after small breaks of reading something more fun. 1. President Bush is now talking of overthrowing the Iraq government and instituting one of our very stable regimes. Sunday’s AP story quotes Bush: “Should force be required to bring Saddam to account, the United States will work with the other nations to help the Iraqi people rebuild and form a just government.” Let’s pause for just a second. Yugoslavia, fell apart and not just (see Slobadan Milosevic). Israel destabilized the area; just, depends on whom you ask. Afghanistan, still in its infancy as a puppet regime, but stable doesn’t seem to be exactly it. Just, we have to wait and see. Hmm, I wonder what could possibly go wrong with setting up reestablishing a government in Iraq with 3 very distinct groups of people. 2. A recent urlLink General Accounting Office report has found that the government has been taking more time responding to Freedom of Information Act requests, even though fewer are being made. FOIA is a 1966 law that make the government more open. It’s obviously been used extensively by the media, but it is available to anyone. The law is to provide openness because that what a democracy, or whatever it is we are supposed to live in, thrives on. Information. While, yes, the public in general has probably taken the opportunity to ignore or be apathetic, that certainly isn’t the case with many of us. While most amendments to the act have benefited the public, the Regime has not been so open. The story from my newspaper isn’t available online, but a similar urlLink Washington Post story noted urlLink John Ashcroft’s new policy , which asks: “Any discretionary decision by your agency to disclose information protected under the FOIA should be made only after full and deliberate consideration of the institutional, commercial, and personal privacy interests that could be implicated by disclosure of the information.” It goes further to say that for “significant issues,” the Department of Justice should be consulted. The JD will also back any denials that have a “sound legal basis,” which in this day and age could be anything. “Significant issues” is terribly vague and unlike with the Legislature where vague is good and open to interpretation by the courts, vague in this sense is not. It should also be noted that Bush is backing legislation that creates “a new exemption to protect information provided by businesses on ‘critical infrastructure’ that could be a possible target for terrorists.” That is from The Times story, which goes on to add that critics contend business could use it to keep problems secret. Only in a time of shady account practice would Bush give businesses more blankets to hide under. If our government is based on being open, on being informed; if this government is supposed to be of, by and for the people, then include the people. Inform the people. Don’t push our country continually away from the people and into the hands of the elite and the business. And... 3. Oil drilling in Alaska thankfully failed in the Senate. Links to the story are difficult, but as part of the 2002 Energy bill, Republicans tried to open up part of the urlLink Arctic National Wildlife Refuge . The story states that Republicans are looking to curb America’s thirst for “foreign oil.” Why not curb our thirst for oil completely? Because America is the largest energy hog, cutting back our use in general gives us more bargaining power, should we need it. But no, let’s just transfer our thirst onto other countries. Also, according to the urlLink Energy Information Administration , the United States imports more oil from Canada (9.6%) then from Saudi Arabia (7.5%). Why is this even a discussion? Because shortsighted people are only looking ahead to next year, not the next decade or the next century. What better time than now, when we have room to play, to get moving along with renewable energy resources, which many are still in their infancy with providing a significant portion of our energy manufacturing. When is there a better time to start to pound into our heads energy conservation? Why doesn’t it? Because conservation doesn’t bring in money to the government or to business. I for one do not want to pay the price for shortsighted politicians, nor do I want other generations to pay the price. It’s time to wake up.

OK, so here I go with the music the industry. It sucks, it’s getting worse and because of it we have to listen to Creed, N’Sync and Shania Twain among nearly 1,000 others. I have to wonder why more people continue trying to break into the music scene. Very few are actually presenting a solution. I understand the lure of money, but can we be more obvious? The Spice Girls. The Britney clones - all who have fallen to the way side even though one or two have more talent than her? N’Sync - the Backstreet Boys clone and then the many who followed and failed as well. This is all just about the quick buck as, within 5 years, they’ve gone from top to bottom. Why don’t the record labels get it when they see the Beatle’s Anthology series and subsequent No. 1 CDs top the chart for weeks. The year Anthology were released, the Beatles were the biggest selling act. Not a single new group could touch them! Elvis’ new greatest hits package is debuting at No. 1 across the world. When will people wake up? Madonna is still bigger than most new hit makers. Maybe not in terms of sales - at least not in the United States - but she still has drawing power, after 20 years. I was really refreshed when I heard Eminem's new CD would finally street. His no-holds barred, tell it like it is style was desperately needed and it's acceptance by fans definitely said most of the people were ready to move beyond the Sept. 11 rememberance that is finally giving way. I'll post some links later, but it's 2:13 p.m. and I have to go to work. The following urlLink CNN story deals with the death of good music because of the radio. The story has been instigated by Tom Petty, a real rock ‘n’ roller who’s been at it for a more than 20 years. He has a new CD coming out and on it, he laments the death of good music. He attributes it pretty heavily to the conglomerization of radio and to the entertainment industry itself. My biggest beef is the capitalist society and desire to feed the shareholders’ and CEO’s pockets with cash and not the listener’s/buyer’s ears with something worth listening to. $18.99 for mediocre CD with one good song; you've got to be kidding. I find it hard to believe that the music industry refuses to change when it’s basis has always been so radical. I know things are supposed to grow and mature, but at least keep the cool. Napster has not had the affect on the industry that the RIAA and others claim. The downturn in sales has dropped because very little is worth paying for at the prices they set. I worked at tower for nearly a year and the CD the customer bought, was $6 or $7 more than what the store charged. I wasn't making that money. They paid minimum wage. Where'd the money go? Let’s also not forget that the economy is down, so don’t blame every problem on Napster and it’s many clones. If you’re actually raising the price of CDs and dropping singles at the same time, you have to expect fans will find alternative means for getting what they want. Way back when - the early ‘90s - singles still carried the main radio play song and one or two songs from the album, making it a decent sampler. Releasing the radio hit and 4 remixes of the same song doesn’t tell the buyer what to expect on the full album. Nor do remixes interest 90% of the population. Napster did get out of hand with entire CDs being copied. I admit, I’ve copied a few CDs, mostly just trying to move from tape to CD with the cost and if there’s a completely new artist I have an interest in, it’s nice to get a full dose of it. I have bought plenty of CDs through my experience at Napster, so the industry really doesn’t have anything going for their claim. How else are people supposed to be introduced to new music? Radio surely doesn’t play anything new and groundbreaking, nor does it play 99% of the old stuff, just a few hundred songs are played from a catalog of tens of thousands. Doesn’t seem fair. And of course it isn’t. But the CNN story makes a point. You’ve got to pay for what you want now. Essentially the free radio world is dead. I can only open that Clear Channel really takes a hit from what they caused. I also think artists give into much. It certainly isn't just the industry. Mandy Moore did know who she was supposed to look like, sing like and rip off. Courtney Love’s recent battle was refreshing. Her support by many in the industry has shown there is a serious problem, but who will continue the battle now? Tom Petty, Lenny Kravitz and Sheryl Crow have put their views in their latest CDs but other than that, things seems fairly dead. Some panel was supposed to look into the industry’s practices, but that was a story that passed my desks 2 months ago and no news from it. Just a side bar to the industry and the government. When the artists were fighting the "Parental Advisory" label, where were the labels? When the artists call for the government to step in and investigate practices, does anyone really think the panel will do much? Industry ownership of an artist's catalog has definitely worked to kill off creativity. I’m a true believer that the CEO doesn’t need to make diddly squat. He’s not writing, producing or arranging anything. In fact, it doesn’t seem that any of the people actually running the industry have ever put out a CD. I might be wrong about that, but I’m doubting it. While I know it’s fad, I praise the artists who sell their CDs through their own Web sites or who make some their music available over the Web for free. It’s a radical concept which is just what the entertainment industry needs to rejuvenate itself. A non-conglomerization shake up would be nice to. Just one last random rant: I really hate that radio stations fail to introduce their music anymore. Obviously, since they limit the the play list, most of the music is known, but occasionally, there’s that blissful tune that perks your ear and it’s not mentioned... Video didn’t kill the radio star: they both killed the rock star.

Let me be surprising for a second and berate the United Airlines mechanics for not taking a bit of a pay cut. Do pay cuts suck? Yes. I may have to deal with the same thing if my internship ends without a hire. Personally, i think if you work for a company, you should have some loyalty to it. urlLink United has claimed that no concessions from the mechanics will force the company into bankruptcy. If that happens, the mechanics might end up jobless and without any money. I’m rather on the fence when it comes to unions. I doubt I’ll ever join one because I’ll only work at a place I enjoy and where I am treated fairly. If the company doesn’t fit these criteria, then I leave and I leave loud - Tower Records on Chestnut Street changed the employee handbook after Jenn and I quit and the Better Business Bureau got a letter from me; The manager at Structure vowed I would never be allowed work in the store (maybe the company) again, but I ended up returning briefly after his incompetence (which I told him and the company about) led to his departure. I’ve stayed at the AIA Bookstore because I enjoy working there and they treat me with respect and have adequate pay raises. So why join a union? You pay dues - on top of taxes - to an organization pushing for what you deserve - or don’t, which is the problem I have with them. For example, Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority union drivers battled it out with the beleaguered public transit and threatened to shutdown service a few years ago. Guess what brilliant people - SEPTA is already a cash strapped organization, it has been and it will be for awhile because public transit receives less support than it needs, but that’s another post. Fighting for pay raises and more health benefits doesn’t help the company as it struggles to close a deficit. Take concessions or flat hikes now and when the company is faring better, make that your main point. But don’t put your employer in jeopardy. I should add that all of this is in the gray and not black and white. If the blue collars are taking concessions or flat hikes, then the same should go for the white collar worker. That’s the case with United: Management took a 10% cut and pilots cut 18% and additional unions will soon be voting on concessions. Now that I’ve taken a swipe at blue collar, let me praise a urlLink corporate association that would like to see new tax cuts for individuals rather than businesses. President Bush is expected to announce a tax cut plan in the coming weeks that may surely do this, should he hope to get it through the Senate where GOP majority is not enough to guarantee passage. Middle- and low-income people could really use the money. The rich are complaining because they can’t afford 2 houses and a yacht, meanwhile some in the United States are in jeopardy of losing their only home and their debt could very quickly crush them. I know I’m partially in that category with 5 years of college loans dropping on me in just a few weeks. Last year’s emergency IRS refund helped how many people? E-mail me if it did. How many people actually got the refund? E-mail me if you did. I know it did nothing for me. Surprisingly I’m not part of the rich the GOP generally favors. For starters, Bush’s last tax plan was irresponsible because he’s already thrown the country back into deficit budgeting. His last tax plan was an eery reminder of former President Regan’s trickle-down stimulus package that didn’t. Fortunately, some of the ideas being tossed around could help: put more people into the lowest 15% tax bracket or cut social security taxes from the first $10,000 made - something that helps both workers and businesses, which isn’t so bad. Hmm, I’m stopping rather abruptly, but then even a small part of big corporate America asking to pass the tax cuts to the workers rather than themselves is shocking. Plus, I need to head to the job. Forgive editing errors, I'm running on a tight schedule today.

OK, the following is a heavily edited version of my previous post; All thanks to Jigsha. Writing about race can be a difficult thing, because it’s such a point of contention in society.I tried tackling it with less than stellar result, but now, hopefully a bit better. *** Let me just state for the record that racism is wrong. It’s generalizating, which is wrong. Stereotypes hurt people, both the perpetrator and the victim. But, people are free to dislike each other. It happens; people clash. It creates tension but that can be productive. And let’s be serious: Stereotypes, racism, sexism, etc. - it isn’t going anywhere anytime soon. To think it is is naive. That’s Utopia and Utopia doesn’t happen. On the subject I have 2 stories to point out. The first is from my old paper, the Temple News . The urlLink opinion piece asserts that anti-Israel sentiment (as in its treatment of and actions against Palestinians) is too often made to look like anti-Semitism (which is religion based and therefore racism on some level). This is wrong because because it throws non-racist views into a racist light. Rather than building up a cause, it undermines the cause. Some are saying they hate Jews. But most just find Israel’s policies to be harsh, wrong, oppressive - the list goes on and on. The people who are bombing in Jerusalem are racist. Osama bin Laden is racist. Throwing people who disagree with Israel’s policies into the bunch with bin Laden and bombers is ignorant. Without jumping to stories and other Web pages, awhile back several pro-Israel groups protested The Philadelphia Inquirer because they felt the paper had a pro-Palestine stance. Their reasoning: Stories covering the plight of the Palestinians were placed front page, while some stories dealing with attacks on Jews were placed deeper inside. I often wonder how many people understand how the media works. For starters, it sounds cold, but 8 deaths in Israel does not get the same placement in the Inky , or any other U.S. paper, as 3 deaths in New Jersey, which doesn’t get the same placement as 2 deaths in Philadelphia. It’s called impact and proximity. Also, poverty and lockdown of an entire town or people gets better placement than the burial of 5 victims of a bus bombing. It’s not being racist. It’s just how the media works. The second story covers the urlLink black boycott of the Philadelphia Daily News . For those who don’t know, the Daily News is the area’s daily tabloid. It's sensational - just a step shy of supermarket tabloid, at times. On Sept. 12, 2001 its front page called for war, this was before any facts were publicly substantiated. It was irresponsible. On Aug. 22 of this year, the News ran a cover story on fugitives at large in Philadelphia. The cover photo was a montage of 18 murder suspects, all were minorities. The story covered 41 at-large suspects. Black community leaders were outraged by the cover and a boycott has followed. I agree that the cover was in poor taste, only because the lack of whites on the front cover went unexplained. This could have been banked on by the paper and could have prevented the outcry. The truth is Philly had no white murder fugitives at large so there were no pictures to include. Could the paper have chosen a different crime for the front cover? Yeah, but what's more important - catching murderers or car theives? A urlLink Los Angeles Daily News columnist summed this up and more. In the end, the story led to the arrest of 2 of the suspects. One by the tipster, the other by himself. So if the newspaper was strictly reporting the facts how can it be racist? There was no bias. You could make the statement that racial profiling is wrong but still leads to arrests and so the arrests aren't more important than the message. But this is different. With highway drug busts and other actions falling under the profiling headline, at least there are whites or other races available to pull over and arrest. This wasn’t the case in Philadelphia with murder suspects. To close out the conversation, the fight for equality has unfortunatly stalled. Too many interest groups are out for their own agenda, not a broad-based one. Why did the civil rights movement succeed? Because millions of blacks and other racial groups came together with no boundaries. It was on the national and state front. It was in the legislatures and the courts. The media took it into every home. Now it's fragmented. It's here or there, rarely both. And false claims of racism only hurt the movement. It is possible for a white person to not hire a black person for a number of reasons and not be racist - and vice versa.

"Verstehen Sie diesen Titel? Vielleicht hätten Sie eine andere Sprache einnehmen sollen." I've been quiet these past few days. I'm dealing with shock, or feigned shock. Now, on to education in the not-so-bright United States of America. Last week, urlLink Colorado defeated a measure to ban bilingual education while urlLink Massachusetts voted to force English-immersion programs on non-English-speaking students. Sounds good enough to the average U.S. citizen who thinks everyone should speak English and to hell with other languages in this world superpower. Silly citizens. This decision follows urlLink Arizona's ban and urlLink California's earlier ban on bilingual schools. I would hardly expect this from Calif., but such measures could be expected from Ariz. - a urlLink governor did, in 1987, repeal Martin Luther King Jr. Day as a state holiday and many legislative attempts failed before protests and pressure forced the state to reinstate it. I find the lack of multilingual education in U.S. schools a major blemish. In 9th grade I started German classes and took the language each year until my graduation in 1997. Following that, I took a year of German at Temple University. I've never been to Germany and at this point my grasp on the language is mediocre at best and deteriorating quickly. But I had the opportunity to learn another culture, another history, another present - a world outside the United States. Even if I never use the language again I can say that my German studies improved my English. I improved simple things, such as putting plural verb forms with plural nouns and pronouns - which so many in this country fail to understand - and misplaced modifiers - which can really sounds stupid. Don't even get me started on incorrect prepositions. OK, I'm being anal about this, but I'm a copy editor and so many in the journalism industry don't have a grasp of these concepts - in the language they write. During my German studies, I learned that my high school had once started language studies in the 7th grade. Oh, to have had the chance to start earlier and finish with 6 years of the language. Are all of these positives just a freak occurrence on my part? No. Why do you think most bilingual foreigners have such impeccable English that put this English-speaking country to shame? Would you be surprised to learn that in some countries, such as Germany, students are required to take a second language and many speak several languages fluently? My German pen pal spoke German, English and French. A Portuguese man, who works with my sister, speaks 7 languages. A urlLink BBC story notes Europe's push to start multilingual studies at an earlier age, which has some basis, but also some baloney. A George Washington University-based institute put forth a urlLink report citing no scientific evidence that children learn languages easier because their brains are more malleable. Is this a nail in my position’s coffin? No, the report does cite increased interest by children or increased contact with other languages that may spark their learning. And finally... A urlLink story from The New York Times that covers a strange phenomenon in New York City. Black students attending a Chinese school and learning Mandarin and Chinese culture and history. Not to belabor the point, but consider this the wrap-up: Multilingual studies is necessary in today's world. It creates understanding by breaking language barriers and teaching cultures. "Reason to vote for Ed Rendell for governor of Pennsylvania," or "Why Mike Fisher is an idiot" I had been planning on going more into the issues behind the governor's race in my mediocre state, but issues aren't on my mind right now. What is on my mind is how Mike Fisher's recent showing proves he is incapable of leading this state. For those who want the issues as well, take the link to urlLink Issues Pa . urlLink Click here for my past post on the governor's race. The Philadelphia Inquirer recently urlLink reported on Mike Fisher's ad campaign in Pittsburgh and his campaign's remarks on Philadelphia. For now, let's just say it isn't very nice. Some quick facts: 1) urlLink Center City District of Philadelphia lists 78,000-plus residents in Philadelphia's downtown - making it the third largest downtown population in the United States. 2) The urlLink U.S. Census site lists Philadelphia as the 6th largest metropolitan area in the United States for the 2000 census. Pittsburgh: 22nd. 3) Philadelphia is the economic center of Pennsylvania. With all of this in mind, what does Mike Fisher do? He attacks Philadelphia. Believe me, I've lived all over this state: In Lancaster County (Central Pa.) and Mercer County (Western Pa.). Lancaster has some importance to the state, Mercer, probably not - certainly Philly doesn’t draw everyone here. But I left Mercer for a reason: there's not much life there. The dying and graying of Pennsylvania has been happening for many years through many Republican governors from everywhere in the state except Philly. Yes, Philly will probably get a significant chunk of funding for schools, but guess what, it needs it! Outdated and decrepit buildings were not part of my education at any of my school districts (2) in the Lancaster County area or in Mercer County (1). Nor was it a problem in my girlfriend's school district outside Pittsburgh. It is a problem in Philly. How does capital - like buildings, books and computers - get upgraded? With money! And that's just the education side. Not to mention a need to increase density and business in the Philadelphia area to cut down on sprawl elsewhere in the state. Of course this needs to be in the Pittsburgh and Lancaster areas as well, but again, that’s a concentrated area of the state. That and a need to control pollution and cleanup, which will certainly take dollars away from areas that don’t need it. In the Inquirer story, Rendell gives the more levelheaded (i.e. well-thought political) response that all the areas have an importance, but Philly is the big attraction. Throughout the campaigning, I haven’t heard or read about Rendell attacking one part of the state. So this is why Ed Rendell is it for mayor.

New York City’s Tower of Babel To see the mostly silly, but not all so, World Trade Center designs, check out the urlLink Lower Manahattan Development Corporation’s site and click away. Without jumping all over the place (The LMDC has enough links and interactive shit to make you not come back to my site) let me tell you that former Mayor Rudy Giuliani doesn’t think too highly of the plans. If you couldn’t tell by now, neither do I. Does this mean I’ll be mayor of New York someday? The biggest problem I have with most of the projects is their desire to build higher than the previous towers, and in several instances, the tallest buildings in the world. I hardly expect anyone to fly any planes into the towers anytime soon, but 1. How many people really want to be up that high on that site? and 2. The original twin towers were much maligned when they were built for being so high. Disregard most people’s professed love for the towers, they were long despised. The following paragraphs are just my cap of the projects. urlLink Click here and you can skip to where the discussion starts up again. *** Probably the plan I disagree with the most comes from the team headed by Richard Meier. Maybe it’s because I had to study a home he designed, which I liked, for Design III and then design an addition to it. But it just doesn’t fit into the city, any city for that matter. One of the designs I like the best is by Think, which includes the architect behind the much maligned Kimmel Center in Philadelphia. This is where I backtrack and get all confusing. This team is one of those who is pushing for the world’s tallest building. But to their credit there is actual city planning involved. They include a park, which plenty of other designers do, but a park doesn’t just attract people. Included is retail space, a library, theater, transit hub ... Everything to keep an area alive from dawn to dawn. And just as important, the design is interesting. The SOM-led team proposes buildings that sit off-center, as in the don’t go straight up. For ground zero, maybe not the best of ideas. But the plan pushes sustainable design - energy efficiency, water recycling, etc. Foster also proposes the tallest buildings in the world, but he adds the green architecture slant and discusses a city transit hub, simply for my sake. Despite how precarious they may look, it’s one of the more interesting design concepts. And it certainly isn’t the phallic symbol he erected in Great Britain. The Peterson team designs from an urban planning standpoint, which is nice, but they also propose very tall buildings. Daniel Libeskind certainly has a way with designing memorials; he designed the Jewish Museum in Berlin. He proposed some of the tallest buildings in the world, but the grouping of the buildings, each jutting up further, rather that 2 monoliths without procession, make the design much more to my liking, maybe other people’s as well. His introduction and slides deal little with sustainable design, something that cannot be overlooked in today’s designs. The last design is by a team called United Architects and they certainly are. The list of members runs on and on. Their design pushes safety, but it does so with the tallest building in the world. So now back to the meat and potatoes of the post. The world of architecture is moving beyond the race to the sky. Most skyscrapers being built now - and have been completed recently - won’t place in the Top 20 tallest list. And when a buildings height is significant, it’s because the city where it is going up is short-statured - like Philadelphia. The Robert Stern building proposed will be tall, but Philly really only has 4 buildings to contend with. This new one will make 5. As for my height problem, I don't think we need to bow to the terrorist threat, but it's possible to stand up, just not stand the tallest. You also have to take into consideration people will be working on those floors that took the brunt of the crashes. Regardless of how safe anyone calls their building, when workers step onto the floor numbers that took the plane hit, do you think business will be on their mind? Skyscrapers certainly aren’t going anywhere anytime soon, but like the iMac, it’s time for the skyscraper 2. Height has already been conquered, how about now making up for what was lacking, rather than having a pissing contest. Rather than racing to the sky, which now has the added cost of skyrocketing insurance, architecture should be working on weaving their buildings into the city and focusing on efficiency, something skyscrapers have not been known to do. But that’s the ego behind it. The skyscraper almost always stands out and it footprint takes up an entire city block, which requires demolition and displacement. Hardly friendly. They also serve little purpose to protecting people on the street. Look at some older buildings with awnings and overhangs providing this protection. Fortunately for New York City, a number of the plans take the urban experience and build on it, but how successful will they be? As I mentioned with Think’s design, a site needs uses beyond offices and retail. Those all have hours of operation that, when closed, vacate an area and create dead space. The nature of a memorial will bring in additional people after hours; An amphitheater and library bolsters that space. Mixed use is the way to go for success. This and sustainable design were major program requirements for the design teams, yet many of the teams mentioned this as an afterthought in their introductions. Another aspect to Lower Manhattan comes into question. The LMDC specified 10 million square feet of office space, about what existed in the original structures. But does New York need that much? A urlLink study by Plymouth Partners , which calls itself a brokerage & tenant representative (?), found Manhattan’s vacancy rate - unrented, but available office space - doubled from 5.1% in 2000 to 10.9% by Sept. 10, 2001. Notice this number is unaffected by the attacks. It ticked up even higher to 11.6% by the end of that year. Certainly New York City will swing back in action, but there’s plenty of available office space throughout the rest of the city that the new tower plans could be scaled back some. New York City has also been known for largely unflattering buildings of late. Aside from the twin towers - which had the distinction of being the tallest - what buildings, post-1960s, really draw attention like the Chrysler, Citicorp or Empire State buildings? Which design is picked, and a few should easily make the final decision difficult, New York City could be back in whatever saddle it was in before. It also has the opportunity to go above and beyond, reinvent itself and once again earn it's reputation rather than banking on the old. Count how many bad cliches I used today and win a prize!
