Big Media, Big Problems, Part 2 The media should be in the business of news not a department of the newsmakers. I can’t say that it has happened, but if General Electric were the center of a major scandal, how would NBC (owned by GE) handle the situation? GE could use the network for damage control or even try to suppress the story. NBC might not accept/go along with the situation, but it’s a very real ethical problem should it happen. More importantly, it’s a problem that shouldn’t have arisen. GE is one of the few glaring possibilities. For the most part, the little media is owned by bigger media, which is owned by the biggest media. It just so happens, that some of them own major Internet properties (AOL Time Warner). And, of course, some are partnerships with crappy computer systems (MSNBC). Regulation is designed to make sure such problems don’t arise. Regulation should remain for this reason. We’ve already seen what happens when big corporations and people are left to their own vices (i.e. Enron, WorldCom and Michael Jackson). A scandal in the news industry would only create more outrage and destroy credibility, which is sagging already. Regulation keeps the chances of that to a minimum, something media outlets should be thankful for. Media outlets are supposed to provide news - and to stay a float, provide business to other businesses through advertising. They should not be worried about shareholder sentiment. Once again, look at AOL Time Warner. When news is about profit, it's "infotainment" and sensational - only making problems worse. As I said in Part 1, mega-media-mergers kill voices and viewpoints. Here's 2 more examples: One very real, the other potential: 1. A story lamenting the lack of urlLink "minority" ownership and access to the media has been posted on Alternet.org. Near the bottom of the page is an interesting Nielsen rating of the Top 20 most visited sites. The list doesn’t deal specifically with news sites, just the most visited. 2. The two biggest Philadelphia newspapers - The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News - are owned by the same company. If a TV or radio company bought Knight Ridder - the national parent company - chances are that company is large enough that it owns other media properties in Philadelphia and suddenly the competition dwindles. One company, would own the top 2 newspapers, a major network and a few radio stations. Different media, same angle, all the time. Thankfully Philadelphia has 2 alternative weeklies and some fairly decent niche newspapers, but niche is not where newspapers belong. To fully inform, the scope must be larger. Niche works for magazines, which I feel have a slant far beyond what newspapers offer. As I’ve said before, an individual effort must be made to combat what is likely to happen. Seek out alternative sources of newspapers. Where the people go, so goes the money in the news industry.

Big Media, Big Problems, Part 1 OK, so I missed my self-imposed deadline, but tonight was not a short night at the paper. It's a legitimate excuse, I swear. To start my media merger story, let me provide a few links: This post stems from the urlLink Federal Communication Commission ’s expected review and rule change of media ownership (i.e. who/what can own how much in a particular market or nationally; how many forms of media can be owned by a particular person/company; etc.). Through recent mergers, many of these regulations have become outdated and rather than forcing compliance, an easing of the regulations is underway. The following stories provide more background information and current thought on the matter: The first is a urlLink New York Times story outlining the FCC’s current regulations and what might happen to them. The second is from urlLink Alternet.org (not mainstream!!). The story does not support media mergers or slackening the Federal Communications Commission regulation. The third is from urlLink The World Socialist Web Site (not mainstream!!). It covers a U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruling that pushed the FCC to review media ownership. The fourth story is an older one from urlLink USA Today . The biggest problem with eased rules - hence bigger conglomerates - is lost voices. As the media consolidate into fewer companies - and fewer slants - different viewpoints and interests have more trouble being heard. Also, as voices move to accepting alternative media, they run the risk of losing credibility and possible readers and falling into the “conspiracy theory” category. Print the same story in The New York Times and a city weekly and the story will not be taken the same way. Many who advocate the weaker FCC rules cite the Internet as an example of why voices will not be drowned out in the mega-media-merger future. Let’s not kid ourselves. Who controls the news on the Internet? CNN, the BBC, a newspaper or two and a U.S. based television station? These groups already have the credibility and muscle needed to succeed on the Internet and the possibility of credible, smaller alternative news sources making a dent is laughable, unfortunately. Also, which is the most available to the most number of people at any one time? Not the Internet. Until the computer and Internet are as common in the home as the television, they can’t serve the same purpose. By the time the computer is that common, the media may be controlled by an even smaller group of people, making start up voices that much more difficult. Many who attack the weaker FCC rules cite the radio as what to expect from all media. Clear Channel owns such a significant portion of the radio spectrum, that one story quoted a source as saying that the listener is changing channels, but the channels aren’t changing. This is already beginning to happen in the news through the many wire services available. It’s not necessarily bad: The Associated Press, Reuters and others have the job of providing national and international news to smaller news outlets. But as AOL Time Warner is learning, big media doesn’t always pay off. AOL Time Warner is responsible for CNN, Time magazine and I can’t even begin to list what else. Because of this CNN can now be a news provider with hundreds of other news sources. But if you can get Entertainment Weekly news through CNN, then why bother visiting the Web site or buying the magazine? One company has essentially become an entire marketplace of competing news sources, and competition always produces winners and losers. The behemoth that is AOL Time Warner is slowing eating itself up. I’m not calling for a tightening of the regulations, but I do not think they need to be as eased as they may be. What shouldn’t happen is different media mixing. The Internet provides a viable outlet for each to make additional revenue to remain afloat, while offering competing stories with different viewpoints and outcomes. Television companies do not need to own newspapers. But as consolidation continues, people must search out the news, rather than taking what is served up on the doorstep or through their television. Actively seeking information is the only defense to being sucked in to a one-viewpoint world. That search can voice disapproval more than a letter. Why? Because when circulation and market share drops, so does ad money and so does the company.

I've found back-up material for my rather jumbled, re-edited race piece. Governor Paints N.J. Green with building That’s a headline I tried dropping on one of the stories referenced for this post, but it didn’t get printed. As Gov. James E. McGreevey begins his 2nd year, he’s become quite the green machine. His ideas are good, his rhetoric isn’t and same goes for the chances of it passing through the Legislature in tact. But politics is more about ideas and less about what gets passed. You can always scapegoat the others. McGreevey used his first State of the State address to tackle sprawl head on. His ideas include regional planning - who’d have thought one town’s actions would affect its neighbors - and incentives to build in already developed areas. That goes back to an architecture lecture I attended at Textile - Philadelphia University to newbies. A professor said that truly sustainable (i.e. green, environmentally friendly, etc.) building and design is in cities where you can improve on the already destroyed and not break what’s already fixed in the environment. So how does McGreevey plan on doing this? With a urlLink big-ass color-coded map . Environmentally protected areas are marked red (STOP) and areas open to building, green (GO). Laws, fees and taxes will making building in the green areas cheaper and more worthwhile. Environmentalists laud the plan (big surprise), while builders hate it (big surprise). Builders say the green areas are already built out. What they mean is the green areas in the nice parts of the state are built out. But plenty of cities in New Jersey have vacant areas that need help. And before anyone goes on about why the vacant areas are vacant, urban and regional planning can alleviate and clear out those problems, which will maintain and boost population. Most cities, while still losing population, are the vital centers for its surrounding suburbs and that will never change. Planning needs to add vitality and accessibility making the cities more desirable. Even during times of white flight, where were the opera houses and museums and other cultural events and places? They never moved to the suburbs, but some smaller and less grand versions popped up there. The Star-Ledger reported urlLink mixed feelings from suburban and rural officials. Some suburbs are afraid McGreevey’s plan will cut tax revenue. They want shopping centers to bring in revenue, but that’s now how it should be. Rather than spreading retail everywhere, with a Wal-Mart and Gap in every town, concentrate it to denser areas. It’s more feasible for companies: fewer stores mean fewer employees, and because there are fewer stores, the shopping population is less spread out increasing revenue at each store. Keep pristine, quiet areas that way. Chances are the population moved there for that reason, so don’t destroy it. Other officials are ready for a plan to kill off traffic congestion and pollution, but are wary of the governors plan. What McGreevey needs to add to his sprawl initiative is tax reform, so municipalities don’t use growth to cover their costs. Funding for activities and necessities, such as school and fire and police personnel, must come more from the state and less from business and property taxes. So, I applaud the Green Machine's, plan, no matter how vague the details are now, but I worry it will falter later when it doesn't fix the other problems. New Jersey has the chance to lead the nation in change - hell, even beating out Oregon as a big environmental state, but it also has the chance to stifle the efforts of others.

Philadelphia Wasteland My mom now has Internet. After providing her 1 hour and 15 minutes of tech support (and I don't have AOL or Windows), she has it up and running. Until she breaks it again. I spent the day building bookshelves and staining, so the fumes have gotten to me. This should be a fun post. The other day I was walking by the Gallery along Market Street expecting to still see Disney Hole - the thankfully failed venture - only to see a parking lot. (For lots of info on DisneyQuest, visit urlLink City Paper and type it into the search function.) This parking lot is more disappointing than the giant 1-block hole and DisneyQuest combined. A parking lot. "Yeah," some idiots say. More parking in Philly. "Blah," others say, "Another drab parking lot." "How fucking stupid," I and others are saying. What a waste. It brings in little revenue during the Gallery's open-to-close hours and from some surrounding offices - when compared to what a building with business could generate. It's a black 1-block expanse that will add to the stifling heat of the summer. I had an idea for Disney Hole way back when, but I never said anything about. Go activism! But it was the important people of Philly who decided it should go back to a parking lot. It won't help Philly; I won't be helping City Council when they run for election again. Here was my vision: A megaplex of stuff to do in Philly after the city dies each day at 7 p.m. What does Center City currently lack? The list might be shorter to name what they do have, but just a few: 1) a major theater (the ghetto theater is long gone). It's either University City, 69th Street or way down Delaware Avenue to Tasker Street. 2) recreational activities aside from drinking, 420 and criminal mischief. What could have filled Disney Void is a lower level roller skating rink (plenty of people do this, or would if it were available) or a bowling alley (plenty people do this or would if it were available). Above that would sit a major-run movie theater with stadium seating and all that goes with it. Also, along this row could be additional shops and offices (the site is big enough). Notice I did not mention a parking lot anywhere. Why? Because the site doesn't need one, even with all of the extra people this would draw. Just to refresh important people's and others' minds and inform out-of-towners: The Gallery is a major transit hub. The El makes 5 (FIVE) stops in this part of town. The Broad-Ridge Spur (subway) stops here. All 5 (FIVE) of the trolley lines stop in this area. PATCO - subway/train to New Jersey - stops here. NJ Transit buses stop here. SEPTA buses stop here as do all 7 (SEVEN) regional rail lines. What's the need for parking?? There isn't. And Monday through Thursday, I'm sure most of the surrounding parking lots sit half empty after dark, so car drivers could use them. And this venture, appropriately named Swope Square, Center or whatever, would bring x times more revenue into the city's pockets than the parking lot ever will or ever could. How many people do you know who flock to a spot because there is something to do during the day and night? How many people do you know who flock to a new parking lot? What the lot is doing is alleviating - in a minuscule way - the parking crunch, which encourages more cars, more exhaust and less use of public transit. So you have beef with public transit? Increased use, means more money for SEPTA, PATCO and NJ Transit, which gives them more money for improvements. Rather than a downward spiral, it's upward. And of course, Philly would offer more to do to attract people from the burbs and retain those who live in the city.

Why Pennsyltucky Should Not Run Pennsylvania I’m hardly a romantic, but the snow today, which kept me away from the newspaper for a second day, was very soothing and beautiful. Probably more because the mostly untouched snow did a great job of covering up the trash and sending the homeless indoors. An AP story coming across the wire this weekend detailed Temple University's plans to offer same-sex benefits to it employees and the subsequent disapproval by state elected officials. The story wasn't carried on any online news source, so you’ll have to take my word for it. The story quoted a state Representative (of western Pennsylvania) in Harrisburg who wants to fully "defund" Temple (Temple is officially a quasi-state funded university - i.e. it received significant funding from the state). The representative also said he had colleagues who would support his move. Bad! I'm currently reading "Rise of the Creative Class" by a very egotistical Richard Florida. It's an urban studies book and it notes that many thriving "creative centers" attract the gay population. Florida also notes that many businesses offering same-sex benefits attract other "creative people" because it shows the institution is tolerant and supportive. Offering same-sex benefits can attract many people outside the gay population because of this, which Temple President David Adamany noted in the story. While I do not support gay marriage (and most marriage actually) - it's been a religious-based ceremony since the beginning of time and has always been between a man and a woman - I do support same-sex benefits. I have been unable to find references to gay marriage in ancient Greece, probably the first bastion of a gay culture, which leads me to believe it hasn't ever existed in a truly accepted and popular form. Temple's benefit plan, however much anyone wants to criticize it, is strict enough. Shared property and other proof of a couple living together and committed to each other for the long term is required. Philadelphia is also the liberal stronghold in Pennsylvania, and a few other local colleges have offered same-sex benefits. This should not be surprising, nor should it be met with such strong disgust from the people running our government. These days, laws and regulations seem to impose one view’s morals rather than everyone’s fairness. Providing same-sex benefits does not take anything from other groups, it merely levels a playing field. Why is this a problem? It is this kind of opposition in the state that fuels our shriveling, graying population, while other cities, other states flourish. People are not fleeing because of the weather. I’m still here! And while on the topic of marriage, ABC reports on some of the bizarre urlLink marriage rituals of yore.

There are 2 results: In the first the aggressor wins and takes territory or the entire country and becoming an area for exploitation. In the second the aggressor loses, the winner takes territory or all and the loser is now exploited and given strict sanctions, all the while dreaming of reconquest. Examples: The Revolutionary War (vs. Great Britain) followed by the War of 1812 (vs. Great Britain); Israel's many wars with its neighbors; and Germany's loss during WWI fueling it's aggression leading to WWII. Bush would also have the world believe that because a statement, believed to be from Osama bin Laden, calls for al-Qaida support of Iraq, Iraq must be harboring the terrorist organization. Rigged Monopoly Taking away choice in the private sector is like starting a game of monopoly with the opponent already putting hotels on Boardwalk and Park Place. It's an unfair advantage, one that isn't beat easily. As the government seems more likely to loosen controls on media ownership, let's look back at a few other government-sanctioned behemoths. I'll skip Amtrak because it's quasi-governmental and some legislation (S.104) is trying to take it off the private track. Rail hasn't been profitable in decades in the United States, Britain or elsewhere, plus enough alternatives exist: SEPTA regional rail, NJ Transit, the MTA in New York and others in Chicago and Los Angeles, just to name a few. To start this post, let me point out the governmental dismantling of AT&T. It relied on efficiency and good service to beat the competition to death. The government chopped it into regional local companies, called Bells, and gave AT&T the long-distance market. In doing this, AT&T lost significant amounts of its infrastructure. Less than 20 years later, the U.S. government approved the creation of Verizon, now the dominant local carrier in the Northeast. So dominant, there isn't really a No. 2. The government has since approved Verizon to deliver long-distance services, putting it into direct competition with other players (e.g. AT&T, Sprint and MCI), while not giving those other players better access to the local market. (To note, my DSL and local calls are administered by urlLink Cavalier Telephone for a fraction of the Verizon price, and urlLink AT&T Wireless connects me to the rest of the United States, eventually the world.) Another example is Microsoft. The antitrust case has essentially fallen to pieces with joke penalties against Microsoft. Even though every major virus attack that has stopped the Internet and cost billions has been attributed to its flaws; even though it commands market percentages in the 90s for operating system and browser; and even though it has spearheaded efforts for complete dominance as an ISP, game console and wireless OS, it is apparently not a monopoly. Apple, Sun Microsystems, AOL, Netscape and Real Networks, etc. have all sued or offered "friends of the court" statements claiming losses because of Microsoft's actions, almost to no avail. Apple is still around because of an agreement between the two, Sun Microsystems' lawsuit is stuck in appeal after winning against Microsoft. The list goes on and on. It should be noted that in nearly every other field there are first, second and so on places, but not in the above 2 noted cases. Yet, the government is creating and sustaining them. And we really expect that FCC won't overly loosen regulation on the media market? Quite a frightening future with out choice. If only the right to choice had been included in the Bill of Rights. Maybe the little people would have something to stand on.

Bush is Worse at Budgeting Than I This is just a quick vent. I haven't vented in awhile. I fear I may have some legitimacy in my other recent posts, so I must cut myself down. George W. Bush released his $2.23 trillion budget on Monday, which would set record deficits this year and next. Then smaller deficits each year at least for the next 3 years. States are already facing deep deficits. California ($26 billion), New Jersey ($4.6 billion) and Pennsylvania ($600 million this year, nearly 2 billion next), just to name a few. But guess what Bush does have more money for? The Armed Forces. Last year received the largest increase since former President Ronald Reagan. He proposes another 4% increase even as the very states that are united have the worst budget deficits in more than a decade with no fix in sight. Because of the deficit and unemployement in Oregon, the state plans to close many public schools early, the numbers vary from 8 or 9 up to 20 days cut according to an urlLink AP story and the urlLink Oregon School Boards Association Web site. Only in the great United States do we spend billions more on wars outside our borders and preparing for one with Iraq - which has yet to pose a threat - while our school children are forced to have their educations cut. Is it any surprise that the United States lags behind other industrialized countries in education and learning? So you want to complain to me and say the military needs the money. I edited a New York Times story this summer, which is no longer available on the Web without paying, which reported on all the necessary items being shipped to the Armed Forces in the Middle East. And this isn't just at my newspaper. Finding a job at any newspaper in the area is proving to be challenging.

Finishing Off Where Daddy Left Off So here we are, on the brink of war - to use the already overused CNN phrase. In George W. Bush's speech last night, he claimed he has been patient with diplomacy, which has failed and that the United States citizens are a peace-loving people. Try selling that one to someone who isn't paying attention. Diplomacy failed because every resolution started or backed by the United States called for war, hardly peace. As I quoted Albert Einstein before: "You cannot simultaneously prevent and prepare for war." Bush has been preparing and pushing for war since September. Bush's latest push for war dealt with a lot from the past. There was Saddam's aggression on neighboring countries Iran and Kuwait. The United States ran to help Kuwait (oil), but where was this country, which as Bush says cares for the Iraqi people and is so peace-loving, when Saddam Hussein attacked Iran? The chance was had in the 1980s to contain him, but that never happened. Saddam was stopped by the first Gulf War and subsequent weapons inspections of the 1990s. His might is a mere fraction of what it was before. To claim he presents a threat on U.S. soil is laughable. He also brought up Saddam's chemical attack on his own people. That was also decades ago and once again I ask, where was the United State's desire to give freedom to the Iraqi people then? There wasn't any. Also, the first war and subsequent weapons inspections have destroyed and continued to hamper his chemical stockpile so this is not possible a second time. Bush also again connected Iraq to al-Qaida without evidence. I point you to 2 CNN stories. 1.) About a U.S. plan to strike a suspected al-Qaida camp in Northern Iraq. Note the story reports the camp is outside of Saddam’s zone of power. 2.) urlLink About the scant decades-old evidence Bush is basing his current standing on. In one swift stroke Bush has burned some bridges and undermined an international governmental body. And one final thing. All the pro-war people claiming anti-war activists are hurting the moral of the troops abroad and not supporting them: Many in the anti-war camp are strictly so because there is no U.N. backing. Bush is the one without support, but certainly anti-war activists are not wishing harm on their soldiers. There are some in the Armed Forces who do not support this, but it is their job. There are families of soldiers in the Gulf right now who do not support this war. There are many more families who have lost sons, daughters, etc. or had them return home disfigured and dismembered who do not support this war. There is support for our troops, but not for the policy that currently has them there. Here's to a disturbingly well executed attack against an army who couldn't present a threat to us if they had moral. Let freedom echo the bomb blasts off the walls of Iraqi homes. And may you sleep well at night while children cower in basements not knowing if they will see the sunrise. So much for peace-loving.

urlLink J'ai peur d'Américains Click on the link and copy the text in the box, then translate from French to English. Afraid seems like such a strong word, but stupidity and immaturity scare me at times. So it's fitting. Case in point, the French boycott. Yes, I mentioned this in my previous post, but it's gotten worse, if that's possible. Within the past week, a petition has formed to have the New Orleans French Quarter dubbed "Freedom Quarter." It doesn't do much for tourism because it kills centuries of heritage and history. When asked if the section of town could just be dubbed it's actual French name - Vieux Carre - the man disagreed because it was still French. He also noted most names in Louisiana are French and the New Orleans thing was just the beginning. At a pro-war rally today, some zealot stood with his poodle and a sign noting his poodle lacked any French in it. It should be noted that reinforced concrete is a French invention, so I expect boycotts of at least the urlLink the 10 tallest reinforced concrete skyscrapers . You can’t be a hypocrite and no double standards. Oh, and let’s not forget America’s greatest architect Frank Lloyd Wright. You must hate his buildings. Tear them down! In fact, most any concrete structure built since the mid-1800s must be boycotted. And just think, all of this because the French don’t agree with us. Sadly, the French are doing the very thing that America was founded on. They are standing by their ideals and voicing their disagreement. It’s the very thing that built the United States into a world superpower. It’s what led to compromises in the U.S. Constitution, which is the reason it is still relevant more than 200 years later. The U.S. colonies revolted against the British because of oppression and persecution, yet this is what we lay on those who don’t support us. In fact, George W. Bush has gone as far as saying not supporting the United States on Iraq will adversely affect economic, academic and other interests and ventures with the United States. Also, as a show of the shortsighted mentality, this country is awfully supportive of the British when only their Prime Minister Tony Blair is gunning for U.S. plans of war. His cabinet and others in his political party have threatened to quit over his support of the U.S. effort. His country refuses any attack without a U.N. resolution, yet U.S. citizens call Great Britain our friend because one man supports the effort. U.S. citizens and Bush tear down the United Nations, when the British are gunning for it. Other disturbing outbreaks: radio stations boycotting the Dixie Chicks because one singer voiced dislike and disapproval of Bush. People are smashing their CDs and a recent poll found that around 75% of those queried would return Dixie Chicks CDs. It’s all very similar to what happened to the Beatles when John Lennon correctly noted the Beatles were more popular than God. (You can call it sacrilege, but their popularity spanned religions and atheists around the world.) The Dixie Chicks have since apologized for the harshest statement but still refuse to support war. If you are going to smash and boycott their CDs, do it for a reason: because they suck, because they are part of the watered down pop scene. Don’t do it because you don’t agree with their statements. They were being very American for expressing their opinions. And for that reason, I must regretfully support them in this post.

Sticks and Stones May Break My Bones ... French-bashing used to be fun. I work across from the Sofitel in Philadelphia and it's always easy to hurl a joke in their direction. But the new vogue is lower than my potshots. "Freedom Fries"?? And served in the House of Representatives no less. And with support from U.S. Representatives? Is it possible to get any more childish? It'd surprise me. Here's the other shocking thing, which will lead in to my future post on U.S. government. All of this is over a dispute, a contention of right and wrong. It's about the U.S. grandstanding. The United States doesn't want anyone standing up to it, and that's not how things should work. Dissention happens because very rarely is someone completely right. There are more grays in the world than blacks and whites. Contention works to root out the wrongs and make the rights more so. Disagreement should lead to diplomatic fighting that in the end is resolved peaceably, not baby games and most certainly not ignoring the other side and charging ahead. So I don't know about you, but I'm about to order a supersize of french fries. A little quote from an intelligent person, to counter the shallow rhetoric of George W. Bush: "You cannot simultaneously prevent and prepare for war" - Albert Einstein.

Links to the Facts Just so no one can claim my facts were hollow rhetoric: 1.) A Reuters story reporting on the urlLink destruction of 40 al Samoud 2 missiles. That fact that people are even upset about them wanting to hold out on destroying them is alarming. Iraq is destroying missiles that would be used to counter a U.S. attack. 2.) An AP story reporting on U.N. weapons inspectors claim that the urlLink document provided by the United States and Britain were forged. The documents were to prove Iraq was pursuing buying uranium for nuclear bombs. The story also reports that radiation sweeps have turned up nothing in Iraq. 3.)Links to the frontpage story of The Times of Trenton are unavailable, but chief weapons inspector Hans Blix reports there is no evidence of weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

Bush and facts, fictions and hypotheses Originally I was going to discuss the American way that seems to have been lost of late. Not the zealots, but the dissent and compromise that have forged the United States into a great country. But then came along Bush and his 50-minute address/Q&A. *** This is how truth works: You have physical evidence (i.e. numbers, photographs, the actual piece in question). Having the truth allows you to make a case. It’s how the judicial system is supposed to work and because the judicial system is ‘fair’ it’s the basis for a lot of other things in the United States, namely making and passing laws and such. Apparently, this has escaped George Bush. The facts are this: 1.) More than 78 weapons inspectors currently in Iraq, working as teams, making random visits to any and all types of places. 2.) Surveillance fly overs by U.S. spy drones that lead to new sites inspections. 3.) U.S. intelligence reports naming potential sites, which inspectors then visit. 4.) Iraq is destroying al Samoud 2 missiles under U.N. surveillance and has turned over others (albeit after they were supposed to). All of these are reasons why most of the world is holding out on blowing the hell out of Iraq. Through all of this, Bush has said with a certainty that Iraq possesses weapons of mass destruction, that Saddam is a threat to U.S. citizens and that he is aiding and abetting al Qaida, yet he never offers proof. Where are his facts, where is his evidence? Words are not evidence. In court, that is called hearsay and it doesn’t stand up. Thankfully, Bush has not spouted the oft-said and questionable defense of withholding it for reasons of National Security. I’m not saying that Saddam isn’t capable of or hasn’t done the things Bush says, but what Bush offers are hypotheses. If he can prove them, without hollow rhetoric, he could have far more in the United Nations and far more U.S. citizens supporting a move against Iraq. Because Bush does not hold out the ‘evidence’ to the public, because the evidence he has provided to U.N. inspectors has not panned out, Bush’s position and motive must be questioned and his aggression should not be supported. We run too great a risk with starting wars on unfounded information.

God, Satan and Details OK, after much delay and a never ending introductory drum beat: The winning design for the World Trade Center site was Daniel Libeskind's, and you can view the project at urlLink the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation Web site . I feel like quite a jackass taking on a great architect's work, but I am not the only one. Let me start by saying that the gradual thrust upward of his many buildings cuts down the abruptness of them as part of the skyline, which actually plays better than the old towers. This is one of the reasons I first leaned toward his design over many of the others. It also has some nice 'gee-whiz' factors going for it, but they also weigh down the overall project. The uninterrupted sun shining between two of the towers every Sept. 11 between the hours of the first plane crash and the last tower fall has significant mean and is a nice touch, but these things will be forgotten. They always are. Details fall through the cracks. It may act as a learning experience, but it will also go largely unnoticed 364.5 days out of the year. Other great symbols will elude visitors, too. How many people will actually acknowledge the significance of the 1,776-ft. tall spire? Surprisingly, in the United States too many will not get it. Details are usually what make a building a pop, but ethereal symbolism risks losing the observer. And while the museum and such will most likely point out the meaning behind the details, explanations are tiring and may fall on deaf or overcrowded ears. People may read about in the brochures, books and articles certain to accompany this project, but to have impact, it has to be delivered and noticed while you are there. And there lies the question: Is it God or the devil in the details? My other complaint is the memorial overkill. Yes, it was a tragic event, but people do have to work there. A successful plan requires that people will want to go there to visit it as a memorial will want to go there as recreation space, will have to go there for work without being constantly reminded and even depressed. Unlike the Berlin Jewish Museum he designed, this a city space, meant to attract people for more than just reflection. Think's design included a good deal of city planning to go with their towers and that’s why I felt that design was better. Libeskind mentions retail and office space, but is short on details regarding the use of space after normal business hours. A cultural center and performance space are dropped in a paragraph or two of the design explanation, but with nothing concrete. While the design will surely change, concrete details are provided about almost everything else; why not here. These should not be afterthoughts considering they will be responsible for after-business-hours visitors. Think's design included open park space, not enveloped by reminders everywhere you turn, as well as a library and other spaces, which would work to draw people in long after the last accountant and CEO has left. My other question regards what was entirely left out of information provided on the site and in the few stories I've read since then. If this is truly to be a great architectural design how does it fit in with the movement of green architecture? Is this the beginning of a new architectural style or thought process? Daniel Libeskind has created the tallest building, but issues of safety and evacuation have been left out and so has sustainability. The safety issue was thrust forward following the attacks, yet here they are absent. Following the attacks academics and professionals debated how this would change the skyscraper. How is this a reaction to the attacks? In the end, the answer to that question will live on well beyond the sunshine and tower height. It's definitely possible I will be more supportive of the design in time, but my questions remain unanswered for now. While the "corporation" leading the design competitions and future of the site downplays the politics behind process, one must ask when is the next step and how long will it take to complete? Hopefully enough foresight has been included, because most groups don't expect a finished project until the end of this decade. By then, how much of this will matter?

Philadelphia Wasteland, Part 2 Curse me, I'm posting from a Windows... from work at the AIA Bookstore. urlLink Part 1 was posted awhile ago and dealt with the giant waste of space across from The Gallery (a Center City mall) in the form of a parking lot. That waste of prime space has spawned more unnecessary parking lots in prime urban space. For starters, a giant block or half block of blacktop does nothing to cool the city, but guess what does? Trees. It's obvious, but a urlLink new study reported in The Philadelphia Inquirer lends it some credence for the disbelievers. The first new lot sits right across from City Hall. Yes, a quarter block expanse of emptiness (Wednesday, Saturday, Sunday and Monday - the days I've checked on it so far) sits beside the seat of the most powerful municipal government in Pennsylvania. Sunday, when the surrounding streets were packed with people, 3 cars were parked there. On Monday, it appeared more construction along the street at the entrance was keeping people from using it. The Ritz Carlton and its lot share the remainder of the block. Within 2 blocks of this lot is a Border's, Tower Records (though I'm in no way endorsing them), the Prince Music Theater and Liberty Place (another mall with it's own parking lot). Other possibilities for this site are endless. Maybe a mixed-use office, retail and housing building. Even a library branch focusing of government would make sense - though that requires an overhaul to the Free Library system in Philadelphia, something needed as well. Mixed use structures would thrive on the 9-5 business clientele by day and the residents and visitors by evenings and weekends. If parking is really needed it can be hidden beneath the building or used to separate the ground floor businesses from the upper residential space. But, as with the lot across from The Gallery, making a case for parking is tough. Why? Because the lot is 1 block away from the largest transit hub in Center City. So what is the need for more parking to get people here? OK, lunch break is over. I have more about this and a better edited version will show up later tonight ... Back on my Mac... With the Ritz filling up the remainder of the block, the average Philadelphian has no need to use this block, which doesn’t do much to feed the business surrounding it. About the only use I’ve seen so far is for Philadelphia’s biggest enemy, the skateboarders (you’d think the way they make everything so not skater friendly). Some of the construction site tools and junk even make for ramps and other objects for tricks, or moves or whatever they are called. The second new lot sits between The Inquirer building and a parking garage. What a brilliant idea. The garage supports Hahnemann Hospital. The Inky has its own lot behind the building. Across from The Inky is a half empty warehouse/factory/office space with its own parking. Also in this area is a Roman Catholic high school and a pricey apartment building with its own parking. Now let me state what you can already assume. I walked by Sunday and it was empty. But it’s Sunday you say? Just a few blocks walk from here is the tourist trap and local haven: Philly’s Chinatown (apparently better than New York’s), the Convention Center, Reading Terminal Market and the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. This lot also sits between two major subway stops: Spring Garden and Race-Vine. Once again, a void along Broad Street that gives the area an air of vacancy and desolation; I don’t care how new the paint job is. I have yet to actually check if either of these spots have futures beyond the parking lot. It wouldn’t seem so. The first lot sat empty for nearly 2 years before its recent transformation and it wouldn’t make sense to blacktop a quarter of a block just to have to dig it out again someday later. It doesn’t make sense, but for the sake of revitalizing Philadelphia, I hope this is the case. The second lot was a vacant building for years before demolition started several months ago. Once again, why fill it in if it needs to be torn out again for building? Let’s hope that will be what happens.

Much to Say, Not Much Time OK, so I'm in the news room, waiting on stories. It's nearly 11 p.m. and we're still waiting for a major story apparently. So how about a digest of my current thoughts and posting-hopefuls? 1.) Sen. Rick Santorum, R-Pa., has made the news over his comments on gay sex. Certainly narrow-minded and hardly representatives of Pennsylvania's or U.S. population trends, yet these are people who end up representing. It's only part of the government overhaul needed. Beyond his stance on the gay issue, his overall mindset is very disturbing. In his world, the two-parent family is king, but where he gets this concept is beyond me. It's not that I don't support the two-parent system. Hell, I most likely would have been a different person had my parents stayed together (thank god they didn't though), but my experience and Census data finds the trend is going away from that. The destruction of the family in the United States is also far more complicated than being wrecked by "homosexuality, feminism and liberalism." A look at a urlLink report from the Census finds just 52.8% of U.S. households were headed by a married couple, 16% by a single parent and 31.2% by a non-family person(s). I can hardly begin to explain why, but it's a changing world and women wanting to be out of bad relationships or doing it for themselves doesn't make them feminists. Should we deduce from Santorum that no married parents are both liberals. And let's be real, what percentage of broken marriages could have resulted from late-blooming homosexuals? 2). Questionable sick days. A San Francisco Chronicle technology reporter was recently fired from his job for falsifying his time sheet. The newspaper new in advance he was taking off to join an anti-war protest. He asked for a sick day and his reasoning: "I was sick. I was heartsick. I was nauseated and I was depressed by the lies, arrogance and manipulation," he said. Yes, strange. Policy at the newspaper changed after the protest and to prohibit journalists from joining in public political activity with regards to the war. This I can completely understand. The catch is that the journalist was a technology reporter. I doubt his political activism would lead to biased articles on computer, phones and mp3 players. While a line must be drawn, newspaper journalist have the added security of being faceless. Editors and news reporter must refrain, but photographers, copy editors, sports writers? I think the possibility of being active and not compromising their post is possible, not that I fully condone the idea, but if someone is "nauseated" by the Bush administration, copy editing isn't exactly an outlet. Oh, and only the Rick Santorum post was written in the news room. The rest was after I got home. Do you think I even read a story after my 10:39 p.m. train left... *** Good Citizens Eat Meat ... Plenty of It (From The Good Citizen's Handbook , a collection of U.S. government pamphlets, civics texts, citizenship manuals and scouting manuals from the 1920s to 60s.)

Waiting Still? Once again, I'm not dead. I just spent the last week with 4 (four) attempts at socializing, 3 outside my usual circle of friends. Spring Time in Philly For some, Spring hits with allergies. For others it's Cancun, Mexico. For reporters in New Jersey, it's school elections and budget votes, which I got to deal with this year. (Far easier than state and federal elections, I'm sure). What really ushered in Spring for me this year: Superman. I kid you not, on 17th & Sansom streets in actual get-up, his cape an American flag handkerchief, running down the sidewalk. Earlier in the day we had a 'drummer boy' drumming to the music in his head, which to the people on the street sounded like a bad James Brown. One year, Spring started with a trek to South Street where I saw a biker type strolling down the street with a live snake around him. And my family thinks I'll voluntarily leave this city for Lancaster. Of course, Spring also comes with taxes. I finished mine months ago and spent my puny return on a futon. I could have gotten more, but I spend my year lying to the IRS claiming I have a dependent at home so they take out less taxes. In the end, I get less back, but I need it most throughout the rest of the year. Speaking of taxes, George W. Bush has signaled he's ready to worsen the U.S. debt and play voodoo economics only 3/4 of what he had originally planned. And what is really in the tax break? Not much for me. Supposedly it will create jobs, but former President Ronald Reagan tried tax cuts as a way to stimulate job growth and he called it "trickle-down," which it didn't. George W. Bush's father, who was running for the presidency in the early '80s, before settling on vice president first, called the plan "voodoo economics." You give tax breaks to the upper class to spend and business to fund employment pushes and spending increases, all which helps the little guy. But with Corporate America carrying the debt load it does, more money has more important purposes, like funding a pay down on that debt to prevent bankruptcy fears. Also, what do the rich, famous and CEOs do with their money? Buy yachts, Porsches and planes? Consume fine wine, caviar and filet mignon? Wear Gucci, Prada and Armani? How does their spending money on that help the average American citizen? Give the lower and middle class money and they'll do the economy a better deed with (pardon the stereotypes) bikes, Chevys and Fords. They'll go the grocery store to buy soda, OJ and fish sticks. They'll dress in Express, Polo and Abercrombie. This at least has a better chance of putting the cash where the cash will do the most. Will $100,000 for a single car have the same impact as $100,000 spent in local mall? Of course, for me, a tax break wouldn't up my spending much at all. The only thing I need is an air conditioner. The rest of any money would go to pay off my $43,000 in student loans and the $3,000 remainder of $10,000 in credit debt I racked up in college. So there’s my rant for the day after tax day. Philly is coming. Was the fourth to last paragraph a subtle sales pitch of the charity type sweeping the Internet these days? I always accept donations and I promise to thank you graciously in my posts :)

WMD False Alarms, Again! Is the media burying the real news about the war? Only a little bit. Last week U.S. forces uncovered barrels of "chemical agents," and the news reported preliminary findings that it was possibly a nerve gas. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld wouldn't confirm the preliminary tests, but said more thorough testing would take a few days and then they would know. The contents of the barrel were nothing more than strong pesticides. How did I learn this? The false alarm news makes an appearance at the end of an article urlLink reporting on a new potential find in today's newspapers. Will any newspapers' editorial pages take up issue with the war entering Week 4 and still no justification for the disarming of Iraq? None that I can tell. One other blunder (the list is getting hard to keep track of) on U.S. television news: Last week when U.S. forces began raiding and occupying Saddam's many palaces, a British reporter for CNN took viewers through a tour of one of Saddam's rather elaborate homes. As the camera went up the stairs and focused on the embellishments, the reporter noted that it supposedly was built with smuggled oil money that was denied to the Iraqi people. Oh, the horror! MSNBC (ugh, Microsoft) later had a report on location and that story claimed the palace was built around 1990, prior to an embargoes or oil-for-supplies trading. So what was with the false alarm report to tug on your heart strings? If only I knew. I believe this if officially a Tuesday morning musing. My 2 days off from the newspaper are Wednesday and Thursday, so I'll post on Philly's parking then. Until then, just this bullshit on the Iraq conflict.

Throw PC out the Window Yes, your crappy Wintel junk, too. As I've stated as many times as I've derided the war in Iraq, I am all about Portland, Ore. Whose Side Is the Media On? If only I could say nobody's side, but ... For the week I was away from Philly, I kept up to date on the war with The Oregonian , the Williamette Weekly and CNN. The first is the biggest daily in the Northwest and part of the same company as The Times of Trenton . The Weekly is an alternative paper similar to the City Paper in Philadelphia. Obviously the last is the better TV news source. The very liberal Weekly had the first article I saw reporting the initial chemical plant find in Iraq as being untrue. Because it had died from the news, I had already deduced that the first reports were incorrect. But it is always nice to have confirmation in print. TV news doesn't count. The Pentagon has become more careful about their reports. Several other chemical finds have been noted, but, over the days, nothing has been said about them again. As this war progresses, my respect for the international media has grown. Not that it was ever in ill repute, but they continue to ask the questions most of the U.S. media doesn’t. An Associated Press war roundup story last week really killed the stature of the U.S. media. And I do mean story, it was hardly reporting. The writer (not reporter) claimed the U.S. Marines had "vanquished" Iraqi forces in Najaf. Vanquished? Is this the Dark Ages? Were the Marines rescuing a maiden from a dragon? Regrettably the U.S. media has succumbed to zealous patriotism. Bastions of respectability still exist, such as the sarcastic reporter at Central Command in the Middle East. He wryly wondered aloud when the "press conferences" from the multi-million-dollar state-of-the-art center would be the center of groundbreaking news. It doesn't yet seem to have accomplished that. Of late, the media has balanced itself out, but required the loss of a growing number of journalists. Part of the mistake on the U.S. media's part is their focus on the technology and not the human element. That has changed some with the POW rescue and destruction of Saddam's statues, but when the maps, planes and bomb graphics come up, the war takes on a sterile, video game feel, which has probably led to increasing support for the war. Also, among the "support our troops" movement are some who feel the soldiers are fighting for our freedom. Huh?? Correct me if I'm wrong, but we are on the offensive in another country, and that country's military capabilities were thrown into confusion almost from the beginning. How were they infringing on the freedom of Americans? The United States lost nothing after September 11 but its fantasy and basic citizens’ rights. Those citizens' rights were taken away by the Bush administration, not terrorists or Iraq. In case people have forgotten, the economy and stock markets came to a screeching halt months before the attacks. The administration is also pushing to further infringe on basic American rights with its proposed Patriot Act II. OK, that’s a lot, so I’ll stop there and let it settle. Barring any more stupidity with the Middle East, I have plenty of raving to do for Portland, Ore., lamenting for Philly and complete dislike for Los Angeles. I witnessed a most frightening sight at the new Borders in Philly. There beside Dan Savage's "Skipping Towards Gomorrah" was Michael Savage's "The Savage Nation: Saving America from the Liberal Assault on Our Borders, Language and Culture." I bought Dan's book.

Return of the Cynic I'm back in Philly. I didn't realize how much I love this city. I still want Portland, Ore., but Los Angeles is a horrible city. Not that I didn't enjoy my time there, but I wouldn't recommend a visit unless you have a driver. The Getty Musuem was amazing, and I didn't even get much to the collection. The building itself was fascinating. I'll have plenty more on that and, of course, the war in Iraq. Yes, I'm happy the people are free. As I've been saying, it'd have been better if the people did it themselves or had a larger part. A CNN story this morning noted U.S. forces were working to expel Kurds (a native Iraqi group) from a city they had taken control of. It should also be noted that without WMDs, this war is still illegitimate. Resolution 1441 and all the others did not give the United States or any nation the power to wage war to liberate the Iraqi citizenry. Citizens are held to the law, and the United States should be held up to the law equally. I only mention this because support for the war has grown, even as it failed at its objective and could end up being illegal. Unfortunately, the Bush administration and media are playing a bit much to emotions and less to intelligence. Believe me, I've got plenty to go on about the media as well. But until then, it's already back to work in the drearier city of Philadelphia.

Reprieve Doing well. Getting more sleep. Working at the AIA. Working at The Times of Trenton for a few hours tonight. I can hardly get a new post together, so let me just point you to some stories regarding the USA Patriot Act; that counter-terrorism measure passed with so much zeal following the Sept. 11 attacks. While this may make me one of those bleeding liberals who will certainly destroy the country, let me direct you to a techie Web site's story regarding urlLink non-counter-terrorism measures the Patriot Act has been used for . Yes, it's still catching criminals, but the problem with the Patriot Act is that it lowers the standards necessary to begin and follow through with investigations. And simply for principle sake, hackers and thieves are not terrorists, so these new measures should not be used against them. Alaska has joined Hawaii and dozens of towns and cities across the United States in urlLink opposing the Patriot Act because of its questionable nature and ability to infringe on people's civil liberties. It's a growing movement. The measure came up in Philadelphia, but never went anywhere. An Alaska state congressman has ripped off a stance I had made earlier, that there is a price for freedom: Risk. Sobering Night, Personal Post I have a best friend named Tanitha Kulsiri and she's going to die today. I believe officially she already is, brain dead I'm told, but I cannot go and see her. I was offered a ride from Philly to the hospital, but already in Trenton and in between trains, it was so far away. I also don't think I could really visit her. I don't know if it would have brought closure or drove me mad from missed opportunities and knowing that she really wasn't there. I do plan on attending the service, that should bring me closure without the dangerous side effects. Tanitha was in a coma last week from dialysis complications, but pulled through. She woke up as herself, trying to remove the food tube, pushing out visitors and demanding to go home. She was expected to recover and was going to get a phone call from me berating her for almost leaving me without me getting her a present (inside joke) and saying "goodbye." Other complications followed, and while trying to move her to another hospital she went into cardiac arrest. That was when it ended. I knew that she had had complications before. She was hospitalized for a little more than month while she was my managing editor at the Temple News . Tanitha is one of very few friends I have from Temple, and the longest from there. She's 22 and this isn't supposed to happen. We first met over alcohol and parties in Temple Towers Apt. 109E. It led to revelations such as: "I sit behind you in Newswriting I!" From there it was work on the Temple News , more classes and faulty group projects over the summer, into Apt. 409E. Finally culminating as my No. 2 at the News We'd fallen out of each other's light following my graduation and only kept in contact through IM and on rare face-to-face occasions, because the two of us were working, and she still in school. But every time we talked again, it was as if the time away hadn't happened. We had recently started talking again daily and had planned on meeting. I guess this is how it goes when you put things off and don't seize the opportunity. I'd missed more than one opportunity with her. I really cared for her and she's one of the few girls I'd wanted to date. Feisty, witty, intelligent and beautiful. Plus she could actually stand being around me. And Tanitha, regardless of what you say, I'm bi, not gay. There's a difference, obviously. It’s been 8 years, I know how it goes. She'd been my partner in crime at Temple. From skipping classes, to causing havoc for our newspaper adviser and probably a professor or two. There was also the underage drinking, and I still have that shot glass she left at my place, and I never returned; a source of contention through all the years. There were the regular trips to the Chinese roach coach for dumplings, dinners at the Cheesecake Factory and god help me, trips to Abercrombie. We also regularly called off outings, something I'm bound to regret, because that was always the beginning of our little falling outs, but that was just how we worked. Tanitha was a big part of my formative years, personally, that is. At Textile I was a mess, but I started getting my act together at Temple. So much of that involved the News (probably something to lament) and the people I met there (not something to lament) and the few relationships I’ve carried beyond that time. I talked to a long-lost friend Lauren, photo editor for me at the News and it felt good to talk about this with someone else who knew her. An earlier conversation with a friend didn't help, but I also hadn't yet had the train ride home to process everything. Early morning discussions with Dev and Jigsha helped close out the day, and I might actually close my eyes tonight before a new day. A different day. I lost a friend today and the best I can do for myself is write about it, rather than closing myself off.

More Bad Things, Such As Supporting Bush OK, you've returned to consciousness, that's good. This hit me like a windshield in a car crash, too. A story that I was reading off the wires this weekend dealt with Bush and tax cuts. Not just the new ones he'd like to have, but his last ones and the next ones. Yes, I said next ones. Apparently the Bush administration is going to push for tax cuts each year. One can only hope that none of them do anything for the economy and it helps him lose the election in 2004. But I digress. It seems the larger goal of these tax cuts is to simplify the U.S. tax code, which in its current form, probably confuses the IRS. I’m all for that, if I could believe it. The only reason major problems, such as tax holes, loops and “Pass Go and Collect $200” for corporations, are being closed now is because moderate Republicans want to trim losses from Bush’s latest cuts. If the larger goal was tax reform, why weren’t reforms such as this included in his plan? More importantly, how much more cutting can the government afford? At this point the United States is cutting services in its bid to cut cost and trim the bureaucracy. It is not cutting entities. It is also beefing up the military. While I do support cuts to the military, allow me to explain why. Probably the only way to do so without weakening the country is through better use of NATO and the United Nations. It’s become apparent the current administration is not looking to do this, and I lament such attitude. The $80 billion price tag for the Iraq conflict could have been halved, I’m sure. Allowing U.N. weapons inspectors back into Iraq, rather than doing it (sloppily) ourselves would save resources, money and would add legitimacy to the U.S. cause. I say sloppy inspections and mean it. Stories coming across my desk this weekend noted the lack of translators and fully equipped search teams. It’s a rather shabby show and former U.N. weapons inspectors are saying evidence is probably being lost each day to looting and inexperience. While states, municipalities and Europe are strengthening through sharing, the United States is doing the opposite and it’s costing you and me more than just money. So, while I hate paying taxes, there's a reason it is one of two certain things in life. Government can't run without them. And government should exist to provide services not deemed profitably by corporations. It's why the Postal Service and Amtrak should remain federally subsidized and not shed, and why health care should simply be reined in to allow larger portions of the population to take advantage of it. Let's not handicap our government. Ah, ass backwards. OK, I digressed some more. It's 1 a.m. I'm working both jobs tomorrow; why am I up?

He didn't fully explain his fear of Saddam Hussein beyond his 'knowing' Iraq has banned weapons and is supporting al-Qaida. A second plane attack by the terrorist group against the United States seems far more likely than banned weapons or Iraqi suicide bombers getting out of the country and into ours. Jeff also believes the price of freedom is war. God I hope this isn't a shared idea in the entire Republican Party. Jeff sees nothing wrong with pre-emptive attacks and fully supports U.S. action against every terrorist, country with terrorists in it and so on. He doesn't understand that those actions are what led to the rise of al-Qaida. That U.S. self-righteousness helps feed Islamic extremism. Rather than solve the problem, U.S. action is mimicking the fatal downward spiral in Israel. Rather than halt the forward front, Israel pushes against Palestinians after each attack. And after Israel pushes forward, Palestinians increase their attacks rather than drop them. The biggest fault I see in Jeff is his inability to relate to other cultures. You can't impose American democracy on a culture that doesn't grasp it, on a culture that doesn't really allow it. Doing so is nation building, which is a degree of imperialism, something the United States has denied it is doing. But it seems the downward spiral has begun. It's not possible to root out every enemy. Let's be realistic, OK?

First Post on My PowerBook I won't bore you with the details of how great this little notebook is. If you've not considered switching by now, nothing will get through your thick head. *** Here's the story I'm going to complain about. urlLink Going bananas for the new year . You can read it before my rant, but you have to promise to return. Urban living. Supposedly more diverse, more cultured and, in some cases, more intelligent. All of these ideas came crashing down on Thursday while I was editing a story dealing with monkey sculptures. Mount Holly, a large town in New Jersey - in our coverage area from Trenton, a city, hence the beginning sentence - is already planning New Year's Day festivities. They call it First Night. To help market the event this year, they are using monkey sculptures. And why, you ask for the 2nd time? Because according to the Chinese New Year, 2004 is the Year of the Monkey. This is where my rant comes in. New Year's Day is Jan. 1, 2004. The Chinese New Year's Day, according to the lunar calendar, is Jan. 22, 2004. The problem is that the reporter failed to note this. Did the reporter know? I don't know. This small oversight also got through 2 editors before coming to the copy desk where the concensus was to inform the public. No mention of even the time difference in non-specific terms, so does the town even know this? Besides the obvious cultural faux pas, the ever changing Chinese New Year's Day is not common knowledge to a vast majority of United States citizens; probably even a large part of the cultural Chinese American population. It was additional information to educate the readers and it could have served as an excellent cultural exchange, something seriously needed in a woefully isolationist country. While the story focused mainly on the monkeys, the extra information could have changed a mediocre non-news story into something more. God knows the Princeton reporter includes 15" of bullshit into most all stories from that area, much to the annoyance of the copydesk, which ... a) is usually stretched and would rather not ready 30" "stories;" and b) can't cut much of the fluff because our job is correcting grammar and obvious factual errors. OK, done. Welcome to the real world of news. It's Saturday night and I'm going out and having a life!!

Quiet, No More Not much has been going on here. Just enough to keep me from posting. I have to get used to the effects of fewer hours in the news room. I could probably have written super-pointless posts, but instead I've opted for just a pointless one following my submersion into the news. This one is fairly scrambled. I was reading the Associated Press story on how U.S. troops in Baghdad are handling the heat. The story was slightly humorous, but apparently the heat had gotten to the reporter as well. While describing the sweating and how U.S. troops manage, the reporter stumbled across and shared TMI - not Three Mile Island, the nuclear power plant that nearly melted down, while I was in the womb and in the worst-case-scenario danger area, but too much information. In attempts to stay cool, U.S. troops don just a t-shirt under their gear and no underwear, "a state known as 'going commando.'" This was in a news story! Come on now. For starters, this is rather pointless information, regardless of the stories tone, but this is also fairly common fact. "Friends" featured it in a episode. Why not mention that the common folk in the streets of Baghdad are Iraqis. I might be overreacting to it, but it's the stupidest thing to read. I just paused and mentioned it to a coworker so we could both express shock and awe that AP editors allowed it. Needless to say, I axed that line of story. Another story that I was fortunate enough to edit (did you catch the sarcasm) dealt with an attempt by the New Jersey Legislature to offer greater freedom to citizens who want to display American flags and other "symbols of patriotism," while restricting towns from banning it. Is this honestly necessary? The Senate unanimously approved it, now it's going through the Assembly, much to my chagrin, though I can hardly do anything to stop it. The legislators sponsoring the bill note that with all the United States has been through, we should all be patriotic and be unimpeded in our effort to plaster flags and other symbols of patriotism on our hats, lapels, cars, front lawn, back lawn and wherever else we choose on our property. Why is this a requirement of patriotism? I got a Discover Platinum card in the mail the other day and, most disturbingly, the design was a waving American flag. I tucked it away until I had time to call Discover and tell them I want a different design, anything but a god damn flag. I told them I can't use a card with that on it. They probably directed me account to the FBI (Oh my God, he's bought porn, what a dirty, bad American! Add that to his file ... that we don't have because we're not really supposed to spy on the U.S. citizenry.) And I'm plenty patriotic. I use my freedom of speech and right to the press. I pay my taxes and I've voted in every election since I made Philadelphia my permanent address (I didn't give a shit who was running the show in Western Pennsylvania). And here comes the tirade... And yet, some of these examples are being infringed upon by the the U.S. government. Freedom of speech can suddenly land you in much hotter water than before the Bush Administration took over. In fact, it can lead to boycotts. Those boycotts also leave the victims alone, because people are afraid to stand up and be seen as "unpatriotic," just like the victims. Hollywood associations were screaming that the black lists of the Red Scare must not return. Isn't this the 21st century? Isn't this America, land of the free? Why was anti-war suddenly anti-American? That line was used from government officials, to media celebrities to the common folk on the street. Such rhetoric was so far from patriotic, you'd have to be an idiot to use it. When will I pay my taxes and get a tax break, rather than the millionaires (not all of them are bad), who use loopholes to already pay far less in taxes than their share? Why am I living in an era when Big Brother gets bigger because a nearly rubber-stamping Congress gave Attorney General John Ashcroft his USA Patriot Act and it's soon to be attempted Part 2, even though a growing number of municipalities across the nation are passing resolutions shooting it down because it blatantly infringes on the basic rights given to Americans more than 200 years ago. If our Founding Fathers gave us the freedom of the press, why is the current leadership making it harder to get in? Consolidation means layoffs, not mass hiring. More outlets mean more jobs, precisely what a) I need; and b) the economy needs. Whether consolidation happens or not, you can be sure in the shrinking environment, some smaller outlets will be forced to close up shop or sell, offering less opportunity for voices OK, catch my breath... My G4 laptop is here with the rest of my gadgets. Ah, to have free time... That'll be Friday, when the nice weather is supposed to succumb to rain and ugly nonsense, ruining my opportunities for a night on the town.

Letter to My Congressmen Dear Rep. Chaka Fattah and Sens. Rick Santorum and Arlen Specter, It seems gay marriage has become the political issue of the summer, after George W. Bush's sputtering war in Iraq and reasoning behind it. While I do not support gay marriage I do not feel a Constitutional amendment should be used to end it. The fact that such an amendment is working its way in the House and has yet to be killed speaks volumes about misused power, when far more pressing matters are at hand. What it reminds me of is the Prohibition Amendment - pushed through not for the benefit of the U.S. citizenry, but for a few overly self-righteous Congressmen. Marriage exists only because of religion. Government provides benefits to the married and in some instances provides marriage services through the Justice of the Peace. Who can marry who should be left to the Church. It’s quite apparent the Church is not supporting homosexual marriage, which it shouldn't. I agree with the Church both as a born and raised Methodist and as a current agnostic (for lack of a better term). What the U.S. government should be worrying about is how best to represent its citizens. I believe that exists in the realm of what has become known as “unions.” What such a thing would provide is government benefits equal to those of marriage. It would not undermine family. It would provide same-sex couples the ability to file taxes as a single household. It would allow a person to visit his/her significant other in the hospital. In the event of a death, it would give a significant other the right to the deceased’s property. And so on. What I am talking about is equality before the law, not God, which is not the government’s jurisdiction. What I am talking about is fairness. I am asking that should gay marriage move along any further in Congress that it be stopped before it becomes the embarrassment that is. Regardless of your religious beliefs, you were voted into office to represent the people of Pennsylvania. The only way you could possibly do that would be to provide an alternative that satisfies the majority of the people you represent. It’s obvious the Bush Administration has special interests in mind. Don’t let this so thoroughly taint Congress as well. I invite you to read some additional thoughts on these matters and similar issues that I have posted on my Internet blog. urlLink Santorum and gays urlLink Same-sex benefits Sincerely, Brian Swope

If Only the Citizenry Were Blameless The media are always the bad guys. It’s easy to point a finger and say “You’re biased” or “Why didn’t you report that,” or any other number of lines. For example, The Philadelphia Inquirer has come under attack over the past 34 months from interest groups for both favoring Israel and the Palestinians in its coverage of the fighting in the Middle East. Now how is that possible? Or how can The Daily News of Philadelphia be a racist paper when its readership base is largely black? Now certainly there is some bias in the media, but is its purpose to deceive? Not in a respectable news outlet. NPR radio is considered left of center. Newspapers in general are the same, while TV is all over the place. Allow me to very truthfully state that of the three TV is the worst with bias. Then radio follows with alternative weeklies and finally newspapers at the bottom. Part of newspaper’s bias comes from it’s decline. Magazines became niche players after radio and then TV served a one-two punch. Newspapers are doing the same thing. It’s unfortunate, but that seems to be the case. And what is to blame for the decline? Television, the Internet and that growing sense of apathy in the U.S. citizenry. The only one I don’t have a problem with is the Internet because it provides far more information than what any newspaper or TV could provide in their coverage. The television also provides some form of news, but these 2 media options have also killed the one thing the newspaper need. An attention span. Newspapers had responded with pictures, color, and expanded sections, but that hasn’t saved them as much as hoped. Gains have only mostly come at the expense of other newspapers. So what has now popped up is this “newspaper” called The Metro . It’s for the short-attention-span citizen. I’d not gripe about it so much, I mean at least it’s some news, but how can people scream bias when this extremely and unfortunately popular global newspaper devotes 10" or less of a story to something that The Times of Trenton ran as 20" and The New York Times ran as 70"? Something is getting lost in the editing here. Could it be facts and other such things that round out a story and give both sides equal time? Probably. The problem with all forms of media is that financing must come from somewhere. Newspaper ads fill editorial space and commercials cut into news clips. Of course, this all works for the short-attention-span citizen, but they need to understand something is missing. Then there are the people who already know this, but being passive readers, they let it go. Then there are psycho news people such as me who avidly readers local, regional, national and international news sources, both independent and mainstream. If more people picked up The Metro as a supplement and still read The Inquirer or whatever major newspaper covered the area, there would be a great balance. Certainly each of the different media requires the others to be successful. The effect could be far better if people were active. How do I know most people are passive and not helping the situation? An urlLink Inquirer poll in June found that 1/3 of American believed U.S. forces had found weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. Err. Wrong. Silly readers. I guess they missed this story.
