O Canada, That Liberal Bastion So the liberals are fleeing this "increasingly conservative" United States of America. So says an Associated Press story. It ran in The Times , but didn’t get posted to the site, so as usual, here’s the story on urlLink CNN . Funny, the conservatives think this country is getting a bit too liberal. But the liberal types are fleeing and I’m not in tow. Going to the land of milk and honey, while nice, would leave me with far less to gripe about. Without that, I’d have no reason to live. I prefer to point out the stupidities and circular logic all while remaining faceless and almost placeless and being the passive activist. I’ve actually never been drawn to Canada. I’ve always had my eyes set on south of the border - Mexico or somewhere in the Caribbean. I’m cold-blooded, so I need to the sun. I’ve also go this penchant for spicier foods, not French cuisine or buffalo. Yes, the more liberal gun control laws and the decriminalization of marijuana means safer streets and more laid back mornings, afternoons, evenings and nights, but why just give up here. Sorry for the delayed warning, but idyllic banter follows. The story notes that people feel Canada better represents the ideals of the United States - set in parchment and blood so long ago - but that’s all the more reason to stay and vote. According to the urlLink Federal Election Commission about 51% of voting-age U.S. citizens actually did the deed in the 2000 elections. Pretty depressing number, don’t you think? That number improves to a whopping 67% of registered voters actually doing the deed in the 2000 elections. Is it not possible for more people to take part? Hell, 1/3 of the registered U.S. citizenry didn’t vote. Couldn’t that have made a difference? It’s not really asking much, just for people to smarten up. I think it’s happening now; better late than never. Approval for George W. Bush continues to fall, as some people realize they were just caught up in the borderline urlLink fascist frenzy following Sept. 11, 2001. Others are just tired of the war they once supported. Maybe they aren’t doves, but maybe they are espousing the dovish cry: “Support Our Troop, Bring Them Home.” See, things just take time. I’m sure the United States could include some liberalism and corrections to itself, but that would require the Green, Reform and what ever other parties there are, to get some people into office. In most every other democratic society, many parties make up the government, but not here. We’re stuck with 2 choices, and, as has been the case, the lines blur between them a little too often. Rather than flee the country in pursuit of good weed and gay marriage, stay here, curse the president and get active. Oh, and smoke a bowl in your backyard. Decriminalizing weed can take away some of the fun to it.

Balls: 2, Strikes: 2, Outs: 2; for SEPTA It’s a bit fatalistic, but all public transit, not just SEPTA, needs help. I’ve been meaning to get this post up for God knows how long. Anyone who has been reading this blog devoutly knows that I’m not afraid to correct myself or attack myself worse than most critics could. It’s part of my self-depreciating manner. The following correction wouldn’t need to happen if Philly just got its act together. But I have a better chance of being reincarnated as someone important. I’ve spent 2 lengthy posts dealing with Philadelphia and its bad habit. No, weed isn’t so bad. I mean the proliferation of parking lots. The urlLink first dealt with the parking lot at the failed DisneyQuest next to the Gallery. The urlLink second dealt with other lots on prime real estate property. I’m not opposed to parking lots when you sink them several levels underground and put a building on top. I’m completely against them otherwise. There are 3 main reasons for this: They are a waste of space for more than half the day and a waste of revenue for their entire life Heat islands in the summer and in suburbia they prevent water from reaching the soil The ability to attract drivers hurts public transit While SEPTA’s budget disaster is currently on hold, its proposed fixes allow it to almost operate unscathed for most of this fiscal year. But to what end? Another standoff next year? Pennsylvania’s funding to SEPTA hasn’t matched inflation each year, so funding has actually taken a cut throughout the high-flying ‘90s when the state was recording surpluses. The state is considering fixes, including using highway funds for public transit. Good idea, the last thing this state needs is more roads. Philadelphia needs SEPTA (any city needs public transit), but SEPTA needs riders. So why does the Parking Authority compete with SEPTA by adding lots to every empty piece of land in the city? The lots that I complained about in previous posts now enjoy being filled with cars for 8 hours a day. (That’s my correction) All the while Philadelphia’s life blood is languishing. The car culture has been killing cities much slower and much longer than the government’s push for suburbia after WWII. Two examples: the horrible cities of Atlanta and Los Angeles. The sprawl there is ungodly. Philadelphia stands as one of the few remaining large walkable cities in this country and unless the city and state get with the program, it’ll be destroyed. Each year public transit is forced into a showdown it loses riders. Every time there is a fare hike, ridership dips. Every time frequency takes a hit, ridership takes a dip. Fewer riders means people are using other means to get to work. A vast majority will turn to the trusty automobile, but the trusty automobile worsens the lives of city dwellers with it fumes. The more cars, the more parking lots and the more parking the lots the more sprawl, which required more cars to get around. Do you see the vicious cycle? I support public transit all I can with my bus/subway/trolley/el/regional rail pass each month, but I can’t do it alone. So if you’re a city dweller and your reading this put down your car keys and pick up a token and do something good for your city. Obviously having a car is a necessity for some, even in the city, but while you in it, you don’t need it, so don’t waste it. *** Hmm, some cheese there at the ending. That’s what I get for putting this down for a day to go out and hang with friends. I lost the vibe, but hopefully you didn’t suffer too badly.

And I was thinking to myself. Either I am a government insider, a cold, heartless objective person or an idiot. Why? Because I vented about this months ago. If George W. Bush would have just listened to my reasoning, we could have skipped the already and ever more expensive war in Iraq, plus he wouldn’t have these credibility issues. And might I add the very mature White House has turned to finger pointing and blame games to cover it’s stance. I spent the entire month of urlLink March espousing my stance and I urge you to read it, if only to boost my Page View numbers. I would have shared this with everyone sooner, but I vacated my apartment last night after this city gave a permit to some group to preach God and fight violence. It wouldn’t have been so bad, but the gathering must have been barely funded because the main voice was not good at speaking and he has a thing for soul screaming. This partly fueled my trip to Washington D.C., me vacating the apartment last night and re-vacating the apartment tonight. I’m acting like it’s Hurricane Claudette up in here.

Today’s Top Story... Yes, there was that shooting at the Lockheed Martin site, but that’s not the big news. Murder is all too common. Yes, George W. Bush’s State of the Union address was flawed, but what intelligent U.S. citizen didn’t already know that? Today’s big news was that Britney Spears isn’t a virgin. CNN.com had that as the lead entertainment story. Apparently during this slow summer, no one was able to come up with a story on CD piracy, whether Madonna still has ‘it,’ or if Ashton Kutcher and Demi Moore have yet broken up. They found time to report on something terribly obvious. Probably more so than the White House gaffe about Iraq. At least that had forged documents. Incidently I was talking with my friend Damon just the other day about infotainment and the no-balls media. What should appear the following day but the most pointless story in America? Also, you may be wondering how is it that this is a slow summer? All summers are slow in the news media. People are out traveling, ad dollars don’t flow as well ... The war in Iraq would have played out differently in the news had it taken place over the summer. The Britney story probably wouldn’t have happened. (Hmm, was I earlier saying I didn’t support the war in Iraq. Maybe I’m changing my mind...) But what about all the kidnappings last summer? The number of children abducted last summer was urlLink fewer than in 2001 , which was fewer than in 2000, which was fewer than in ... You get my drift. God knows the pages and airwaves have to be filled with news, so during the summer it’s much easier for something to catch on and become blown out of proportion. The year prior, 2001, had been the “Year of the Shark,” but guess what, there were urlLink fewer shark attacks that year than last... Now before you decide to lower your respect for the media, don’t forget that heightened awareness most likely saved at least 2 children from being abducted last summer. The shark attack hype probably saved one person from death. There is always a little bit of good to go with the bad. So now I’m off to bed. I think I’ll sleep better knowing Britney’s not-so-secret secret.

Diddy, Puff Daddy or whatever was too much. *** A Few Things I Won’t Miss at The Times The air conditioning system which forced employees to wear pants and jackets and use heating units from May to August. Any story written by Michael Jennings. His metaphors actually detract from his stories. For instance, the budget crisis coverage was compared to a tumor. Why not use that metaphor with a medical malpractice legislation story? Metaphors aren’t the best writing technique to start with, but if you’re going to use it, make it match the topic! Having to constantly edit out “in which,” “of which,” “during which,” “with which,” etc. Don’t waste time saying: The Civil War was the war during which brothers fought brothers, when: The Civil War was the war when brothers fought brothers is much more succinct and not awkward. Or: This is the hand with which I am going to edit the hell out of your bad story, when: This is the hand that will edit the hell out of your bad story packs more punch. *** So the final night went really well. Recall the Recall OK, so how old is this issue? I’m slow getting around. My excuses are in the previous post. While more than one reason exists for the backlash against Governor Gray Davis, the one issue fueling the debate and recall is the budget crisis. For some reason, the most populous state seems to have a much higher percentage of people without a clue. Nearly every state in the union is facing some sort of shortfall. New Jersey was facing a shortfall of about $5 billion earlier this year before estimates changed to slightly less and then painful cuts and accounting tricks closed it. My state, Pennsylvania, was facing a deficit of about half that. But California was facing a $38 billion ($8 billion still after the budget passed) deficit you say? California is also the most populous state and the largest economy within the union, so of course it’s problems are going to be larger to match. The budget woes in that state can be blamed on a lot of factors, the least being the person in office. He may share blame, but he shares it with the Legislature as well, and that is made up of his supporters and critics. No one’s hands are clean. And honestly, blame can go the whole way up the Bush Administration in Washington, D.C., and even prior to him, with the Clinton Administration. The general trend in the federal government over the past decade has been to push services, agencies, etc. onto the states. Welfare is probably the biggest. Education has been straining the states following Bush’s initiatives. Then came all the needs, monetary and more, for protecting against terrorism. Medicare may soon be unloaded onto the states and if Bush has his way, so will Amtrak. No one wants to raise taxes, but the federal government pushes these services to the states so it can cut spending, which means the difference has to come from someone’s pockets. More importantly, Bush’s tax cut proposal did not call for budget crisis aid. That came from the Democrats, and the funding has been helpful, on some level. Back to the recall: What about the candidates? It’s a discombobulated mess that makes the 2000 national election look like horseplay. How are we supposed to take this seriously, this theatric mess in the most powerful - politically and economically - state in the union? What does it say about the state of government in the United States of America? Yes, elections should be open to all, but how about all who actually have a purpose and a real agenda? How many actual politicos are running? It should be noted that the legislator who funded the recall and announced his candidacy has since dropped out. More importantly, a midterm election costs money, something the state doesn’t have right now. In general, governors from across the country are supportive of Davis, if only because the thought of a recall election shakes them to their bones. At first the thought of the Terminator running for governor didn’t sound like such a bad idea. Sonny Bono was successful, as was Jesse Ventura. But after seeing one of his political ads, I’ve decided the idea of it is laughable, and I mean that sporadic awkward laugh not at the bombed joke, but the suffering comedian. Gray Davis is in his second term and that so many citizens have apparently turned against him so suddenly says to me that it’s a “heat of the moment” response and emotions rarely play out successfully for the long term without a fair helping of rationality. If rationality had played any part in the proceedings so far, there wouldn’t be porn stars, 100-year-old ladies and Hollywood types filling the ballot. There would be politicians with an agenda and a history to them. The ratio is very out of whack. California is out of whack. I can only hope that by October sensibility will return and the recall will fail.

The Media: It’s Own Worst Enemy The urlLink Associated Press reported yesterday that even as Congress is pushing to undo the Federal Communications Commission’s loosening of media regulations, the National Association of Broadcasters is suing because it doesn’t feel the FCC went far enough. NAB doesn’t represent your local ABC, NBC or CBS affiliate, it represents the larger entities. To complicate matters, the smaller local affiliates are fighting their parents and siding with Congress. The larger media want the regulations slackened so they can grow and compete. What this amounts to is more money. The larger television networks have mostly matured and, naturally, there is a desire to expand. Unfortunately, 3 or 4 major networks cannot all expand. I can imagine that NBC would love to have 45% of the market across the United States, but does it do anyone any good if all NBC is broadcasting is crap? I know I’d love to be able to watch essentially the same reality TV show on even more stations. “Last Comic Standing” is already broadcast on two stations (NBC & Comedy Central) as is “Queer Eye for the Straight Guy” (NBC and NBC-owned Bravo). I’ve only seen each of these shows once and not in my own home, but I know of the dual showings through stories at work. Now isn’t the growing number of stations supposed to mean more variety? If the networks already are failing with caps in place, what can we expect when they have more stations? Most likely it’ll be a lot of the same stunt, it just won’t be so obvious. Maybe the focus should be on quality of programming, not quantity of ownership. I wish I could comment further on that, but I really don’t know what’s on anymore. When “Seinfeld” ended (horribly) my TV viewing took a hit. When “X-Files” called it quits (thankfully), my TV viewing took a hit. Now I can’t even remember what day to watch “That 70s Show” or “Law & Order.” And most of the time I’m working. Obviously other shows must fit the ‘quality programming’ bill, but I’m pretty certain there’s more crap. That’s at least what I can tell from the reviews and the death toll articles that abound one month into the new programming season. So rather than empower corporate America, how about power to the people? Congress is certainly urlLink trying to push back some of the FCC’s loosened regulation, but not all of it. A bid to do” that failed in the House, but a bill reconciled with the Senate version still has to pass and Congressmen can be swayed if they hear enough backlash. It’s the only thing more influential than money. *** I’ve somehow tapped into a wireless network in my building, but it’s dial-up, so it’s slow and whoever the person is with it doesn’t leave it on all the time, so this is coming to you from the AIA. This downtime is probably good. I fear Internet addiction on occasion, but my withdrawal hasn’t been difficult at all. Plus, I’ve been reading, writing, cleaning up, job hunting and pushing for a move to Portland, so it’s been a productive week so far.

Conspiracy Theory Collision So the last post was debunking one, now I’m supporting one. On Sept. 2, it was reported that a major asteroid was on a collision course with Earth. It would hit on March 21, 2014 and lead to chaos and death, according U.S. stories. The BBC was a bit tamer. The next day, it was reported that “sorry, we were wrong and overzealous” because the odds were a long shot and getting less likely each day. The story has become a yearly event since 1998, but to what purpose, when each time the actual doomsday scenario is immediately blown off? why not notice it, study it for a few days, recalculate and skip the trouble? They latest collision would have been 11 years away, giving them ample time to correct themselves before going public. But the current method has a “crying wolf” effect. People react to the doomsday story, but then are reassured. A few more of these and fewer and fewer people will notice each time the story is reported, until finally the story is reported, but there isn’t a follow-up stating the collision won’t happen. Does this sound a little crazy? Yes. Did the BBC ask this question several days after the last doomsday revelation? urlLink Yes. Do I think an asteroid is heading straight for Earth in the near future? No. But if it were, if March 21, 2014 was going to be doomsday, how would the world react if people were told about it? Would people stop paying their bills, stop worrying about getting ahead? I think so. I know I’d stop paying my bills. At least my student loans. I’d need to keep a line of credit open for my 11 years of partying. Maybe if the story would break, a contingency plan would be offered up, as a way to save the human race. By this time, there might be a much more substantial space station. There might be a moon base, but nothing that would support a large portion of the world’s population. Surely some would stay and accept their fate. Armageddon is built into all the major religions, but not everyone who wanted a chance to get off could or would. The effects of a real threat of collision could certainly lead to serious complications for governments around the globe. Of course, the U.S. could pull an Armageddon style trick out of its sleeve, if only they hadn’t starved NASA for as long as they did. ** Well there’s a refreshing “over breakfast and before work” read.

I’ve Contracted a Conspiracy Theory This is not the post I’ve been promising for days, but this is a little more intriguing, so the other will wait. It’s not often I delve into science and what’s possible or not, but recent debate among my friends and on the subway has fueled my interest in the matter. After rather substantial research into the topic, I’ve found a disturbing amount of literature and people who support and believe HIV is a U.S. manufactured virus designed to kill off gays and minority racial groups. As is the case with all conspiracy theories, both sides have just enough strengths and weaknesses to fuel the theory. For instance, urlLink David Gilbert , who writes a very strong case shooting down the theory, is considered a political prisoner and is serving a prison term of 75 years for the murder of several law enforcement officers. His writings also bring to light several facts that were left out of writings by those supporting the theory. The pro-theory side has history on its side; the U.S. has tested and infected minority populations - it was U.S. policy to eradicate the Native Americans, and the Health Department did purposely infect scores of black men with syphilis, only to later call the test meritless. This is just the tip of the iceberg. I’m not about to repeat all the facts and "facts," but here are a few links. Debunking the Theory: David Gilbert’s story is in a format difficult to read, but urlLink Tracking the Real Genocide offers some facts to debunk the conspiracy theory, plus the ramifications of believing it. urlLink CNN also devotes a story to both sides, which includes links to more information. Feeding the Theory: I could provide links from now until next year, but urlLink totse.com provides all the basics and presents them in a factual manner, unlike 90% of the sites you’ll stumble across using Google. ** I first heard this theory while riding the Broad Street Line in the early morning on my way to work at the Bookstore. A young black man was hawking an underground monthly newspaper detailing the oppression of blacks in the United States. I was completely shocked when I heard the man reading the headline accusing the U.S. of creating HIV to wipe out the black population. I asked my friend Jenn, who took life sciences classes in college, if she thought this was possible and true. She did. Damon and I recently debated the theory and he agrees with it. Even without the fudged facts used to hold up the theory, the desire for wanting to wipe out a race and then accomplishing it so successfully is difficult to believe. It has been tried, but it has always failed. To do this successfully in America would require a conspiracy of daunting proportions. It would have to hold up through each of the administrations in the White House. If some of the theorists’ thinking is to be followed, this conspiracy would also require the United Nations and the governments of scores of countries. It would require the acceptance of the scientific community, of the medical community. More importantly, it has never been the policy of the United States to wipe out the black population. As colonists, Americans were bringing Africans to this country by the hundreds of thousands. Once the government outlawed the importation of slaves, slave masters turned to breeding to increase the black population. Skip ahead a few hundred years and blacks and other minorities still represent a form a cheap labor. It’s rude to say, but the facts support it. Whites are the highest paid workers. If it is the purpose of HIV to kill off minorities, who is suddenly going to fill the gap? Is Senator Rick Santorum’s son going to serve me the Chicken Fingers Meal at Checker’s? Someone has to do it. So the U.S. spreads HIV to Africa to kill off that population. Now who is going to dig up the diamonds and emeralds for the rich white people to wear? Vice President Dick Cheney’s granddaughters? I don’t think so. The United States is a capitalist society and for capitalism to succeed, there must be this tiered society. You can’t chop off the bottom and expect the upper levels to hold steady. Yes, HIV is many times more prevalent in the gay and minority community, but there is a laundry list of reasons why. From health care to education opportunities, from money to belief in these conspiracy theories. From hedonism to apathy. Never mind that creation of HIV means that in a decade (theorists point to its roots as circa 1967), the U.S. military started research into an immunodeficiency virus; a separate group of scientists coincidentally created gene splicing (1973); and the military then successfully created HIV using this cutting edge biotechnology, which then gained a foothold in the population in 1978. It took the United States nearly a decade to get to the moon and that is far less complicated than unraveling, understanding and controlling the building blocks of life. It should also be pointed out that the original theory of the U.S. creation of HIV started in East Germany in 1987. For anyone who doesn’t remember, that was still during the Cold War, when propaganda between the Communist Bloc and the West was designed to instill hatred and fear in the other. While not all propaganda is incorrect, theories and ideas during this time must be viewed with a certain amount of skepticism. What the United States can be blamed for is the institutionalized disenfranchisement, and at times racism, which has both fueled the conspiracy theory and the epidemic. But to claim HIV was created by the U.S. government to decimate and kill off minorities and other groups is to give the government too much credit. NOTE: All facts and “facts” - dates, places, etc. - have been culled from the sites I link to. NOTE, as well: HIV virus is redundant, so I didn't use it that way. Neither should you.

The First Anniversary It was one year ago when this blog started. Wouldn’t it have been nice to throw the redesign up? Yes, for some, but I generally ignore important dates and holidays. So it’s still coming. I’m not sure if anyone can tell, but I think my writing has improved immensely since that first post and the Sept. 11 anniversary lamentations that followed. I won’t be lamenting so much this year. I am without a news job, and while the memory or effects of Sept. 11 haven’t worn off, the very open awareness and expression of that day does seem to have died down - only more so for me now that I’m not paid to read the stories. I’ve covered many topics, some with more tenacity, others with less knowledge. While not a lot has changed, much has happened over the past year. We started and ended a war, which we were never in a rush to start anyway - so the Bush Administration said. Bush’s ratings have tumbled because of it. He asked for another $87 billion, on top of the $79 billion he initially called for, all while cutting government revenue. We finally have Osama bin Laden’s whereabouts narrowed down to 40 square miles, whatever that means. Fighting ended between Israel and the Palestinians following a new peace plan, which subsequently faded into fighting and resignations. The government’s tenacity with attacking white collar crime seems to have faded. Skateboarding has become the “hot button” issue in Philadelphia politics, even as thousands leave the city each year for other destinations. I’ve lost my job in my major at Temple University, and my friend Chris has yet to land one. Jigsha very successfully moved from an internship to a newspaper job, and Jenn had her store closed down, only to move onto something better. My rent went up at the Philadelphia Regency, while the building’s condition continued to justify the amount even less. A very close friend of mine passed away, at age 22. My sister started a relationship and is now engaged. I’ve started my first relationship in 2 years. And so it goes. The next year holds many changes. From graduate school to my big move to the West Coast. Veronica is applying to college and Damon is starting a new party for the Philadelphia area. Oh, and the world will get to see if “The Matrix” trilogy is truly a mess or if the 3rd movie will save it.

Ketchup I stumble out of bed this morning, pour a bowl of Cocoa Pebbles and beginning my morning routine of catching all the news, what's fit to print and not. What should I find, but a story of delayed tactics in the CD industry. According to urlLink The Register , Universal Music Group is slashing CD prices by 31% in a bid to boost sales. Is it too late for the industry to save itself? Maybe, maybe not. If it does, it'll be a wake-up call to the rest of the industry, and I'll certainly purchase a few CDs I've been holding out for. More importantly, it actually offers competition to iTunes and its rip-offs. One of my last nights at the newspaper involved some serious talk about the evolution of music media: from vinyl, reel-to-reel, 8-track, cassette, CD to mp3. There will be CD buyers for time to come because there's just something about holding the CD in your hand. Something about the cover art, lyrics and whatever else comes packaged. The pricing had been getting quite insane. I worked at Tower Records when the industry moved CD prices from $17.99 to $18.99. The across the board change didn't make sense. The Beatles, while worth every dollar ever spent on them, shouldn't cost $20, 30 years after they broke up. It’s all royalties at this point. There are no advertising costs anymore; no more studio time fees to recoup. What baffled me more is how a Beatles CD, 40 minutes of music that changed the world, cost the same as the latest pop star wannabe who would be forgotten before a second song was released. That whole fiasco, and the T1 line at Temple, led to a major Napster addiction. Better than 600 songs later, it all came crashing down. Napster died and I moved off campus and dealt with dial-up. Now it's iTunes and the addiction to that would be stronger if more artists and labels would just stop fighting the movement. You lost. Rather than fade away by your own actions, stick around for awhile. I'll pay $9.99 for that mediocre to good CD and $.99 for that one really good song. You'll get your money in the end.

After much dismay over the math sessions and much delight over the verbal sessions, I took the 2 practice tests. The GRE uses the same scale as the SAT. You can top out at 1600. When I took the SAT, I scored 1110. On the first GRE practice test I scored 1120 (560, 560), without finishing the math section. Odd, I thought, I prefer writing, I dropped the math-focused major years ago. On the second practice test I scored 1200 (560, 640). That really freaked me out. I completed the math section and did much better on it Both times I started the test after 10 p.m. I’m a night owl, how can I take the test with the early birds? Christ, did I do my undergraduate major in the wrong subject? But because I did better I can assume I learned something, or probably I learned how to better take standardized tests. Bush Is a Little Slow, His E-mail is Slower Earlier this week, after watching a TV ad regarding the Climate Stewardship Act (information available at urlLink Undo It , I signed a petition, which was forwarded, through cyberspace, to my elected members of Congress and the White House. Below is the e-mail header for the version forwarded to the White House: From: bswope@att.net Date: Tue Oct 21, 2003 20:17:35 US/Eastern To: president@Whitehouse.GOV Subject: Please Support Climate Stewardship Act Now here is the e-mail header of the response: From: Autoresponder@WhiteHouse.GOV Date: Tue Oct 21, 2003 21:25:26 US/Eastern To: bswope@att.net Subject: RE: Please Support Climate Stewardship Act It took more than hour to auto-reply to my message. It also went on to state that my ideas and comments are very important to Bush. I somehow doubt that, seeing as how I’m actually placing my bets with one of the long-shot Democrats. It wouldn’t be so long a shot, but I wonder when these candidates and the even the Congressmen will stop sounding like broken records. For instance, last Sunday on “Meet the Press,” Sen. Bob Graham (D-Fla.) was pitted against Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.). Tim Russert asked several questions about the new free $87 billion for Iraq. I’m usually a McCain supporter, but his Republican side really showed. All he could go on about is the United States’ place as a world superpower and how the $87 billion was justified. World superpower? 2003? The Cold War ended more than a decade ago and the United Nations, started so long ago, should be the only body even attempting that title. The idea of “world superpower” is why we have so many enemies. Its idea is why this country elected a brash, uncouth uneducated, jackass into office. It’s time to cut the world superpower title. But I digress... Graham’s response to each question of money was only about how the U.S. needs to pull troops from Iraq and get the United Nations involved. Hmm, maybe we should repeat the question Sen. Graham? I could now go into the need for third parties in the U.S., but I’ll leave that for further along the election trail. I only wish the White House had asked my party affiliation prior to the fake e-mail response. That way I could have gotten a response with the feelings Bush made so obvious following Sept. 11 and the Republican response: As someone who doesn’t support his and his party’s measures, I’m un-American.

My Personal and Political Dichotomy Who do I vote for if I don’t think either mayoral candidate is what Philadelphia needs? It’s not something I ever expected to have to ask. Ever since I’ve had the power to vote, I’ve taken to it with quite a bit of zeal. But Philadelphia is working to snuff it. The race in Philadelphia is very much like what would have happened, had Al Gore opted to run for president again. I’m very supportive of Al Gore; I think he was robbed, and I think he could have done a lot of good for the United States. But a repeat match up would not have been a good thing. Other issues suddenly come into play, issues that wouldn’t do anything for the political climate in America. And that is my problem with Philadelphia. How can a city this size run the same two opponents from 4 years ago? It makes for an awfully blah election year. And here’s the real dilemma, the lack of political activism exhibited by my city is killing my political activism. It’s a vicious cycle. In the end I’m going to vote for John Street because Sam Katz obviously hasn’t been good for Philly before, why would he be now. He lost last time by 9,400, a margin several times larger than what Gore and Bush saw in Florida. My only problem with Street is that he is too political. He tries to shutdown skate boarding in the city, but as soon as the idea becomes too politically hot he wants the X-Games to return and promises a skateboarding park elsewhere in the city. He bowed to the federal government and accepted the closing of Chestnut Street at Independence Hall, even as city businesses attacked the idea, but once it became obvious how much the closing was a problem, he backed off and pushed for its opening. I don’t mean to say only bad things. Philadelphia schools are making some headway after the state and city worked to revamp the district. Better education means better lives for Philadelphia children. I have 2 less abandoned rowhouses I can see from my apartment window because of his Neighborhood Transformation Initiative. Fewer abandoned rowhouses means fewer places for drugs and whatever else goes on behind those decaying walls. His abandoned car initiative helped clean up the streets of Philadelphia’s neighborhoods, making more room for cars with owners and less room for what an abandoned car can hold. Mayor Street has gotten much started, he’s carried on some of what former Mayor Rendell started, and all of this feeds the future. These initiatives must continue to bring people back to Philadelphia. New initiatives need to be made. Such as completing Penn’s Landing and fighting sprawl. The city needs to work more with the state to get college students to come to and stay here. Can Street do this? I think so. I think that the growing chorus of complaints against him will have to force him to change his tune; not turn it around completely, but adjust and make it more better for Philadelphia, rather than better for those connected to him. And for all the doubters, I’ve debated some with friends and after all the GOP stealing another election rumors, it comes down to a few things. Philadelphia didn’t get worse after Street took office, it just got better slower. All of Street’s major initiatives started before Sept. 11, 2001, except for Operation Safe Streets. That was the year the economy collapsed, that was the year cities and states were forced to pick up the tab on security. These 2 problems take a bite out of growth. I figure that once things get started again economically, improvement in Philadelphia will pick up. I’m leaving Philadelphia next year for graduate school. That will be 2 years away, and hopefully 2 years in a much more progressive city planning environment. After those 2 years are up, where will I go? I would like it to be Philadelphia, I can only hope the coming election results will convince me to return.

An Apple a Day Keeps Tech Support at Bay As anyone who’s read this blog and/or visited my personal site even once knows, I’m an Apple freak. Not quite like those crazy people who fill the Mac chatrooms and are in love only with their Apple computer - I split my love with a few other people. I’m gladly forced to love Apple more and more every day. My jobs strictly use Wintel junk. It’s to be expected; AIA Philadelphia is a nonprofit with some strained cash flow, as I understand it, and the Bookstore is a little independent shop that helps fund the Chapter, as I understand it. But recently, the Wintels have been extra evil. Such as during the August worm/virus attack, when I spent 4 hours downloading updates. Or every other month for the past 6 months when the Dell Precision Workstation doesn’t work - to be precise. We supposedly have next day, onsite maintenance, but only after filling out an impossibly long set of criteria that was e-mailed to us. So today I spent an hour doing all the troubleshooting I could, only to come up with a system no less broken then before. So I replied with my responses; when they’ll get it, read it and give “next day, onsite maintenance,” I have no clue. Meanwhile, I’m using my G4 laptop each day to do my work at the Chapter. When I first brought it to the Chapter, it immediately found the network and worked, to be precise. I connected the Epson scanner and the Apple scanning software recognized it immediately, even after several failed attempts at installing drivers for Photoshop 5, running in OS9. Why can’t more people be about Mac? I’m guessing it’s the human desire for abuse. I remember reading about that when “Weakest Link” debuted in America. There was something about the leather-clad British dominatrix that viewers loved. My Dell is a black plastic piece of junk trying to dominate me, but alas, I have a sleek Titanium friend at my side. Troubleshooting my laptop doesn’t require a hammer or a wrecking ball to satisfy me. So I’m joining forces with the only other Mac user at the Chapter, our Communications Director, to beef up Mac support here. She’s been left with an original G3 tower to run the department. I say department, but it’s really her and I that do all the communications work. If she can get the Chapter to buy her a last generation G4, it would also mean her getting Office and Photoshop 7 for OSX. I could put them on my laptop and suddenly dropping this Imprecise Non-WorkStation Dell from the 24th Floor wouldn’t prevent me from staring idly at the dead thing, which prevents me from working.

More Desperate Than Madonna This past week, the Bush Administration went on a very desperate PR campaign to beef up opinion of the war in Iraq and the aftermath. It goes far behind lesbian kisses at the MTV Music Video Awards. The Bush push seemed like such a ploy, but unfortunately other people saw it differently; Bush’s approval ratings went up last week. Why it’s not so obvious to others that the PR campaign is a front for an administration on the run, I’ll never know. But I’m not here to berate my silly American peers today. I’m trying to get a little bit of information out that didn’t catch on in the major media. CNN and The New York Times failed to pick it up. The story concerns urlLink a botched letter writing campaign , which The Olympian [Wash.] uncovered. The newspaper received identical letters from 2 hometown soldiers serving in Iraq. The letters touted progress and much the soldiers enjoyed lifting up the Iraqis. Gannett News Service eventually uncovered 7 such letters, some which the soldiers, whose signatures appear on the letter, don’t recall signing or even knowing about. None of the letters were written by the soldiers who signed them. It’s unclear if any of the soldiers took part in any of the events described or visited any of the places mentioned. Of course, when asked, all agreed with what was written, but not all were comfortable with the tactic. urlLink Yahoo has a similar story, which notes USA Today did report the news. Of course the Department of Defense has no idea what the letters are about. Right. If my memory and Hollywood serves me well, letters from soldiers don’t get delivered until after being approved by the military. I don’t have a problem with that type of censorship, but this fact hurts the DoD stance. So I guess in some way this is the Vietnam War of my generation. No disrespect to those who took part in the events of that era; Americans today never stood against the war like those who protested Vietnam, but it’s the most similar thing I can come up with now.

Degrees to the Famous Today I helped out with the regional architecture conference hosted by AIA Philadelphia. I’ve been with the AIA for nearly 3 years. In that time I’ve met a few random famous people: members of Incubus, Judith Light, lil’ Bow Wow and Andre Braugher. I’ve seen Nappy Roots and a few others who I’ve pretty much forgotten about. Bjork has been through our Holiday Shop and I’ve met and talked with Kevin Bacon’s dad, Edmund Bacon, several times; he was city planner of Philadelphia for awhile and has a book published, which we sell, and he comes by to sign it on occasion. But today my link to a famous person is very much like Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon (I’m 2 degrees away, for anyone reading this who plays the game). After the conference breakfast broke and classes started, local architect Gerald Cope came through. He was running late, but stopped to talk to the chapter director and the guest speaker. Cope is British, his accent lingers after all these years. He’s an architect I’ve not heard of outside of my work with the chapter. The most famous still-living Philadelphia architect is Robert Venturi. He never shows up at the bookstore - he has go-fers for that - but I’ve seen his work and my Design III class studied a house he did for his mother. My sophomore year at Textile, I saw him on a class trip to Manayunk. We were to design a cafe along Main Street, which is also where Venturi’s offices are. The class stood on one side of the street, while the professor pointed to Venturi on the other side. Also, I feel I should note, the Philadelphia AIA member firm Bohlin Cywinski Jackson designed the SoHo Apple Store. The firm also did Pixar Studio headquarters, the Steve Jobs-run animation studio. I’ve met one of the partners and another person from the firm. But I digress... Cope is an older man, one with stories. He studied architecture in London after W.W.II. While there he met Le Corbusier. He met him several times after this. Le Corbusier is a major force in architecture. He helped form the international style. More than one of his built projects shows up in architectural history books. More than one of his homes was studied in my Design III class. I’ve heard about his work, but today I got to hear a personal story about the man. So even though these past 2 days I’ve been up since 5:30 a.m. to help out with the conference, even though it was mostly boring working the registration table, I thoroughly enjoyed 15 minutes of my day today.

”Do Not Call” It Free Speech The last time I heard something as ridiculous as the telemarketers’ “free speech” stance against the national “Do Not Call” list, it was coming from the same government now trying to enforce it. I’d be more specific, but the White House says something stupid at least twice a day. But let’s say for just a second that the line does hold up. I don’t see how that suddenly means Joe Blow in Arizona can call me in Philadelphia and try and sell me cheaper phone service, when I’m already paying rock bottom prices. So a judge says that’s free speech. Well so is the 6 p.m. news. So is Playboy magazine. So is that bland Top 40 radio station that sounds like every other one in every other city. Guess what all this has in common? If I don’t want to watch the news, I turn off the TV and suddenly it’s not coming into my house. If I don’t want to read the articles in Playboy, I don’t subscribe or I cancel my subscription and it no longer comes to my house. If I don’t want to listen to bland radio, then I turn it off and it’s not in my house. Why can’t I do something about preventing telemarketers from essentially coming into my house? As with all the above mentioned examples I can stop it after it’s already come into my house, but I can also preventing from getting to me. I don’t want MCI hassling me to switch phone companies when I’m already a loss to that viled Verizon. I don’t want a new credit card. I’ve spent the last 3 years paying off my canceled credit card debt and I’ve finally done that. Why throw myself back into near bankruptcy? I don’t have a house, so don’t call asking if I want to take out a mortgage. Do your damn homework, you stupid telemarketer. I don’t want scammed over the phone, so con artists, don’t call my number. Guess what telemarketers, Regina Unger doesn’t live here. This has been my number for 2 years, stop calling for her. The only voices I want coming through my phone are those of friends and family, or of some business with my permission to call me, such as my current creditors, or a pollster. The free speech claim telemarketers are making undermines free speech, much like the Bush administration is undermining democracy. Finally the government is doing something for the individual citizen - and not business - and what does the judicial branch do? Stick up for business. I wonder how many people have read about the ironic twist to this story. The Denver judge who ruled against the “Do Not Call” registry submitted his name and phone number to the list. As of now, the number of people who submitted their telephone number to the national register rival the number of votes for either George W. Bush or Al Gore in the 2000 election. Nearly 51 million people were wrong when they voted for Bush, but the list has nearly 51 million Americans (and is growing), it has the backing of both houses and both parties in Congress and the “do not call” list already exists in states from sea to shining sea. Something must be a little bit right about it, don’t you think?

The Best Party No One Attended So Clean imploded. It sucked up a lot of preparation, hopes, plans, money and people. Damon promoted endlessly for 2 weeks; I had it listed in the weekly calendars in the City Paper and, yes God forgive me, the Philadelphia Weekly . By 6:30 p.m., only 7 people had showed, and 2 got in for free. The day didn’t start off well; at noon the bar owner was to have opened up for us to get the place ready. He showed up half an hour before the party was to start, and how the place was trashed! (You know I mean it when I use an exclamation mark, the most viled - by the news industry - punctuation mark.) But the people who did showed up stayed until we shut down at 7 p.m. We kept their attention, so that says something. Philly is a difficult town like that. So a better GRE score could lead to me having to choose a school, rather than being forced into one I don’t want. ** Anyway, Armeggedon continues** Anyway, Armageddon continues outside my cozy 10th floor apartment. Thankful for Something I think this year was probably the best Thanksgiving I've had in awhile. Generally I go to my grandparents, my mom comes down, Veronica and I are bored out of our minds, and the stepfather is on some pointless rampage. But oddly enough, none of that surfaced. What did come about was the largest gathering of the Weirs in 3 years, and not a single argument. We went to Good & Plenty, an Amish-style eatery, all 17 or 18 of us. Bad Taste Bartender: What’ll it be? "Beer" Drinker: How about a low-carb, low calorie Miller? Bartender: Oh, piss. Bottle or tap? ** It wasn't enough that I was forced to sit through Miller Lite ads while watching my favorite shows. It wasn't enough that Coors Lite tried to make me believe that banging parties with hot chicks happen when I drink it. I guess the advertisers might have almost had me, had every frat party I ever attended (3) not been lame and serving it. Before getting too much further into this I must say I'm an alcohol snob. Parties in Apt. 109E always featured Nattie Ice or The Beast for guests, while the roommates and an elite few enjoyed White Russians or Yuengling. Yuengling is a regional beer from eastern Pennsylvania. It, Guinness, Corona and Amstel Light (those ads are cool) make my cut of excellent beers. I usually take to the local beers when I’m traveling, but these 4 will always be the returning champions. What is it about these beers? They deliver every time. And they’re respectable beers to drink in public, in front of the ladies. Just like women supposedly don’t respect a man who eats salads, there's nothing attractive in ordering low-carb Michelob or a low-cal whatever just came out. And it’s not just about respect. If you’re going to drink and if you’re going to enjoy your beer, then it’s OK to put your diet on hold. Or order some water. But don't make the watered-down beer more popular than the real stuff. American beer is already watered down to meet stringent alcohol content rules here in this free country. Let's halt this consumer-driven encroachment on beer drinkers' one passion. Why someone who is trying to be healthy would even go to a bar is beyond me. There’s the beer-gut inducing drinks to be ordered, the secondhand smoke to be inhaled; the sprained ankle from that drunken fall... I’ll refrain from getting more graphic. Let’s break this down. Go out once or twice a week, have a few real beers, do your healthy thing - if you must - the rest of the week and there’s nothing to worry about. ** Beer drinker: Bartender, another Yuengling, and pass the pretzel and the astray. [Women enters from the side] Women: [To the bartender]: I’ll have the same. [To beer drinker]: Hi, my name is ... [Scene fades]

Marketing Promotions Gone Awry I am rather alive, and rather busy. I’ve recently lost my personal space. This sounds much worse than the situation really is. My most personal relationship jumped ahead several steps over the past month, and we’ve decided living together is best for us. It also helps because we are moving together when I leave for graduate school, and we might as well work out the kinks before the situation gets dire. So far so good. My apartment was rather sparse, even after 2.5 years, but no more. It feels like home, but that doesn’t mean I like living here. It’s become impossible for me to keep my cool, so I’ve turned to reporting the building to Licenses & Inspections here in Philadelphia. I’ve taken to writing letters to the building management, seeing as how it takes DAYS to get response, if I get one. Soon I may get my councilman involved. But, enough about me, let’s get on with the show... I am black. So says AOL. The only thing going in AOL's favor is it’s not MSN, otherwise, I'd be much meaner. AOL’s latest niche/blanket promotion is called “Black Focus.” I live in North Philadelphia, a predominantly black section of Philadelphia, so I received this promotion. The packaging is in deep earthy tones. This version of AOL gives me exclusive access to “new music releases from artists like 50 Cent, Missy Elliot and R. Kelly. It also provides “the latest take on news and events that impact” my community. I so very much dislike the term “community.” Blacks have community. Gays have communities. Whites don’t have communities. Is everyone else supposed to predictable and alike? More importantly, if community, in the true sense of the word existed, would black on black crime exist as much as it does? Would the rate of HIV transmissions still have gone up as drastically as it did if gays treated each other as a community? Community, I bet. But I digress. Aside from that, I don’t know why the company is still so strongly pushing for AOL dial-up, when the future is in DSL. The company continues to lose dial-up subscribers. And let me be stereotypical for a second. If they are going to blanket North Philadelphia with an ISP option, why not do something to take on al the cheaper alternatives. Free service for 45 days really isn’t anything if the price is going to be jacked up to one of the highest prices in the industry beginning on day 46. *** I'm working on getting back to regular communications with the larger world. We'll see how well that goes.

Academic Blooper OK, maybe academic is being too kind. I am talking about Temple, the jock school of Philadelphia, quite possibly. [Note: Prospective Students: Don’t get me wrong, I got a lot out of Temple.] [Note: Alumni, current students, dropouts: Why should a blunder on Temple’s part even phase me?] I graduated in May of 2002. I somehow missed the exit interview. I continued to miss it for a year and a half, until upon needing transcripts for grad school, Temple informed me of this. What this did was put a hold on my account, which prevented me from getting transcripts, my grades and, apparently, call backs from University staff regarding this issue. So today I went to visit my alma mater - still just 4 or 5 blocks from my apartment - to clear it all up, only to stumble on another problem. I couldn’t even start the exit interview because my login contained incorrect information. Not because I entered it incorrectly; I think I have my social security number and birthday memorized. It was wrong because, all through my years at Temple, the University file on me was wrong. They had my birthday as 1980, not 1979. How do you mess that up when you are entering information? Even with my sloppiest handwriting “79” does not look like “80.” So to login, I had to lie about my birthday; the office I was doing all of this from, Academic Records, couldn’t change it, that’s to be done in financial aid, or some other office that doesn’t seem like it should have that power. After nearly 1.5 hours, it was all done with. I paid the money to get copies of my transcripts; it should take 5 days, but could be as many as 10. *** So what have I been up to of late, which has prevented me from posting regularly? We’ve written a business plan for urlLink Clean Recordings , I’m working on his bio, and I’ve put up a rather shabby Web site for the record label. In the works is a press packet to drum up some noise for a forthcoming CD, simply awaiting capital investment, and more gigs on the East Coast. Not to mention it’s now Christmastime at the urlLink AIA Bookstore & Design Center . This week all 7 of our windows will change/are changing to ornaments, gifts and whatever else we need to sell but haven’t so we’re throwing into the window with high hopes of clearing the inventory. We’re short 2 people this year, as the slow economy didn’t hit our independent, niche bookstore until after last holiday, so now we’re paying for a bad year. Already I’ve gone out for drinks with the buyer and manager, and the windows haven’t been completed. Oh, what a year this will end up being.

Shock & Awe I'm in agreement with the Vatican. I honestly can't think of a time this last happened. Yeah, I was about the Pope standing against war, but that was a given. But I digress. This post will most certainly induce self-retaliation, so I should just keep focused. This post also has the high honor of being the first I've made with a urlLink BBC story . I'm not sure how long the story will stay online, but above is a link to check it out for as long as you can. The Vatican has taken a stance against pharmaceuticals that manufacture anti-AIDS (Aids according to the BBC) drugs for putting money before goodwill. Amen! OK, enough of that. Yeah for the PR! But what about all the others with AIDS in this world, the ones who are too poor to buy the drugs as well. Is it OK for pharmaceuticals to charge such high prices when the disease ravages the poor? Personally I have problems with the pharmaceutical industry for essentially being an industry for those who can afford it. I can't go into it all, but the way the brand names stall their drugs from generic issue is problematic. And yes, studying and creating these drugs is expensive, but the federal government provides money and incentives to cut those costs, at least in the area of AIDS. But this is about the Vatican and their conflicting policies. The Vatican does not support birth control and that means condoms. Condoms prevents the spread of HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Does this seem just a little hypocritical? Certainly the Catholic Church doesn't have the sway it once did, but it's archaic and harmful policy can be found in the policy of our Methodist "President" George W. Bush. Please, does any of this make sense to any real people? If more people were using condoms, had access to condoms, there wouldn't be orphaned children from HIV. There might not even be children, which honestly can't be that bad, seeing as how famine is regularly ravaging Africa where AIDS is a serious pandemic on a scale not seen elsewhere in the world. And here is a summarized quote from a Jesuit priest in agreement with the Pope: It was a moral issue which showed lack of social conscience on the part of the international drug manufacturing companies, he [Father Angelo D'Agostino] added. Doesn't the stance of the Vatican show a lack of social conscience? I think so.

The Spin Machine in D.C. Just last week I was talking to my friend Jigsha online. We've been talking fairly regularly, but on this day, there was news to discuss. George Bush had been in her state and the newspaper had her put in some extra hours to get all the coverage up on their Web site. After his time in Tennessee Bush took off for more fundraising in Florida. The story I'd like to quote from deals with the Florida leg of his trip. When Jigsha sent me the link to the story, I didn't have to read long before a very suspect line got my attention. It couldn't have gotten my attention anymore if it were bold and danced around the screen thanks to Javascript. The following quote is from a Jan. 8, 2004 article in the TCPalm.com News: "We carried it once and we're going to carry it again," Bush said at a fund-raiser that brought in $1 million for his re-election. Carried Florida? Doesn't this seems like artistic license to the extreme? He only "carried" Florida 36 days after the polls closed an in one of the closest, if not the closest, elections in the history of the United States. And, only after the Supreme Court weighed in on the matter. This is the sort of artistic license that got the United States into a nearly unilateral war in Iraq. This sort of artistic license forced a vote of confidence onto Tony Blair, prime minister of our most vocal ally, England. Bush could certainly use some help with his word choice. Hell, he could use some help getting his facts straight. One can only hope this type of swagger will be his undoing. *** So yes, I'm writing regularly now. For Pete's Sake It's not very often I take on the subject of baseball, or any sport for that matter. Should I have to make the post, then baseball it would be. Of course, this just has all sorts of relevance for me. My family has always been Phillies fans. It's the baseball team closest to where the family grew up. The subject of this post played for the Phillies... Is there now any doubt in your mind as to whom I'm writing about? Yes, Pete Rose. Pete Rose is trying to get into the Hall of the Fame. He's not just a man with ego, he holds records and for one of those records he had to out-hit someone already in the Hall of Fame. There's one small snag, Rose bet on baseball, which led to his ouster from the sport. If he's reinstated, he's got a shot at his Hall of Fame dreams. A shot, and that's about it. He'll have to pass dreaded Rule 5, which tests integrity; not something ranking high for Rose, as he's lied about betting since his ouster. Of course, he could just be throwing in the towel to be given a shot, but that's not much for integrity either. But, as I've learned through my limited research for this post, the Baseball Hall of Fame has urlLink some hitters who strike out in that area . Now I don't want to just have certain rules thrown out. They stand for a reason. Something needs to hold back the floodgate of unscrupulous characters, but we're talking record setters here. We're not just talking about good players. We're talking about players who helped make the sport America's past time. Those people need to be recognized. In an era of charging for signatures and over-priced food and players, we need to recognize what baseball was. More importantly, Rose had a passion for baseball. All these years banned from the sport is pretty disheartening for someone like that. Rose has been punished, let's not punish the sport or the fans. Some people don't want Rose in the sport anymore, as a coach or anything. Honestly, I'm not sure what team is going to hire him as head coach. If no team picks him up, then lots of people get their way. Pete gets into the Hall of Fame, but his past transgressions will always follow him, holding him back. Sounds fair enough, as far as being a criminal goes.

Truth. Fair Drug Law. Parents. The Anti-Drug. Have you seen these commercials? I can handle some of them: The Interrogator & the Punisher aren?t so horrible. It?d be nice if these ads focused on more problematic drugs, but you?ve got to start somewhere, and while I use marijuana, I don?t push for it?s use. But there are two ads that really irk me. The first ad features a little girl playing precariously by the pool. The voice of God takes the story further: some pothead teen is supposed to be watching her, but the pothead isn?t because the pothead is smoking, so the girl falls in the pool and drowns. Uh huh. Let?s take things to the extreme. Could someone please provide me with the statistics on child - pool deaths related to pothead baby-sitters? More importantly, why have the parents allowed their pothead teen to baby-sit? If this teen is so high as to not be able to watch the younger sibling, how do the parents not know? We?re not talking about a recreational user here, we?re talking about a hardcore user. And if we?re to believe all the studies, this teen is using a lot more than pot. Maybe we should take this commercial and focus on bad parents. The second ad features a high school basketball team practicing in the gym. The coach enters to dismiss a player. The voice of God takes the story further: this pothead player, apparently the star player, has been kicked off the team for being a pothead. What are the consequences? The team won?t make it to the playoffs. Uh huh. Let?s take things to an impossible extreme. The reason the team isn?t going to the playoff isn?t because of the pot, per se. In fact, this pothead player has taken the team to the brink. It doesn?t seem to be hurting his abilities - so much for that dope image. It?s the outdated drug laws that have ended this star player?s career and the team?s chances at the playoffs. Maybe we should take this commercial and focus on bad laws. More importantly, it should be noted that this ad campaign was started in 1998 and is part of the White House Office of Nation Drug Control Policy. Quick note: Bill Clinton was president in 1998 and, even though he denied how far he went with the drug, we can infer that he smoked pot. It?s now 2004 and our latest president is an admitted crackhead and drunk. Doesn?t this all just smack of something hypocritical? I?m hardly expecting progressive drug laws out of the current administration. Christ, the Bush Administration was waving its pointer finger at Canada for freeing up prison space by making marijuana possession a ?do not go directly to jail? offense. I also don?t expect it, because ads like this give the wrong impression. If voters are to believe these ads present common instances of drug use gone wrong, how will fairer laws ever come to pass? Would I fight this if it had been a heroin addict who let the younger sibling drown in the pool? No. Would I have complained if the basketball player was kicked off the team for steroid use? No. But as an organization created by Congress and associated with the White House, how about a little more fairness. I mean, this isn?t war with Iraq.

I Support 3rd Parties, Just Not This Year I'm a 3rd party fanatic. Any political debate I get into, I bring it all back to the lack of a poly-party government. Israel, Germany, England, etc. etc., all have several political parties that require alliances be formed to fulfill the tasks at hand. But not in the United States. No, here you have a party, which can easily take majority of either House of Congress and force their will, with little that can be done by the only other party. *** Side note: And when we get around to codifying all of this, could we please include an amendment banning LaRouche from politics. His party, his workers, he himself aren't left or right, they're somewhere over the rainbow with those posters and slogans and beliefs. I really don't like dismissing people, but there are always exceptions to the rule. *** So it's my belief that true campaign reform won't happen until our government creates a level playing field for Republicans, Democrats, Greens, etc. etc. Unfortunately, all of my 3rd party banter can't convince me to vote 3rd party this election year. I would have voted for Ralph Nader in 2000, had I been registered. But I wasn't. I'm not pissed off at Nader over the 2000 election outcome. I think Gore was an OK candidate, but I think Sen. Joe Lieberman hurt him. I was so glad when Lieberman dropped out of the presidential race this year. He's so centrist, he's on the right. But I am so pissed at President George W. Bush that I feel only a single viable alternative to him should be on the ballot to ensure his demise. I've probably said this once already, but I'll say it again. If Bush is to win and rule for another 4 years, it is my very strong belief that nothing short of a revolution can get this country back on track. And not my track, but the track laid down by the Founding Fathers. After the Democratic candidate takes the White House, after some fixes are made, then I can get my principles back. But to allow Bush in the White House again would go against my principles even more than putting them on hold. Plus, honestly, Sens. John Kerry and John Edwards are shaping up to be pretty decent contenders.

That actually reminds me of a skit from Kentucky Fried Movie . If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend it to those who are against PC in the name of humor. Bush and the pervasive climate within the media industry that hires people through contacts rather than what they can do. But I'm not bitter. Oh, let me backtrack; here is a comment on George W. The Non-Apology Apology Sounds very Seinfeldian, doesn't it? I'm going to pick on the man-of-the-moment who is guilty of this, though it can be applied to most anybody. I'm talking about the University of Colorado football coach who is now on paid leave for comments he made about a former female kicker who is accusing at least one male player on the team of rape and assault. After Katie Hnida made the allegations in Sports Illustrated , her former coach at UC, Gary Barnett, in a statement to the press, said as a kicker, Hnida sucked. His exact words: she was an "awful player." Uh, huh. Why was she a kicker on his team then? More importantly, if she sucked so bad, how did she transfer to the University of New Mexico, where she played in a Division I football game? And I haven't even gotten to the juicy part yet. Following his remarks, the University decided to put Barnett on leave, prompting him to make another stupid statement: "I sincerely regret that yesterday, a portion of my remarks were either misinterpreted or taken, aired out of context." I watched the news conference and I have no idea how any statement he made could have been taken out of context. He spent that conference grabbing at straws and not even addressing the issue at hand. Who wrote this man's prepared speech? He was absolutely not apologetic, in fact, he came across as a pompous asshole. I sometimes wish I had gone into PR or advertising, because there is so much mess out there that needs cleaned up. Not that I'd want to help Barnett, but either he needs a PR person, or he needs a new one. Barnett's performance should garner him much more than paid leave; the University should fully distance itself from that man by letting him go. Actually, if the man had any honor at all, and his non-apology apology shows he is lacking in that considerably, he should leave by his own volition. As for the validity of Hnida's allegations, which Barnett seems keen to brush aside, I'd say they seem very valid, seeing as how she left CU, apparently not over grades, because she easily moved on to another school, another team.

Pick a Candidate, Any Candidate Let me just start off by saying that I have always been a big fan of presidential candidates Sens. John Kerry and John Edwards since the race started. I always thought Gov. Howard Dean was a little too, eh, what's the word? Strange? Too far left of center, I'd say. One thing missing from the current primary election focus is debate on the issues. There certainly are issues, at urlLink John Kerry's Web site you can read his stance on nearly 30 issues. But they're not really be debated out in the open. What is being discussed is Kerry's "electability." How has U.S. government and politics fallen so far? It's an election year and the issues seem to be an aside to getting President Bush out of office. I want Bush out of office as much as or more than the next person, but if you have someone with a strong stance on issues, that should be enough to unseat the bumbling puppet who sits in the Oval Office. Honestly, if there are so many people who are against Bush, who want him out of office, then how did the man ever get into office? Could it be a lot of people were slacking the last time around? I don't know honestly, but I like to be accusatory. Maybe the only positive thing to come out of the Bush Administration is a renewed interest in politics by the younger generation. And this younger generation, is by virtue more progressive. Maybe, just maybe, because we had to fall back 8 years with this Administration, our next one will be several years advanced, as will the next and the next... It's about the only thing that keeps me so controlled during these years of no tax relief (for me and the rest of the lower middle class and further down the scale), Constitutional infringements, and special interest give-aways. Unfortunately, if people are basing their votes only on "electability," this means a lot of people might be biting the bullet on issues they don't agree with. Oh, how I long for a United States with a more-party system, with at least 3 parties, with choices! I'm such a romantic about this type of thing. But I digress... I'm simply asking you, America, to take more into consideration this election year. In the 2000 election no one could separate Bush from Al Gore on most of the issues, and it cost the United States dearly.

Strong, Not Wrong, Marriage I've made my stance on gay marriage very clear back in urlLink July. I'm not about to amend it, much to Damon's chagrin, but recent comments by the self-righteous Right is really starting to irk me. First, in a CNN story covering Ohio's gay marriage ban, that state's Republican governor had to this to say about marriage: "Marriage is an essential building block of our society, an institution we must reaffirm." If it's an essential building block of our society, why deny it to a segment of the population? Second, in another CNN story covering a gay marriage protest in Massachusetts, the Boston Archbishop Sean P. O'Malley said: "Good strong marriage and family are good for our country, for society." Who is to say that homosexual love is any less binding, any less strong? Marriage is on the decline in the heterosexual world; maybe the Archbishop should take on that. I honestly feel the gay marriage issue is simply being slowed by the less progressive aspects of U.S. society. I would love to see any state, hell, even the United States, put forth an amendment banning gay marriage. In no time there would be lawsuits, and I do not believe any of the amendments would hold up in the court of law because of the inequality inherent in them. *** Oh, and just to mention: Andy Rooney, who must be older than both my grandparents, found Janet Jackson's stunt at the Super Bowl to be far less offensive than Nelly or Kid Rock. And Prince was such a weak opening for the Grammy's. Honestly, when did he last have a new album to garner any attention? Why did he only sing songs from the '80s? Janet would have done much better.
