Taxing Times Today started off with no sleep and dreams of a tax refund directly deposited into my checking account in 12 days. It's now nearly 4 p.m., still not much sleep, and certainly no dreams of tax refunds. Why? Because the government still wants a $331 tax payment from me after the $1,900 already deducted from my paychecks. Boo-hoo you might say, but I only made $19,000 after taxes and adjustments. After years of paying down my debts, I'm falling behind again and living paycheck to paycheck. This is going to make my move for graduate school SOO easy. This will be the first year I've had to pay taxes. I knew that paying Uncle Sam would happen eventually; I just hadn't expected it in one of my worst financial years. I also wouldn't expect to do that in the first tax year following Bush's 2nd tax cut. OK, that last part was sarcastic. I need to somehow adopt a child and make it legitimate back to last year. (Note to IRS employees: that's sarcastic as well). What the Bush Administration has managed to do with the support of the people of the United States of America is simply astonishing. Yes, a tax cut that failed to lower the tax rate of the poorest, while the richest are reaping thousands of dollars in savings initiated by the Bush Administration, passed in Congress and signed by the Bush Administration. Bush would now like to have the tax cuts made permanent, and probably a few new things to boot, all while pouring more money in Iraq, the military and a now ballooning non-fix fix to the senior prescription drug program. I am beginning to feel the same as the Quaker woman in New Jersey who refused to pay taxes because the money was being spent on programs and policies that conflicted with her religion. While my religious beliefs are jumbled, my political beliefs are certainly not. Seeing as how I've not supported the war in Iraq, the Department of Homeland Security, tax breaks for energy companies, the new prescription drug plan, etc. etc., it makes it much harder to pay this sum with no benefit to myself. Yes, it sounds a little egotistical, but I'm not alone here. My mom will have made less money that I did last year, and she will have to pay taxes as well. All while the house is 3 months behind on rent, etc. etc. etc. I'll refrain from beating this point home with countless actual examples. Hello IRS, close up those loopholes and let's get some tax relief rather than tax breaks. Let's not put the burden of running the United States on the people who are barely surviving.

Fueling Controversy Let me finish my rant on Condi Rice. Not sure if it's even relevant now, seeing as how she will testify publicly now, but... One of my other problems with the Bush Administration classifying EVERYTHING, and Rice not testifying also because of the possibility that classified material could be brought out into the public, is that the events of Sept. 11, 2001 are going to be 3 years old. To me, that means a lot can be said without blowing national security or jeopardizing the current war on terror. I had the above thought yesterday, but Damon was working on music. And when music is being made in this apartment, my mind becomes discombobulated. I require silence. It's partly to blame for my irregular posting. But now a more current topic. So the Bush Administration and the Kerry campaign want to make rising gas prices a political issue. Could this be anything less political? Part of the reason gas prices have gone up is the new, more environmentally friendly additive being added. There's also demand. Demand-supply is not political. There's also the open market style of buying oil. It's economics. As an environmentalist and public transit user with an interest in urban studies and planning, I am very happy gas prices are going up in today's dollars. It's still dirt cheap compared to gas prices in the United States during the early '80s, when adjusted for inflation. But our gas prices are about the cheapest in the world. I think higher gas prices are what we need to start breaking this wasteful mentality in the United States. Maybe people will think twice before buying a Hummer or any SUV. Maybe hybrid vehicle sales will skyrocket. Maybe public transit ridership will rise. Oh the positive possibilities. Unfortunately another maybe could be greater acceptance to drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. People don't understand that opening that up to drilling isn't going to cut prices now. It probably wouldn't bring much relief at all, and if it does, we're not talking about next week or this summer. The extent to which this is political is the energy policy the U.S. Government is putting together. Fortunately key parts, such as drilling in ANWR, have failed every time. I've said it once, and I'll say it again. What we need is energy conservation. It serves 2 purposes. First, it breaks the so-called hold people say OPEC and the Middle East have over the United States, and second, it's good for the environment. Oh, and it keeps the wallet a little more full for longer.

Where's the Rice? So Condeleeza Rice loves to testify, just not in a public forum. She's already given some 4 hours of testimony to the 9/11 Commission. But the public wants to hear what she has to say. The Commission wants the public to hear what she has to say. But no. Her reason? The "long-standing principle that sitting National Security Advisers do not testify before the Congress." It sounds legit, at first. But give it a second thought. No sitting national security adviser has ever testified before Congress. Also, never in the history of the United States have we had a day like Sept. 11, 2001. I think what happened that day justifies an exception to the long-standing rule she hides behind. This administration has been claiming since Day One that they have nothing to hide, yet they've been rather "seal-happy." There's the energy task force for starters. Then the Patriot Act, which keeps more government actions away from public scrutiny. Etc., etc. Rice says she has nothing to hide, butthe pattern has already taken shape.

Unions Against Philadelphia As a liberal-minded, independent, stand-up-against-big-business kind of guy, you'd think I'm pro-union. Somehow I'm not on at least my 2nd anti-union post. Maybe "anti-union" isn't the correct word for it. I just think that sometimes they're very short-sighted and hurt both the business and the benefactors of their work. The most recent example involves MTV's The Real World of all things. I'm not a fan of the show - Road Rules was always superior - but it coming to tape in Philadelphia meant a lot for Philadelphia, in terms of publicity and so much more. Oh, and my friend, who works in the business across the street from where the house was to be, was going to give me free coffee while sitting and complaining about the pretentious cast. So what if the show wasn't hiring Philadelphia union members to do the construction work. The residual effects the show was capable of bringing to the area would mean far more work. And it's more than that. If the unions gave a damn about the city, they would understand what bringing the show to Philadelphia says about the city. It says there's something here to be shown. There's some excitement here. A show like this introduces to a captive audience, life in Philadelphia that you don't see on any other channel. That captive audience also happens to be the age group that Philadelphia needs to sustain itself as a viable and exciting city. But don't tell that to the unions. It's not like they really have a reason to complain so much. How am I going to get my found on TV if Mayor John Street can't salvage the Philly show?

A Deadly Sin in the White House To start things off, I'd like to thanks to everyone who responded to my last post, who shared my last post, who didn't want to read my last post, etc. etc. Again, thank you! ** Texas Governor George W. Bush was elected president of the United States in 2000 or 2001, your pick. He secured urlLink 48% of the popular vote . Vice President Al Gore lost the election with 48% of the popular vote. The difference between the two candidates in the popular vote was 540,000 voters, with Gore the winner. It was the electoral college and U.S. Supreme Court that put Bush into office. It's now time for election 2004. These past 4 years have offered much opportunity for Bush to secure a better shot in this election. He's blown most every chance given him. He took us to the war with Iraq, essentially alone, amid worldwide protest and, as is now clearly obvious even to his supporters, for a trumped up reason. Each of his tax cuts focused solely on businesses and the wealthiest citizens. His environmental policies fly in the face of solid science and worldwide policy. States, counties, cities and towns, urlLink more than 150 so far , have passed resolutions against the Bush Administration's Patriot Act. The Bill of Rights Defense Committee puts the number at urlLink 3 states and 258 cities, towns and counties , but I thought I'd first offer a less biased news article before I back my standing with an activist group. All this, and obviously more, yet the White House refuses to back down on its policies. For a "compassionate conservative" who barely won the election, he's far more divisive than seems prudent. And I'm not simply talking about pissing off the Democrats and others. His recent announcement of legislation to give illegal immigrants temporary citizenship is pissing off Republican Senators and Representatives in Congress. His support for a Constitutional amendment banning gay marriage is pissing off the so-called "Log Cabin Republicans," the gays and lesbians who supported him in his first election. It was also revealed today in The Philadelphia Inquirer that the Bush Administration withheld costs for the Medicare overhaul bill to prevent 13 Republican Senators from voting it down; some of them want to take back their votes now. (I'd post a link, but I'm having trouble finding the story on a site with free archives.) Is his political goal to win the national election by an even slimmer margin than election 2000? Shouldn't an administration that won in the closest election in U.S. history be doing more to reach out rather than close itself off to the voters? I say the Administration is a little too self-assured, too blinded by its early successes, too arrogant. Break out your thesaurus and look up arrogance. You'll find pride listed as a synonym.

Quiet Riot I had my friend Jigsha look over this, my opus on the protests against and push for gay marriage in the United States. I have heard nothing from any of the newspapers I submitted it to, so this will be my medium. I call this Quiet Riot because Jigsha's critique, aside from a few corrections, was that I was making this argument, but doing so without being harsh or offensive. I like to think this is my personality. At the end of my piece I have included the the links necessary to contact your Senators and Representatives in Congress. If you are in agreement with my stance in any way, I ask that you e-mail this peice to them or voice your own concerns. I ask that you be proactive and get this piece, or your own letter to your elected representatives at the state level, because Constitutional amendments can also be passed if enough of the state legislatures approve of it. *** All men are created equal. So says the Declaration of Independence, the document that first stated, loud and clear, the existence of the United States of America. The document that followed it, The Constitution, was flawed, and this nation has tried 27 times to improve upon it. There is now a push for a 28th Amendment to prevent gay marriages. This may be Amendment 28, but it is the first of its kind. It is the first Amendment to explicitly discriminate against a human being. In this case it discriminates against a human being who is a citizen of the United States of America; people who are eligible to vote; people who pay their taxes; people in pursuit of happiness. I believe this makes it the first amendment, which can, right now without the position of the Supreme Court, be deemed unconstitutional. It should also be noted that this Amendment destroys the "separation of Church and State" barrier so much a part of the founding documents of this country. Our Founding Fathers were all Christian, but they understood that in this country there would be non-Christians who must be treated equally. How does the amendment undo the intentions of our Founding Fathers? The makeup of the gay marriage protesters in San Francisco have been largely Christian; the protesters waving their Bibles high, condemning people to hell. Also present were Muslims. What I have not heard about are atheists or agnostics protesting. The people protesting say it is an abomination before God. I say to them: your God is not mine. I say to them, my country says you and I are equal. You have the right to marry the one you love. You have the right to file taxes as a couple; the right to adopt a child as a couple; the right to be with your lover in the hospital; the right to collect your lover's belongings upon passing. But I/we do not; not without complicated paperwork requiring a lawyer, and even that fails to guarantee me everything you have. For the first time in U.S. history, a religious doctrine - one espoused by Christianity, Islam and Judaism - will be codified in the founding document of a country that offered a life away from religious persecution. But this is what the amendment will do: persecute me and others for our beliefs. Christians are doing it, Muslims are doing it, the president of the United States is doing it and so are the elected representatives. For those against gay marriage, but not so extreme as the religious fanatics condemning me, us, to hell, is the argument that gay marriage will dilute and destroy the very foundation of marriage. I say you are crazy. Follow the coverage of the gay marriages in San Francisco. What have I read, heard and saw? I read about couples, who have been together for years. For five, 10, 15, 25 years or more. How is such a bond going to destroy marriage? This bond, this relationship, this love should be seen as only validating marriage even more. I haven't seen, heard or read about 22-year-old gay men getting married in San Francisco. But I have seen, heard and read about Britney Spears getting married in Las Vegas, a marriage that lasted just two days. If anything is being held up as destroying the idea of marriage, it should be this type, which unfortunately is all too common. That and marriage because the couple is pregnant, marriage for green cards, marriage forcibly arranged by parents. Because the idea of marriage - straight marriage - is held so dearly by the major Western religions, I say that it is unconstitutional for an amendment to the Constitution to codify what religion can and cannot do. Let the Church, the mosque, the synagogue decide who they can and will marry. This is why, for all intents and purposes of law, marriage should be stricken from government. Let marriage be the term for unions consecrated by a religious leader. Let those who take part in it use the term among friends and family, on wedding invitations, etc. etc. Let civil union, or some other word, be the term used by government, in the court room, on paperwork, etc. etc. Let the religious, persecuting extremists have their word. Because that's all it is. At the end of the day I just want to be held up as equal before the law, with rights equal to my peers. At the end of the day, I say let the religions have their protests and their beliefs, because even though I am not in agreement, this is a free country, and if they can protest, I want to give them something to protest. I do not want to take away or hinder their right. In closing, President George W. Bush said this of the gay marriage issue: "After more than two centuries of American jurisprudence and millennia of human experience, a few judges and local authorities are presuming to change the most fundamental institution of civilization." If it were not for the few "activist judges" where would the antislavery, women’s suffrage or civil rights movements be? Brian Swope http://swopey.blogspot.com *** Contact your urlLink U.S. Senator . Contact your urlLink U.S. Representative . The following link will take you to the beginning of this post regardless of what I post after this or where it is archived. urlLink Quiet Riot

Dell Computers, It'll Put You in a Pickle This is probably the fastest turn around I've had for posting something on my blog. It's 7:30 a.m. and I have no idea why I'm up, but I've already had breakfast and I'm watching CNN. Because Damon is working on his music, the TV is on mute, which means closed captioning is on. I wonder who does the closed captioning for CNN, because it's never right. Today was no exception. In some discussion about Gateway cutting jobs (now that's what I call job growth, Mr. Bush), the American Morning staff started talking about Dell Computers and the competitiveness in the tech sector. The closed captioning typist, either by mistake, or the person shares my feelings about Dell, transcribed it as Dill. Something like this could never get by me, as anyone who's read my blog knows. It's not even that I'm a Mac head, but the Dill Computer at my AIA Philadelphia desk should be hurled from the top of the water tower on the roof of the 24-story office building I work in. But only if the eternally broken elevators (they've been modernizing them for at least 2 years) could get me and the Dill to the 24th floor. I bet when the Dill hit the ground, it'd make that crunch sound trademark of Vlassic. I always laugh openly when Dill claim to get an "A" for customer support. AIA Philadelphia purchased "fast pass"-like response for tech support on our Dill, and I still spent 1.5 hours on hold when the black box from hell refused to load Windows. I thought it had something to do with the Dill, only 2 years old, sounding like a space shuttle launching when I start it up. I finally gave up, then played e-mail tag for a week. It still sounds like Discovery at lift-off, but it loads "secure" Windows when I need to download a new security hole patch each week. So remember, when you buy a Dell, that lemon will surely put you in a pickle when you don't want it.

Primary. What Primary? Today was the first time since I registered 2 year ago that I did not vote. I honestly heard little about it, until this morning. A quick glance at what this primary was about and I decided against voting at all. There wasn't much of a contest on the Democratic side. The big race here is for a Republican Senator. If only I could be Republican for a day! It was incumbent Arlen Specter, a moderate with support from Bush, vs. Pat Toomey, a super conservative with support from no one who means anything to me. Not that Bush does either, but the last thing this state needs is 2 super conservative senators. Who's the other? In case you didn't know, it's Rick Santorum. While I was a work today, the voting issue came up. I hadn't said but a few words to my boss before this lady starts nodding her head in agreement and joins the conversation. She wanted to be a Republican for a day, too, just to vote down Pat Toomey. First vote down Toomey, then Bush, she said. As I'm typing this the votes are beginning and with just 3 of 9,416 precincts reporting, Specter has the early lead with 10 percentage points. I bigger margin would have been nice for the start, but we'll see where this goes. The lady who jumped into conversation at work has taken up a dirty cause. She feared for my generation's job outlook. Had this not been an election year, the whole outsourcing issue probably would have never gotten further that Lou Dobbs on CNN. Hell, he might not have been able to make a case of it. While it adversely affects me, I expect such. Plus, it's not like outsourcing is something new. The American economy has done a spectacular job of creating new jobs and new types of jobs. Taking a protectionist stance does nothing for us as a nation. Plus, it was the protectionist stance that worsened the Great Depression. The lady also was "woe is me" over my inactive generation. I think that my generation is improving. Not long ago, B.B. (before Bush), I didn't care who was what on which issue. That has certainly changed in the A.B. years, and I think that for as much as I dislike Bush, his positions, his use of the English language and his attitude, he certainly has done a great job of rallying his voter base (i.e. the crazy Christian conservatives), the opposition (i.e. the crazy, "all other religious options" liberals), including the others (i.e. sane, rational moderates). As I'm wrapping this up, with 33 of 9,416 precincts reporting, the margin has widened by 2 percentage points, but the percent of reporting precincts has yet to break 1. God, let this primary be a sign that Pennsylvania (OK, just the portions west of Philadelphia) has come to its senses. It looks like I'll be here another year, and I need to have hope in my home state of 24 years.

Eskew Not Eschewing Views Askew As a member of blogger, I was invited to GMail. I've heard the concerns, and I mostly think they're bogus. I'll never need 1GB, even with all the junk mail I get. Plus, my e-mail conversations rarely amount to anything so groundbreaking or illegal. I hardly use my e-mail anyway, so this won't get much use. I had 5 or 6 e-mail addresses at one point, but now they only exist for the Web space that comes with them. My favorite feature is Quick Keys. It might not seem so amazing, but to have quick keys built into a Web-based e-mail program is the coolest thing about GMail. Oh that AT&T Worldnet offered that. *** On the copy desk, one of the most common things noted were people's names and their jobs. For example, maybe a bomb squad member's initials are TNT. Notable examples exist in politics, but I can think of none that received more coverage than former President Richard M. Nixon's aide Robert L. Ehrlichman. Why such coverage? Because Ehrlichman was involved with Watergate and in his last name is the German word for "honesty," "ehrlich." Oops. Today, I was watching Tucker Eskew get interviewed on CNN. Have you seen those word games where you have a word and with 1 letter change each step, you must transform that word into another. For example: meal seal sean seen Usually the first and last word are somehow connected. In just one move, Tucker Eskew, Deputy Assistant to the President [George W. Bush] for Communications, becomes Tucker Askew. askew adj : turned or twisted toward one side Things that make you go, hmm.

Selling Out for Cinnamon Rolls I can't remember the last time I was so worked up about an ad campaign like I am with the Holiday Inn Express Cinnamon Roll commercials. I've only seen them run during CNN's "American Morning," though because I watch that news show religiously, I couldn't say if it runs anywhere else or not. So Holiday Inn Express has launched this ad campaign focusing solely on the cinnamon rolls available at breakfast. I don't know anything about the rooms, rates, number of Inns or anything else. But I want to stay at a Holiday Inn Express for the free breakfast cinnamon roll. I was in one once for a little while, but I really can't go into that. And this was before the cinnamon roll. This is how much I love the commercials. The other day, after it seemed the ad campaign was playing less frequently, I visited the Web site in hopes of viewing them endlessly online. It wasn't to be so. In an effort to rectify the situation, I wrote an e-mail to Holiday Inn Express: I truly love your Cinnamon roll commercials. you should really put them online, as they aren't played enough on CNN American Morning to satisfy my funny bone. After all of the crappy ads out there, I look forward to cinnamon roll ads. I felt a little dorky sending it, but how could I resist. These ads made me want to stay at the Holiday Inn, regardless of any rats, high rates or inept check-in clerks. To my surprise I got a response! Thank you for taking the time to contact us. We are happy to hear your comments about the Cinnamon Roll commercials. I have forwarded your comment to our marketing department to let them know how you feel about the ads. If you need further assistance, please feel free to contact us. Best Regards, Xxxx Xxx Internet Response Team The response from the marketing department was not so stellar as the Internet Response Team: Dear Brian Swope It is always a pleasure to hear enthusiasm from our guests, and we want to thank you for your feedback on our commercials. We are very proud of the commercials, and feel that they truly represent our personality. Stay Tuned! Holiday Inn Express Marketing Yawn. To continue my surprise, the morning after all of this, I saw 2 of the ads played during the hour I was watching TV. Yes, the news can be depressing, but God, those commercials just do me right. It doesn't hurt that CNN "American Morning" has such a great crew. I am all about Soledad O'Brien. Yeah, she's hot. She's funny. And the whole crew meshes well. Plus, they're "The Most Trusted Name in News." I'm done my plug kick. CNN, you can reach me at ... I'll be staying at the Holiday Inn Express on ... Let's do the job interview after breakfast.

Me and LaRouche Don't know who LaRouche is? I don't really know him either. I do know he is endlessly running for the U.S. presidency on a platform of conspiracy theories and that he doesn't get interviewed, nor do his fanatic street team members. It used to be that the LaRouche fanatics would set up their table at a high-traffic spot on the sidewalk. Recently, they've stepped up their measures to spread the insanity. In just the past week I've had three encounters with the "LaRouchies," and each was more unpleasant than the one before.. It started off with one of the "LaRouchies" leaving behind a flyer and brochure at the AIA bookstore. If they wanted to hand it to me or an employee, that's fine. But don't leave it at the door where we keep architecture & design related postings. Don't cover up the Chapter newsletter and flyers on a book signing next month. As soon as I saw the flyers, I quit helping a customer at the register, so I could pull them from sight ASAP. Not many days after, a "LaRouchie" was passing out more brochures, but this time it was at Broad & Girard. I don't know what possessed this kid to do such. The only other people on the block are hacks, and I'm not talking about that lame Philadelphia-based TV show hacks. As I passed the "LaRouchie" to cross the street and head to work, he approached me with his brochure of theories. I, with my iPod, politely said, "No, thank you." He apparently didn't hear, because he still held out the brochure, and well above where I would reach out and grab it with my hand. No, this brochure was being held out to be somewhere around my upper chest and neck area. Later that day, during rush hour, downtown traffic came the "LaRouche-mobile." With a bumper sticker claiming him to be "The Real Democrat," the "LaRouchies" in their minivan wasted gas and clogged traffic to drive up and down the streets with speakers blaring the voice of LaRouche stating his theories. A lot of this is to be expected from candidates in an election year, but it's only April! He's campaigning in Pennsylvania, but no one can vote for him because 3rd party candidates don't get in the primaries. At least John Kerry can be voted for come whatever day the primaries are here. Isn't it a bit early for the insanity? Yes, I know the same can be said of the Democrats and Republicans, but there's a chance with those candidates. Hell, Ralph Nader has a better shot than LaRouche. Can we lessen the insanity? Please, LaRouche?

A Nice Ending to a Hell of a Week It's Saturday night and the weekend couldn't have come quick enough. But now that it's here, I'm reveling in it. Went out with the boyfriend today to take in some rays (I'm less pale now); take in the sights and smells of Philadelphia and head to University City (God, the UPenn brats) to see "Kill Bill, Vol. 2" at the Bridge. Yes, that uptight movie theater that ruined my "Matrix Reloaded" viewing. I shouldn't blame it all on the theater, the movie was lacking. But this time around, the experience was better. It helped that I had a Lee's Hoagie chicken wrap prior to entering. This week I also paid taxes. Why couldn't the certainty of death come first? This is the first year I've had to pay taxes, which is strange because apparently we've had 3 tax cuts since President George W. Bush took office. I wonder why it hasn't affected my taxes yet? Why am I complaining about paying taxes? Because I'm living paycheck to paycheck. Because I don't have health care. Because I can't find a job in my field. Because I don't want my money sending another urlLink cappuccino machine to Iraq. I also got yelled a lot this week and last week at work. I was coming in late 5, maybe 10 minutes late. The one boss was getting catty about it, and in the end I did get written up, which hasn't deterred me from changing my ways. Maybe I deserved it all, I don't know. I used to be late regularly for weeks on end. These past two weeks were anomalies, as I've not been late since early fall 2003 when my newspaper job ended. The bosses do know about my renewed job hunt and the few rewards it's starting to show, so I think that plays into their change, which is why I'm ignoring it all. I don't want to leave there on a bad note. So yes, I am going to clean up my act, but I'm expecting something in return, dammit! I'm going to stop this post now, as it's still very beautiful out, and who the hell is inside reading this anyway?

Easter Passions How did I spend my Easter? I watched part of a bootleg copy of "The Passion" and indulged in Cadbury creme eggs. I've been meaning to watch the movie, but with varying degrees of interest. I've now decided to wait until it hits video. Larger-than-life lashings really don't do it for me. I'm a hedonist to the end. I did watch enough the of the movie to question the anti-Semitism people are complaining about. If there is anything to complain about, I'd say let's attack the selectivity of the facts. Though that really doesn't stick in the face of artistic license. My understanding of the truth is that Jesus had to die to fulfill the prophecy and truly become the Messiah. I don't think Christianity would have taken off without the crucifixion, ascension and reappearing to the Disciples. So the Jews wanted Jesus put to death. Doesn't that fit perfectly with what was expected to happen? Didn't God harden the heart of Pharaoh while Moses tried to free the Jews? Didn't this put them through more suffering? Isn't is possible that God hardened the hearts of the Jews so Jesus could return to God's side? Someone, something had to be responsible for the death of Jesus. Maybe it was God's plan that was so inhumane. Maybe it was the Romans, who so obviously enjoyed whipping the flesh from Jesus' back. Maybe it was the Jews who chose Barrabas to be freed, over Jesus. It seems that if none of the aforementioned groups had performed the acts they did, Christianity wouldn't be here today. Things that make you go, hmmm.

Making the Presidential Administration Damon is watching MTV's "Making the Band," featuring one of my least favorite people in the world, Puff Daddy. Or is it P. Diddy? I prefer nobody. Never have I seen a less functional group of people, going through so much drama to still be nobodies at the end of the show. I honestly think the only reason people actually show up to the mall appearances and wherever else the "band" "performs" is because the MTV cameras are there. Oh my God and are these people ugly! Christ, the ego! But it's given me an idea. Maybe we should put the next presidential administration together in much the same way. It's not completely unheard of. When the United States first started out, it was always the loser presidential nominee who took the vice president's job. How's that for putting incompatible people together to accomplish something? Imagine Al Gore as the vice president now. You can't get drama near that on "Apprentice" or "Real World 37." Maybe we could get people excited about politics and government again. And AT&T Wireless can do text message voting. It seems nearly fraud proof and far less scandalous than the botched, GOP-headed Florida election fiasco. *** Disclaimer: This is a very jumbled post. Every time I type another sentence dealing with my political take, I have another issue with the episode, which forces me to quit my train of thought and back up 4 paragraphs to add another gripe. ***

Mac 'n' Cheese 'n' Gas ** Before going into my personal life this week, I have to comment on something I happened upon this week while promoting for a party I'm doing with Damon. Side note: urlLink Spice on Friday nights and Sugar on Saturday nights. I went to the Mean Bean to see about dropping off some flyers, and on the counter there sits a tip jar. The sign attached to it reads: Funds for Counter Inteligence [sic]. It was an attempt at humor with the FBI and CIA. I need to give the people behind the counter a tip on spelling. Also, I just read this story on CNN, which, to me, takes a slap at the recent Bush ad regarding Kerry, taxes and gas prices. urlLink Ford's CEO has said he would support a 50-cent gas tax , even during these trying times of "high" gas prices. The purpose: to push consumers to take up fuel-efficient vehicles. Now the Bush ads attack John Kerry for his proposal for a 50-cent gas tax, saying that's all wrong. Tonight is our party and tomorrow will be rearranging, and then the party again. Then Sunday. My day of rest. Then Monday, another day of rest. Then Tuesday, back to the bookstore. Postpartum Depression I move on Thursday, after 3 years at Apartment 916. No more view of West Philadelphia, the thunderstorms rolling in or every firework show 10 miles west of my place. It'll be hard, but I'm certainly about done with this place. The situation has gotten so bad at my building, the Philadelphia Regency, that they're offering $100 to any current tenant who refers someone who actually signs a lease. Verizon has yet to shut off my phone, even though the shut-off date was Monday. After canceling my cable service for June 1, I got a bill for June service. In case anyone is wondering, it's Viking Cable, and I'd certainly watch out with them. I have a feeling the company resells Direct TV, as Direct TV commercials litter every station - "for the latest in sports, check station 218"; I only get 50 channels. Also, the storm rolling in is making TNT stutter. I have nothing in boxes, nothing unplugged, nothing even sorted for trash and Salvation Army donations. This week is going to be insane because of the move, work and the party at the Mercury Lounge. But this is how I work. But enough about me. I've been rather personal on here of late, and I need to rein myself in. *** What's been happening of late outside of my life? The prisoner abuse scandal in Iraq is getting out hand. So out of hand that President George W. Bush has been forced to get his speechwriters and Cabinet together to get everyone on the same page. It was the usual "blameless, emotionless, apology-less" speech we've come to expect from our compassionate conservative president. I invite you to read a previous post on the urlLink Bush Administration's ego . "American Morning" was a riot early Tuesday. The question of the day was something along the lines of "what would you like to hear the President say during his speech tonight." The Top 2 overwhelming responses: "I resign" and "I'm not running in 2004." Oh, if only. After reading the above post, this little bit is just all the more interesting. Whether you think the speech was banter, a good start or right on target, a lot of people didn't see it because the broadcast networks didn't carry the speech. Could it be because the (right, left or unbiased) media didn't want to (hurt, help or uncover) President Bush? I don't have an answer to it; I just think it was wrong. Whether I like or dislike the president, it doesn't matter. If the president is giving a speech to the general citizenry, the broadcast networks need to be there covering it. God knows news is all over the scandal. Front-page news for the print media usually translates into coverage by every media outlet. *** I am imploring people to visit the urlLink Free Press activists' Web site . The group has started a petition, which, I'm not sure when it started, but the sign up in Pennsylvania is pretty despicable. The petition is pushing for FCC Chairman Michael Powell to attend the public hearings being held on the topic of media consolidation, something he supports. It's no surprise that he makes it to all of the broadcast media's "pat on the back" and "look at us" galas, but can't make it out to hear the public's thoughts on the FCC's positions. With the recent slip up by the broadcast media and the push for less media regulation, I'd say getting the FCC chairman to hear the public's view is ranks pretty high.

Pop Culture Minutes Dell has been taking the brunt of my PC anger for quite sometime now. It shouldn't be surprising, what with their inferior product and annoying ad campaigns. And another one landed on TV this week. It features 2 college roommates, each working on their term paper. The first man, who is working on a Dell computer, saves his term paper as the sun comes up. The second man's computer crashes as he is saving his term paper. Cut forward 5 years and the man whose computer crashed is cleaning the windows of the skyscraper where the first man is working at an apparently good desk job. The moral? If only the window washer had bought a Dell all those year ago. When was the last time your PC hardware died, preventing you from completing your term paper, essay, book, financial reports, etc. etc.? I bet never. But when was the last time your Windows operating system put you in a pickle? The Dell ad is actually incriminating Windows; the hardware has nothing to do with it. Regardless of whether your computer is a Dell, Gateway for Compaq (I'm leaving out IBM because they make the new G5 PowerPC processors for Apple), it's all Windows OS, which is what crashes and leaves you open to hackers, viruses, worms, etc. etc. Oh, and to add my experience to it: The Dell hardware will someday leave you in bind while you're on the job. Actually, it's not just a bind, it'll die on you and prevent you from getting your job done for the whole day. The problem will get "fixed" only to do it regularly every 2 months. And to make the experience all the more pleasant, try wasting an hour with Dell Technical Support. The first time the Dell at my job died, I was on hold for an hour. And that was after using our "Customer Preferred" number, or whatever it's called that is supposed to get you expedited service. Dell, drop your bad ad agency. And stop taking credit for that which you have no control over. *** My second golden nugget for today is an indictment of my favorite news channel, CNN. Well, to clarify, I live for "American Morning" and not much else. Last evening as the channel surfing was underway, I noticed that Anderson Cooper's "360" show was brought to you by Bud Light. This was the second time I saw this. The first time I caught it only in passing, and I had hoped it was just for the one news segment. You know, like how Delta and Coca-Cola brings you the weather each morning on CNN. Why does a news segment require a sponsor? This isn't a sports game. Isn't this a little too similar to integrity questions that come up with NBC being owned by a global conglomerate, with ABC being owned by Disney... The list goes on. CNN, drop the sponsorship from you show. Enough with stuffing as many ads into the shows, how about less repeating of stories or less commentary?

Yes, I Am 21, Now Let Me Enjoy the Liquor Sites The extent of my work for urlLink Sugar & Spice has been relegated to finding sponsors to help pay for flyers and allow us to offer drink specials. As I'm going through these sites, I find they use Flash in ways that would induce vomiting in anyone drinking the advertised beverage. The other thing I notice is the bogus attempt at keeping out minors who want to view these crazy Flash movies and get dizzy, a feeling similar to drunkeness. Enter your date of birth to enter. Uh, let's see. It says I need to be 21 years of age to view this site...I'm 16 and born on Feb. 29, 1988. Damn, I can't get in. How do I make myself 21...[twiddling thumbs]. Oh, yeah, I'll lie about it. [Moon blots out the Sun] The above story is totally fictitious, as I'm 24, going on 25. Though my first incidence of drunkenness occurred 6 months before my 16th birthday. Seriously, I don't understand why our country attempts to shield teenagers and young adults from alcohol. I can honestly say that my drinking in college was at times heavy, but rarely was i so out of control. And why? Because I had some exposure to it. I'd already been drunk; I already understood what it did to my body; and I already knew when it was time to cut myself off. Rarely did drinking interfere with my school work, and when I wanted to let loose, I did when I knew the next day offered time for recovery. On only one occasion did things get out of a hand, and that had less to do with alcohol and more to do with tension and aggression between roommates; we did have 6 of us. Too many people have their first experience with drinking during their freshman year, and oh, what a disaster that can be. If alcohol ads can make it onto TV screens everywhere, how can a Web site, which can be so much more informational, require a minimum age? How has American gotten to be so backwards? Where is the progress?

I hope not. So why else have I been quiet through the media storm? Because I don't think Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld needs fired. If the orders to abuse the prisoners came from him, then yes, fire him. But that's not what I've been hearing, and I seriously doubt I'll ever here that. Also, Bush's ratings are dropping. This is a Godsend, without the creepy clone gone wrong. So I'll be back to posting on whatever I fancy, but until then, I need to add some sponsorship logos and get this Web splash sent off for someone to post!

Wedding Bells for a Southern Belle I watched the final episode of "Friends" tonight. It was probably the first time I watched the show in 2 years. It lost my interest way back, but I can't say why. I had a big falling out with TV after "Seinfeld," "X-Files" and "Futurama" disappeared. Plus, my work week at the time didn't allow for much prime time TV. Was the ending heartfelt? Yeah, some. Did I guess Chandler's remarks before he said them? Yes. Did I guess Rachel left a message and got off the plane before she did it? Yes. So it ended. Nothing earth shattering. The only thing that irked me was the ad for "Fraser" while the credits were rolling. I wanted to see the final bow. Oh, plus I never cared for "Fraser." But, as you can tell, none of this has anything to do with the title to my post tonight. My very good friend April Navy is now engaged to be married to her boyfriend Adam Berry. Now as I'm writing this I see they will have the same initials. I have yet to meet this charming young man who swept April off her feet, but that should change. I need a vacation this summer. Adam needs to finally see Philadelphia, and they have a house now, so they can host a friend for a few days. I'm not being presumptive, the offer has already been made. So congratulations to April and her fiance, Adam. I had more information on the plans, but I seem to have deleted that voicemail. I haven't had a chance to call and deliver my congratulations in person, but we've done the text & voicemail message thing a few times. I'm actually off all day tomorrow - I work Saturday instead - so she'll get a harassing phone call from me for sure. Oh, days off. I love them.

Filling the Void Where have I been? I've been keeping entirely too busy for my own good. I honestly don't know how I worked 65 to 70 hour weeks this time last year. Burn out sucks. Part of the reason for this burnout is the party I'm throwing with Damon at the urlLink Mercury Lounge . I'm making an attempt at doing much of the footwork (i.e. flyers, ads, press contact) needed to get the party going, and it's not going successfully. It seems Philly's gay men aren't about leaving the gayborhood or the same tired dj at the same tired Shampoo. It seems the latest repetitious Britney Spears remix is bigger in Philly than something more soulful, more original and full of talent. I know the bartenders at Mercury Lounge are thankful each week for something new and decent to listen to. Damon's also received far more compliments on his djing and music selection than not. So here I am talking up House music like I'm a clubber. Ha! Not the case, but when I do go out, give me something I can get into. Actually, these past 2 months I've taken more to rock than I have in a long time. A few weeks ago I had a 3-hour Led Zeppelin session; I bought the Jet album from the iTunes Music Store (pretty good, but nothing spectacular: the ending is too soft compared to the rocking beginning) and some nice people shared their Maroon 5 and 2 White Stripes albums via a P2P network. I'm very much about the last 3 CDs. I listen to them regularly while taking my 25 minute walk to work each day. I've always been intrigued by the White Stripes duo: I've seen them perform at the MTV Music Video Awards and on Conan O'Brien, but it wasn't until the video for "Seven Nation Army" last week that I took the plunge. I always pick up on these things too late, but the last time I really listened to the radio was years ago, and why waste my time with MTV when I have TNT for "Law & Order," Comedy Central for "Futurama," and a plethora of other channels for history, science and space. Oh, and my guiltiest of pleasures: E! Entertainment. How's the for a little bit of insight into my life? Such an abrupt ending I know, but back to slave labor for the weekend party.

Less News Headlines Today, More Celebration June 30. It was to be the day Iraq regained sovereignty. But, the Bush Administration has apparently cleared up the day so my friend Devalina won't have to share her birthday with puppet regimes and false hopes for an entire nation. Now she just has to share it with the Cassini-Huygens satellite entering orbit around Saturn. Oh, and that little movie Spiderman 2 . urlLink NASA (Nasa, if you're in Britain), has a great site dedicated to the Saturn mission, 7 years in the making. I visited the Flash version, which I highly recommend. My only disappointment was the elementary nature of the information provided, but seeing as how a disturbingly high number of Americans think Saddam Hussein was involved with the Sept. 11 terrorists attacks or that weapons of mass destruction have been found in Iraq, we need to start simple with the American citizenry. For proof of my Iraq & WMD claims, I point you to a Knight Ridder article from urlLink April 22 . The numbers have improved, but until less than 5% of the public stops taking President George W. Bush's assertions as fact, I won't be happy. But let's not let this get discussion get mired in politics. Behind Iraq and the military, NASA has managed to seriously increase its profile over the past year. Have they made space interesting again? First it was the Mars rovers. Then it was urlLink Save Hubble! Now it's Saturn. Within a year, the shuttles will launch again to continue piecing together that already doomed International Space Station, thanks to President Bush's new space vision. Of course the ISS isn't going to last forever, but it is a stepping stone to a Moon base. Why just write it off? Why work towards canning it after so much has been put into it? Hell, the space station is far better for studying what astronauts will have to go through to get to Mars, which is the 2nd phase of Bush's mission. Astronauts traveling to Mars will be living with no gravity for the duration of the trip. The space station provides zero gravity living. The Moon doesn't do that; it's gravity is about 1/6 that of Earth's. Of course, none of this matters right now. As I'm writing this, Cassini is closing in on Saturn's rings, soon to actually pass through them and beginning a several year mission around the only planet in our solar system that could actually float in a lake, if there were a lake so big. The 2 headline missions for NASA right now are both unmanned, and many an unmanned mission will continue before a human passes beyond the Moon's orbit. In the meantime, I look forward to something far more academic on Saturn coming from NASA. And to Devalina: Salgirah Mubarak, or Happy Birthday in Urdu, the language of Pakistan.

Happy Birthday to Me I turn a quarter-century on June 27. I can hardly believe it at times. At others, I feel older than that. This birthday is extra special because Marlboro sent me a free lighter. It showed up in the mail today. The lighter is far cooler than the cheap Zippo they gave me when I first signed up with the company one drunken night at Shampoo. I think I also got a pack of cigarettes for free, which I quickly passed on to a friend who had gotten his own pack for free for doing the same thing. I figured that night that I'd sign up for it so I can be a loss for the company for as long as they send me stuff. How noble of me, right? I also started getting a weeklong free subscription to The New York Post today. All I had to do was answer 3 questions about the Yellow Pages to get it. First question: "Do you have a copy of the Yellow Pages at my house?" Yes. Second question: "How often do you use the Yellow Pages?" Less than twice a month. Third question: "How often do you purchase a service or product through a Yellow Pages listing?" Never. This is the 21st Century, right? The Yellow Pages reads like one of those "decide your fate" fiction books, jumping from one heading to another because, even though the Yellow Pages knows you're going to look up the listing under Heading A1, they see fit to list your needs under Heading G5. It's much easier just calling Directory Assistance, for those with spare change, or using Yellow Pages online, for those without spare change. Well seeing as how this is the late afternoon before my birthday, I have other things to do. As you can see, the blog has undergone some significant cosmetic changes, and people can now leave comments! I really don't know how the comments work, what with me not getting any yet, but I promise not to edit them, if I even can. I also won't delete any comments that express views not my own. I will, however, delete ignorant rants and tirades.

The Importance of Impotence Impotence. It happens. I tend to think it plays an important role in keeping the gene pool from muddying up. I guess the same could be said of homosexuality. Why am I bringing up this topic? Because I'm sick of the Viagra commercial. I'm sick of it for 2 reasons. 1. Why are they using that Queen song? Freddy Mercury must be going all epileptic in his grave. 2. Where did they find the cast for the commercial? The cast perfectly fits my thoughts on the importance of impotence. And more importantly, don't they have anything better to do besides run and jump up and down the street? Shouldn't these people be in the bedroom? My complaint with impotence drugs doesn't end there. There's Cialis, with a list of side effects that complicate sex, such as a headache, upset stomach and back pains. Let's not forget the eternal erection, which requires medical attention. I understand these side effects don't happen in everyone, but any drug with a list of side-effects longer than the list of good things it does is pretty much a waste in my eyes. Oh, Enzyte, the cheesiest of the impotence drugs. Natural male enhancement? How exactly is it natural if it's enhancement? Isn't that an oxymoron? I meant to go on and on and on about these commercial ages ago. But the newer "7th dose free" campaign is too much. I don't understand how impotence, menstrual cycle and diarrhea ads make it on the air. I find them more awkward than anything else out there. I'll take breast-baring Janet and the f-word over these commercials any day. Of course, I wouldn't have to deal with any of these ads, except that my TV viewing somehow fits the target audience for them. CNN's American Morning and Law & Order be damned.

"Be Label Conscious This Summer" "Or an Ode to Michael Myers" is probably an apt subtitle for this post. I saw the title of this post on a billboard ad for Heineken I passed this afternoon on a walk in my Nike shoes, Abercrombie shorts and Tower Records t-shirt to the park for a picnic with storebrand PB&J sandwiches and Arizona Iced Tea, reading a Star Wars novel and soaking up some sun. It was such a nice day, I was glad to be out of the house. My Apple G4 laptop probably needed the rest after crunching its processors doing some graphics work on Adobe Photoshop for Clean Recordings. Upon my return from the park, my Nokia did its annoying polyphonic ring to inform me my friend Jenn was calling. She's on my AT&T Wireless GSM America Family Plan. Such an odd thing. My best friend Jenn and my boyfriend Damon are on my Family Plan. Family. What a word. I'm sure neo-Conservatives everywhere are clutching their hearts and staggering away from their computers right now. Speaking of computer, my self-installed, Apple Airport wireless, in-home network isn't work. And Why? Verizon. Who'd have thought Verizon would have thoroughly messed up my DSL order, yet again? No, I do have it and its allowing me to view porn, "borrow" music and post to my blog at half the blazing speed I had at my old address; it's just that my old e-mail account with them didn't make the transfer to the new number or new account. I never use Verizon e-mail, but the Mail program in OS X does need to connect to that account so I can send e-mails from my att.net account. For now I have to use the Web-based e-mail program, which isn't too bad, except that AT&T is in cahoots with Microsoft. All the bells and whistles for the program only work with IE; I'm a Netscape user, quite possibly one of the last. Such a bummer. No color, italics or backgrounds for the few e-mails I send. After unsuccessfully dealing with the aforementioned problem, I watched Austin Powers in Goldmember on my Panasonic TV with DirecTV. I was rather disappointed because I missed the opening sequence, probably the best part of the movie. That's pretty much up-to-the-minute as I'm writing this. This weekend wasn't all that exciting. It was our off week for Sugar & Spice, which we've cut because Philadelphia doesn't have much of a House music scene. I couldn't even get our party listed in the City Paper or Philadelphia Weekly . Damon spun at a drag show at the Mercury Lounge Friday, which I mostly missed because I visited Jenn at Starbucks across the street from the "Real World Philadelphia" house. I finally got to see 2 of the cast members. It was hardly a life-changing moment. And the media is all over them, creating more drama. A "Making of Real World Philadelphia" is definitely in order. Brian Swope In Effect I'm back. Verizon DSL is on. The whole world is at my fingertips, at half the speed, yet the same price, as the service at 1220 N. Broad St. Apparently download speed is inconsequential, in terms of hardware laid down by Verizon. Today has been such a big day. Apple's stock jumped more than $2. as the iTunes Music Store spreads to Europe. I own stock in the company, so this is big news for me. ** The 9/11 Commission concurs with the rest of the world and disagrees with the Bush Administration over the relationship between Iraq & al Qaida. As the rest of the world knows, it was nonexistent. Why? Because Iraq was essentially a secular state, whereas al Qaida is an Islamic extremist group. They didn't like each other. Attempts were made, but Iraq rebuffed al Qaida. It should be noted that this finding invalidates a 2nd Bush Administration reason for our Iraq attack. Do I see the man's political future dim? Please let it be that, and not me blacking out from the conservative Christian movement's encroachment on my lifestyle (and I'm not just talking about between me and my boyfriend). ** Fahrenheit 9/11 will finally see the light of day in the United States, but to how many people? The film is now battling the movie ratings board over the "R" rating it received. Some want it to be PG-13 to allow more people to view it. Personally, I'm fine with the "R" rating for 2 reasons. First, what 13 year old could comprehend what 9/11 is all about (or even want to)? I don't want to write people off, but at 13, some are still dealing with coodies, boys and sleepovers. Second, the movie does feature dead Iraqi babies, prisoner abuse and children burned by napalm - not exactly your normal movie fare for the young teen crowd. Hell, I'm sure parts of it will be a bit much for some adults. ** Britney Spears' knee injury has led to the complete cancellation of her summer tour, and one can only hope the same can be said about the video she was taping while injuring herself and her career in general. ** Jeez, what does tomorrow have in store for me?

PECO Is Captain Planet It's a bit excessive, and I'm sure I've induced seizures in environmentalists everywhere. Why do I make such an outrageous correlation? Well, thanks to my friend Jenn, I've been informed of PECO's urlLink wind energy initiative . She received information about it in her last PECO bill, and she's going ahead with it. It's costing her just $5 more a month, for her energy consumption, which is affordable. She's taken the wind power initiative into her own hands, spreading the Gospel of wind energy to coworkers and friends. The power company names itself the largest provider of wind-generated energy East of the Mississippi River, thanks to wind farms in Pennsylvania and West Virginia. I remember reading several stories regarding wind farms in Pennsylvania, and how the environmentalists here were decrying them because of the danger they pose to birds. You can't win for losing, now can you? I believe in the end, the people running the wind farms, agreed to cut back on the wind mills during heavy migration periods. So now I'm spreading the Gospel. Actually, that's about all the Gospel I'm going to spread. My focus is the urlLink FAQ section , otherwise know as the Asinine Questions page. I would like to specifically point out questions 5 and 8. 5. If the wind is not blowing, will my lights go out? 8. Will there be a windmill in my backyard? I really don't even know how to tackle these questions. I'm stumped. I'm dumbfounded. The following day, I did my own part for the environment. I went to Kinko's to get some flyers printed for the party Damon and I do. While I waited to place my order, I breezed through a pamphlet outlining the company's own green initiative. It included energy efficient lighting and machinery, recycled papers and printer cartridges, just to name a few. One way the consumer can help is by having copies printed on either side. I had already done that, it wouldn't make sense to print flyers with a blank back, now would it? Kinko's recent mingling with FedEx has also garnered green news, as FedEx is testing a fleet of green delivery vans/trucks in California, which is to be expanded nationwide at some point. So while I'm generally for the small guy, sometimes the economy of scale is just too much to be against. Needless to say, I'm doing more business with Kinko's.

Europe One-Ups the USA, Again I've been against the war in Iraq since before it started. So has nearly all of Europe. I've been against SUVs in Philadelphia, in any city for that matter, for years, and now the Europeans are doing something about it. CNN reports that Paris is looking to urlLink ban SUVs for all the reasons I have: They're gas hogs, they're dangerous to other cars and pedestrians, they're too big for city streets, etc. Paris has traffic nightmares far worse than most people find in America, which is why the city has been switching more lanes to buses and bicycle lanes. I've lamented the lack of bicycle lanes and dismal public transit use since before I started this blog. More importantly, a study in London, where SUVs and 4x4s are thought of just as a highly by the city mayor, found that just 1 in 8 4x4 drivers had taken they're vehicle off-road, and 6 in 10 never left the city with theirs. How pointless? Now how to get a similar movement going so strongly in the United States?

Little Interest for a Deceased President The first news I heard this morning was of the passing of former president Ronald Reagan. During his presidency I grew up from a very young 1 year old to a very young 9 years old. His 8 years in office went over my head. Most of it still does. There were obviously other people out there (people did put him into office) who he affected, who liked and disliked him. Today, I heard 2 people say "Yes! Ronald Reagan is dead!" I say some pretty ignorant things at times, but this will not be something you will ever here me say. For as much as I dislike the current President Bush, I seriously doubt I'll ever utter those words after his last breath. My one friend was pleased about his last breath because he was not pro-women's rights. Another said those words, I assume, because of the racism, the drugs in the ghetto, the anti-gay platform, etc. etc. I'm pro-women's rights. I'm pro-choice. I'm pro-gay rights. I'm anti-racism and anti-drug. So why don't I hate the man as much as these 2 people in my life? Because for all the downfalls in Reagan's politics, he was put into office because a majority of the United States voted him into office. Reagan shouldn't be damned his beliefs, the U.S. citizenry should be. President Reagan was simply a reflection of the times. Of late it doesn't seem like things are so different. Yet things couldn't be more different. So while I'm not sad, I'm not happy. Somber is probably the best word to describe my thoughts on the passing of a president whose 2 terms will probably have some effect on the rest of my life.

Cheap Gas for Iraq I have said more than once in my posts that I'm all for high gas prices. It's the one thing we have going for us to help break the car culture of America. Too many people hop in their car to drive 2 blocks to the post office, grocery store, etc. etc. Not enough people have taken to bicycles and public transit. Breaking the car culture in America would be several steps in the right direction to cutting or ending sprawl. Breaking the car culture would mean more money for public transit (with token and pass purchases), which would in turn improve public transit. So I'm with Bill Maher about high gas prices. The rest of the world is paying up to twice what we pay (compared in dollars). Part of the reason for liberating Iraq dealt with cheap oil for the world oil market. That has obviously not been the case. About the only thing it has done is to overinflate the price at the pump. Watch for the next round of quarterly earnings reports. The oil companies are going to report billions in profits, at your expense. Something else you didn't know was happening at your expense? U.S. taxpayer dollars are subsiding 5-cent a gallon gas in Iraq. Iraqis are filling up their tanks for just $1.10 according to an urlLink AP story . What's the cost to you, the U.S. taxpayer? About $500 million for a 3-month supply of 5-cent per gallon gas. Also add in the cost of military escorts for moving all the oil around. Doesn't the gallon of gas you just purchased seem a lot more expensive now?

I'm Not Dead But thankfully the Creed, as a band, is. God, I disliked them to no end. And the lead singers attempt to equate the band with Led Zepplin! Blasphemy. Though, looking at it now, maybe there is a God. On 895 quadrillionth day, God killed Creed and saw it was good. I'm not dead. I feel happy. Note that that isn't great or superb, just happy. I've settled into the new locale, and while it's not to Damon's or my liking, we're getting by. We've made it cozy for now. I'm without DSL for a little while, which hampers my online presence, hence the sporadic posting this past week. According to Verizon, that could change as soon as Tuesday, but that depends on which customer service rep I talked to. I'm seriously considering just up and dropping them for good. Oh, that a move to Chicago could change that and so much more. That's the plan now because the city has a larger house scene for Damon and newspapers for me. The question is how soon until the move happens? It seems the journalism field is picking up here in the Philadelphia area, as I recently submitted my resume to a newspaper that actually had an opening. So any job I'm going through here will be financing the move to Chicago. This is brief, as the dial-up experience drives me nutty. That and urlLink Clean Recordings has officially relaunched, with product showing in several Philly area retailers... Now that might be what finances the move! It's been keeping me pretty busy, with a slight revamp of the site, promoting, invoicing, designing, etc. etc. Ciao until Tuesday!

Christ Over Easy Is there no end to religion being forced upon everyone? I opened a carton of Westfield eggs a few days ago to make breakfast, only to find Scriptures printed under the lid beside the nutritional information. The egg carton lid asked where I was going to spend eternity. Well, if Dante's Inferno is correct, I'll be in the 7th Ring of Hell, thank you very much. I half expected that I'd choke and die eating the eggs, seeing as how every religious layman and clergy is condemning me to hell. But no. Maybe God doesn't have it in for me. Maybe my "sin," if it must be one, isn't any worse than Newt Gingrich's affair or Rush Limbaugh's 3rd marriage. So I have to wonder exactly how this can be allowed. Usually people on the street try to push pamphlets of doom (sometimes not), and I can easily create a collection of doomsday pamphlets, or I can pass them up. But this dozen eggs was bought, and I don't know what religious group was behind the message. If it was Methodist or something similar, then fine. But what if this was a Pentacostal or Catholic group? I could be funding the ultra-conservatives behind the Bush administration! Suddenly choking on one of those eggs seems it could be a Godsend.

Guiliani, the Republican Lapdog ATTENTION. WHAT FOLLOWS IS SOMEWHAT OF A RANT. I WOKE UP THIS MORNING TO THE VOICE OF RUDY GUILIANI TALKING OUT HIS ASS. *** Rudy Guiliani, former mayor of New York, and current Republican lapdog spoke on CNN this morning. Bill Hemmer was interviewing him from the Fleet Center floor. I'm not sure what he was doing there, and I wish he hadn't been there. I'm really getting tired of the Republican spin machine. These people twist the facts in a way that should be illegal. The most recent offensive "fact"? John Kerry is the most liberal voting member of the Senate. That is correct, according to The National Register for 2003, but Kerry's long-term voting record ranks him as No. 11. The GOP has also tried highlighting vice presidential candidate John Edwards as the No. 4 most liberal Senator, but he's only No. 25 when you look at the long term. I read this additional information in a urlLink CNN story on a GOP slap at Kerry. Of course you won't have an easy time finding these facts because the publication that tracks voting records is subscription-based and not available to the public for viewing. That's annoying enough in its own right, but to find more on this information I had to visit urlLink The Washington Times , the Republican lapdog publication, not the respectable Washington Post . Doesn't it suck, that to find information from a "non-partisan publication" (as per the "About Us" page for the National Register), one must read partisan publications? Why is the GOP spinning these skewered facts, among the many others? Because the only 2 attacks they have on the Democratic contenders are the "liberal" position and the "flip flops" John Kerry has made. As far as flip flops go, hasn't the Bush Administration made the biggest of them all with the changing reasons for war with Iraq? There were the WMD (unfounded and as yet untrue), then Iraq's links with al Qaida (uncorroborated and untrue, according to the 9/11 Commission) and then the human rights violations of Saddam Hussein (even though he had U.S. support when he was gassing his citizens in the 1980s). And, as far as flip flopping, if the facts of the case change, if the position of the constituents change, than so must the policy and the politician. Bush is stubborn, his steady position had better lead him right out of the White House. When I originally wrote this, it extended on and on, but it was getting to be too much for me. So I cut it. So I'm ending it with this little bit: This election seems to be about balance. Populist Edwards with "liberal" Kerry and an intelligent Cheney with a stupid Bush. As I'm finishing this, the convention and all of its nonsense continues.

O-BAM-a So the Democratic Party has found the black who will be the party's future in Barack Obama. I didn't listen to his speech, nor have I really listened to anyone's speech yet. I don't think I will either. I'm just not too big on the political convention. I think there's been a few too many flops for this year already who were given prominence at the convention. There was the Dean machine with the loose nut who garnered Al Gore's support too early. At this point, I'm not paying much attention to anyone Gore supports, with the exception of John Kerry because I was about him long before the Iowa primary. And the Reverend Al Sharpton really had a lot of good things to say each and every time he spoke, but no one was taking him seriously. As The Daily Show with Jon Stewart reported, he was good, but he was black. I'm not really sure how the Democratic Illinois Senator candidate rose so quickly. He's running an as yet uncontested race. But after I heard and read segments of his speech, I couldn't agree more with the media laying such a lofty position on the man. Nary a decisive word came from his mouth that I heard or read, and his position is a compassionate one. Hmm, all the things Bush claims to be but isn't. "Well, I say to them tonight, there is not a liberal America and a conservative America -- there is the United States of America. "There is not a black America and white America and Latino America and Asian America -- there is the United States of America," Obama said. "We are one people, all of us pledging allegiance to the stars and stripes, all of us defending the United States of America." Give this man the presidential ticket! He's got my vote! I just hope Obama can keep up this outlook and this personality after going through the dirty politics of the U.S. Senate. How I yearn for a more-party system. Hmm, does this also explain my lack of interest in the Democratic (or Republican, for that matter) convention? I certainly don't expect this to come easily. People don't give up power and influence so easily. Unfortunately, state and federal laws all but make a third party candidate as a true contender something relegated to dreams of utopia or 1992 with Ross Perot. But I digress. Maybe this Obama can make a full-blooded Democrat out of me yet.

Fuzzy Fascination Exactly 25% (as of Tues., July 27, 21:49) of the last 100 entry pages to my Web site were visits to my pets page. I have no clue why the hell this would be the case. Why do I even have a pets page? These are all very pressing questions, but my head is killing me. A very shitty day started at 6 a.m., improved by 10 a.m., but the residual effects have yet to fade. Yes, President Bush, I can see the vast improvement in the economy! *** The bookstore recently started carrying product from urlLink The Unemployed Philosophers Guild . The humor is right up my alley. My favorite product (besides the Bush Administration being turned into a doll set titled The Axis of Evil II)? The Saint Sebastien pin cushion!!! Who is this saint? He was a Christian martyr who survived being shot up with arrows by the Roman army, only to be beaten to death later. I love this company!

Back to Work I haven't been in the bookstore in 12 days. I've not even been by the bookstore since before Boston. The downtime was good, but put me back to work! Of course, it'd be nice if that work were journalism related, but I'm willing to wait some more. I've sent my cover letter and resume to at least 4 or 5 newspapers, media outlets or publishers, so I should hear something back! When I wasn't in another state or applying for work, I spent my time reworking the urlLink Clean Recordings Web site , as well as the rest of my Web site, which I've now designated 3.0. There wasn't much of a change to my site, just updating information and cleaning a shitload of code. The site still looks simplistic, but now the code is equally simplistic. As for the Clean Web site, just take a look! The changes follow the label's relaunch, which means Damon is preparing music for demos to be sent out. So I guess this vacation was pretty productive for everyone involved. My God, this vacation did for me what vacations are supposed to do! I'm revitalized.

Lame Games Woe is me. Not so long ago, I upgraded my cell phone to AT&T Wireless (soon to be Cingular) GSM America plan. It required a new phone, which I was willing to take. I've only ever taken the "bottom of the barrel" free phone, but I wanted to splurge. I purchased a Nokia phone, as I always do, and which I highly recommend to everyone and anyone who wants to help me out indirectly (through stock gains). I was sorely disappointed before purchasing the phone, because one of the classic computer games of all time, Snake, was oddly missing from the phone. Instead backgammon (?), bowling (?), Air Glide (?) and Sky Diver (?) were my only options. I even went to AT&T Wireless to see if I could download Snake, but no. How is this classic favorite game of mine not available? Snake, for me, falls into the same category as Tetris. These games are the ultimate in computer games. Many a company has attempted to successfully redo or update the games, but 99% of them have failed. Nintendo made up with me with the N64 version, after failing miserably on SuperNintendo. Many a morning, noon and night was spent in tournaments with college roommates and friends. The game is probably one of the few things I'm competitive about. Philadelphia Story As with every time I leave this city, always much needed, I look forward to the return. This time the return from Boston was dampened by a small disaster at the house we live in. Thankfully, the trip to Boston was the easiest ever. Previous vacation transportation involved an oversold Amtrak train, a Greyhound breakdown and being stranded at the airport. Apparently low costs equal high quality in American travel. Damon and I took the Chinese bus from Chinatown Philly to Chinatown New York to Chinatown Boston for $40 each, roundtrip. I read through half of Bluebeard , another good Vonnegut book, and nearly made it home before my iPod battery gave out. Damon and I mostly enjoyed ourselves. Boston isn't exactly our kind of city. I don't think New England is a part of the country that works well with me. We were a little bit out of town and short on cash, so that certainly figured into it. Then there was our desire to eat at a Quizno's, thanks to the crazy singing gerbil things, but the downtown store was apparently the scene of a Hepatitis A outbreak. We also had trouble with getting directions from people. Us to the cop: How do we get to the South End? Cop to us: Where do you want to go? Us: We heard it's a nice part of town with cafes and shops. Cop: How about Newbury Street? It's ... We later found out we needed to go just 5 blocks west to get to our desired location, which was the city's gayborhood. Apparently, the cop wasn't about us going there. Our 2nd day, we did make it to the South End, but we somehow lost Tremont Street on the way to the movie theater to see Spiderman 2 . So we asked a street cop. Us: What happened to Tremont Street? Cop: What are you looking for? Us: The Loew's movie theater. Cop: Take this street up to the Commons... When we weren't out and about, we watched the 25 most outrageous episodes of South Park , some MadTV and the movie 28 Days . I did get some nice pics, so I'll put them on urlLink my photoblog , which I've not updated in almost a month. Gotta finish with the cleanup here at home and get some zzzs!
