The Best a Human Can Be I've fretted and fretted over America's inability to reason, a problem worsened since the 2000 campaign. Well today, that (your choice of higher power)-given trait made a brief reappearance on the U.S. Senate floor. Today, the U.S. Senate was to take up debate on the gay marriage ban amendment, and thankfully, the Republican Party, which has made this a major agenda, couldn't muster enough votes in their party to get the matter beyond a procedural vote. As expected, one Sen. Rick Santorum of my home state, voted against the measure, but not before making a fool of himself. To paraphrase him: I'm not a hater; I'm a lover. A lover of traditional family with a mother and a father ... the right of a child to have a mother and a father ... blah blah blah. This amendment has nothing to do with children. Gay couples, gay singles even, already can, have and will adopt children regardless of the future of the amendment. For a co-sponsor of the bill to create the amendment, he surely isn't very knowledgeable on it. I tried finding the actual vote statistics, but alas, it's not yet posted. I received an e-mail with my Senators' names and phone numbers so I could call them and tell them to vote against the measure. I didn't, what with the letters and e-mails I've sent over the past several months. The e-mail did note that Sen. Arlen Specter wasn't for or against it, unlike his small-minded counterpart. Specter may have a congratulatory e-mail from me coming his way. On to a vote I did come across: CNN.com's quick vote (as of 20:06, July 13) recorded 65% of those who participated did not support a gay marriage ban amendment. I made my urlLink very reasonable stance against this amendment months ago. *** In my attempts to unearth today's gay marriage ban amendment vote, I came across one good thing he's done for the Philadephia area. Specter and Santorum, through their power in Congress, managed a $589,999 grant approval to SEPTA to purchase 13 new hybrid electric buses. Of course SEPTA's Web site mentions nothing of this grant approval, nor can I find how many hybrid electric buses they already have. The Delaware Valley Regional Planning Commission, in January 2004 meeting notes does mention a test program by SEPTA using "2 low floor Hybrid buses," but if there are any other type of Hybrid buses, I have no idea. Because I'm all for public transit and alternative energy sources, I find Santorum can be reasonable about some issues, just not enough of them. *** Oh, and following political conversation at work (it's so cool of late) regarding Fox News (fair and balanced, my ass!), I read about a documentary showing a pattern of Republican opinion reporting rather than news reporting. It's called urlLink Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism and MoveOn.org is helping to set up urlLink house parties around the country for viewing it.

Bush Administration at Odds with Science The Register not so shockingly reports that the Bush Administration regularly pushes aside science when it comes to policy making. What replaces science? Well, religion, politics and party donors, of course! You could easily push this aside except that the latest report, or complaint, from the Union of Concerned Scientists has 4,000 signatures attached to it. What's 4,000 signatures in a country with nearly 200 million people? Included in those 4,000 signatures are "48 Nobel laureates, 62 National Medal of Science recipients and 127 members of the National Academy of Sciences." The report documents specifics with Appalachian mining (Bush OK'd, science didn't), the "Plan B" pregnancy preventative (Bush nixed, science OK'd) and endangered species policy. Of course, this trend expands to watershed requirements, oil drilling and the allowed pollution content in the water you swim, drink and fish in and the air you breath. Something more jarring than the aforementioned is the policy of the Bush Administration in terms of sex education and AIDS. The U.N. is holding its AIDS conference this week in Bangkok, Thailand, and the World Health Organization reported that a record number of HIV infections (5 million) were reported last year. What does the Bush Administration and his super conservative base think should be done to fight the disease? Abstinence of course. Abstinence, even though abstinence is the most arcane and short-sighted solution. Yes, people not having sex would certainly end the spread of HIV, herpes, not to mention the human race. Yes, it's a fine idea, except that humans are sexual. Priests even have trouble with their vow of celibacy. urlLink Ever since the 1800s, the rate of illegitimate children and those born out of wedlock has been rising. Just how long has the liberal left been destroying this country?!? Listen, my family is Republican and has voted that way for as long as they could. They were raised with church, and some continue to attend. But my grandmother and grandfather had their first child out of wedlock, as did their 3rd child, as did two of their grandchildren. Abstinence is a great idea in utopia. But, like the administration shooting down the Plan B pregnancy preventative, what's left when abstinence breaks down? A complete ignorance of sex, that's what. How do you use a condom? What's the difference between these different styles? What size fits me? If sex is treated as a taboo, how many times will a teenager play Russian Roulette with sex before they have the gumption to ask about it? The adult thing to say is that if someone isn't ready to talk about sex, they shouldn't be doing it. But shouldn't isn't couldn't or wouldn't. A urlLink study of black high school girls found that real sex ed led to improved sexual health and smarter choices. So much for sex ed leading to sex and pregnancy. But you wouldn't expect the Bush Administration to follow real science, would you?

Media, err, Kerry, err, Bush Gone Wild I meant to get to this post on the day of the crime, but I'm doing some freelance architectural writing, and because that pays, that comes first. What "crime" am I talking about? It's the scoop on Sen. John Kerry's vice presidential pick. By now you must know that The New York Post incorrectly scooped everyone when they printed John Kerry choosing Dick Gephardt the night previous to the announcement. For some reason (media manipulation, maybe) the Kerry campaign prematurely announced to his urlLink election Web site listserv members whom he had chosen for his vice presidential running mate. That who was John Edwards. Well before Kerry was set to officially announce his decision to the world, CNN and every other news channel in America, possibly the world, was covering the empty podium where Kerry was set to announce "John Edwards as his vice presidential pick in 'x' minutes." When they weren't showing the empty podium TV screens were filled with political commentators and the latest poll numbers on who Kerry should choose. Before I got all the news on how the media found out early, I was appalled by the breaking news. Why can't the man just announce it himself. But it seems he didn't want to. So rather than bash the media, I'll bash the Bush campaign, which is a much easier target. On the front page of the Bush re-election urlLink Web site (I can't believe I'm linking to Satan), the Bush camp attacks Kerry for choosing Edwards. Why? Because Kerry attacked Edwards for being too inexperienced to be president during the primaries. Uh, maybe the Bush camp doesn't understand, but Edwards isn't running for president, he's been picked to be vice president. The Web site also claims Edwards is Kerry's 2nd choice, but they fail to mention who his first choice was. We can guess that John McCain was the "first" choice they speak of, but I haven't read a report putting him in that spot. I've read that Kerry had asked him to consider it, but Kerry had a short list of several possible vice presidential candidates. The site also complains of Edwards' pessimism, but his strong point is and has been his optimism. He was banking on that during the primaries, and he became the biggest threat to Kerry because of this. And anyway, no pessimist can smile like Edwards can smile. I'm not really sure how Kerry picking Edwards is a flop simply because they were opponents during the Democratic primaries. They had a common goal and that was to unseat Bush from the White House. And more importantly, the Bush Web site picks out several votes that make Kerry and Edwards anti-family, anti-military support, anti-anything and everything. And guess what? The two had similar votes on most of the topics mentioned. Flip flop? Maybe strengthening of a platform. Let's look at another example of paired opposites that work... Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O'Neal, when they are on their own, are not friends. The media has covered more than one spat between the two, but when it comes down to winning the game, they're a team and they accomplish the goal. I can pin another example on Bush. Bush and McCain were opponents in the 2000 presidential race, but guess what? McCain recently introduced Bush during a speech. His manner was very respectful and he praised the current president. Former opponents now friends? Who'd have thunk it? To close this out, Bush's re-election Web site is a horrible mish-mash of moving ads, banners and I don't know what else. Kerry's Web site is much calmer, easier to read and follow, and doesn't leave you dizzy after visiting it for a just a few minutes.

Survivor? I Think Not I just finished Survivor by Chuck Palahniuk. He's the author of Fight Club , which was made into one of my Top 3 favorite movies of all time. I first saw it when I was still a Temple student, so it's taken me quite a number of years to finally get to the books. Probably only because I had no idea how to spell this guy's name, and I'm not one for asking for assistance at the bookstore, or anywhere. Oh, and more importantly, the Center City Border's is not known for staffing its Information Desk, on the off chance I ever did ask for help. This is probably the quickest I have ever read a book. It's not written too complex, but the dark humor, the bizarre facts, I couldn't put the book down. And it's not like this book is a cliffhanger or anything. But why do I question the title? Because, like Fight Club Palahniuk is subverting societal norms, etiquette and morals. This time it's religion and celebrity. I'm already cynical, but this book just takes it to the max. If you're not already, it's a little difficult to finish this book unscathed. I've done nothing but talk about this book since I got it from Overstock.com, which comes highly recommended as well. It's cheaper than Amazon.com! I wanted to read this book at work today, which wouldn't have been a problem, because 75% of Philadelphia was closed. Coffee shops, Wawa Express, Liberty Place, the many lunch trucks, etc. etc. So now one was out. It was amazing I survived the day in retail. We sent one employee home earlier and we could have sent a second home without understaffing the store. For the record that would leave 2 people running the store. Why else am I amazed I survived the day? Because it was 87 degrees Fahrenheit, high humidity and the air conditioning was broken. Not that it ever really works right, but usually it's at least pumping air. Why else am I amazed I survived the day? I should rephrase that and thank whichever god is truly running things that I'm still alive after ever walking into that store. See, the building is a rather old building and it's gone through many an owner. Recently, the store has exuded a certain smell of death. It's coming in through the vents. The main lobby area reeks of it to as well. The building covers it up with some foul smelling cleaner, with the fumes also being circulated through the building via the air ducts. It wasn't noticeable today, but in another week, it'll be back, I'm sure. I was a good citizen the other week and sent a "tip" to the regional EPA office, complaining of the smells and the dry throats and headaches resulting from the building maintenance cover up. What response did I get from the EPA? Hi, We dont have any legal athority to come into your building and that is what you need - a site visit. Since you are nearby, If the owner of the building sends us a letter then EPA management may honor that request. Hmm, yeah, the owner of the building, which could be in violation of God knows what, is going to let you come in and maybe fine him. Someone was paid with my tax dollars to write that stupid response to me. Another day to survive, I guess. In other news, this is my 200th post. If this were a sitcom, I'd be doing a retrospective, but maybe another day.

I'm Surrounded by Cancers It's yet another birthday among my circle of friends, this one belonging to my closest friend in Philadelphia, Jenn. So to you I say, alles Gute zum Geburtstag! In other news, the new World Trade Center's corner stone has been laid to rest today. Over the next few years the skyline of New York City is going to change dramatically. Like the first world trade center towers, this one isn't without its share of controversy. I guess there is something in common between the two. Some of it is political, some of it is historical and some of it is emotional. It seems fitting that it commemorates a date in American history that has so split the American people and taken down paths never thought possible. Happy Birthday to America as well. It's time I sign off here today and get on with the July 4th tradition of too much food and later on the fireworks, minus the Isley Brothers. I can't say I'm fans of them, but of fireworks, yes indeed! I haven't much cared for the musical selection at Welcome America! in Philadelphia over the past couple of years. Hell, I've seen better fireworks as well. Or at least more moving ones. I remember Long's Park in Lancaster, Pa., with the city orchestra playing "The 1812 Overture" as cannons fired to open the fireworks display. I'm not sure if they're even that spectacular anymore. The Bon-Ton used to sponsor the event, but that's since been passsed on to Wachovia Bank, or Walk All Over Ya, as my friend Chris calls it.

Always Room for Activism Has Bill Cosby thrown comedy out the window? His last 2 headline grabbing endeavors have been stances against how black people live each day. Blaming the white man, listening to foul rap music and bad parenting, among other things. His first coming out as an activist garnered a lot of negative press; it seems more because this was an unexpected move and less because what he said was racist or wrong. Cosby's second foray into activism seemed better received. Though the word "tirade" is still used in the AP story making the rounds. "Dogs, water hoses that tear the bark off trees, Emmett Till," he [Bill Cosby] said, naming the black youth who was tortured and murdered in Mississippi in 1955, allegedly for whistling at a white woman. "And you're going to tell me you're going to drop out of school? You're going to tell me you're going to steal from a store?" So maybe tirade is the right word to use. Regardless of tirade, the man has a point. It's always good to see someone with the clout of Cosby take up a cause for the better. God knows with all the offensive and subpar hip hop artists and their music, we need more positive positions. I take a strong stance against hip hop, though you'll find quite a bit in my iTunes Library. Artists like The Roots, Outkast and Missy Elliot, they aren't bring people down. But others are, and the rap lifestyle is ever pervasive in the black communities where I have lived and do live now. Cosby also took up my favorite thing to be against: double standards. "When you put on a record and that record is yelling 'n----- this and n----- that' and you've got your little 6-year-old, 7-year-old sitting in the back seat of the car, those children hear that," he said. White people are also ignorant when it comes to the English language. White people also beat on their kids and wives. White people also get stuck in minimum wage jobs. But one thing white people don't have is a derogatory word with accepted usage only by other white people. The use of n****r is the worst example of double standards, when it comes to issues of race. How is this word interchangeable with friend from one black person to another? But beyond these small parts to the larger tirade, I'm always interested in activists who don't push religious views. Not because I'm so against religion, but because religions have their own oppressive ideals. As of noon, Friday, July 2, 98% of the people responding to CNN's online poll felt Cosby's tirade was justified. The real question shouldn't be weather Cosby's comments are justified, but rather do his recent actions point to a political future? Could his name show up on the ballot for governor, senator or representative in the near future? And what chance does he have?

Greetings from Lancaster I haven't been in Lancaster County since January, and that was for a very brief period. I'm helping an aunt move out of her house. It's an old house that my grandfather's parents had lived in for some time. The original house is from the 1800s and had only a bathroom, kitchen and bedroom. In the early 1900s it expanded to a living room, dining room, 2 new bedrooms and a larger bathroom. After more than a century of standing, it's ready to come down. I took a couple of pictures that might end up on my photojournal, I don't know yet. The moving was ungodly stressful. I was expecting everything to be ready for moving, but no, it hadn't even been gone through yet. We found phone books from the '80s, TeenBeat magazines from the '70s. Anything and everything! My grandfather has a bad knee, but he's always got to be working, so his limited work was aggravating him. Honestly, he'll be working his own funeral. But now that is done, and I'm returning to Philadelphia, refreshed, buffed and stuffed with food. My trip home did have some political charge to it. I'm Democrat/Independent and the grandparents are Republican, about everything and everyone. One thing that did shock me was my grandpa stating that Condeleeza Rice should be vice president. My grandma things she'll get Colin Powell's Secretary of State gig when he's done (presumably after this election). Their thoughts on Condi took me by surprise. My family hasn't been the accepting of people, but Condi has obviously made an impression on them. What also took me by surprise is there apparent dislike of the current vice president, Dick Cheney, who has quite a bit of support from his Republican constituency, even after all the problems he's been involved with. *** In a pointless sidenote to the past week, I've not been emptying the bulk bin of my yahoo account. The filters managed to capture 901 bulk e-mails by this Sunday at midnight. I don't even use the account, I don't know how my address has made the rounds. I probably reported as spam another 20 e-mails over this time. My att.net account gets hit pretty hard, but I have that e-mail posted on my Web site, so that's to be expected, unfortunately. I've been getting bombarded by e-mails (duplicates usually) from this one company, which I've been unsubscribing to each and every time. The link says that within 10 business days I'll have my address wiped from there mass mailings, but after 5 or 6 days, there's been no change. I'm sure they'll bombard me until Day 10. More when I return and settle in.

Transition I'm single again. I've not been single in more than a year. I feel both welcome and uneasy about this change. I've always been insanely independent, and me dating Damon came as a surprise to everyone, including the two of us. But I must admit, having someone can be very uplifting and comforting. As far as feeling uneasy, it comes with us still living together and being close. At times it's awkward, and other times jealousy comes into play. We also aren't planning on moving away from each other. There has been discussion of still moving to Chicago or somewhere together. I do know that this break up is a 180-degree turn from the last I went through. The events of that implosion/explosion made my single life all the more enjoyable and desirable. I just hope that being friends works out for Damon and I. We put too much into the last 14 months for it to crumble. That we both feel the same way bodes well. In the end, we've split more because we needed to, not because we wanted to. Needless to say, I've been thrown for a loop of late. For the purpose of being quick and simple, what follows are two things to note in the political spotlight. There was urlLink Arizona Senator John McCain attacking a pro-Bush ad that slammed presidential candidate John Kerry . Why did John McCain do this? Because the ad was unfair and similar to the sleight the Bush camp dealt McCain when they were opponents in the 2000 presidential election. Sometimes I really like McCain, and other times, not at all! This, obviously, being a time I'm on his side. But that seems to be part of the charm McCain has. I considered voting for him in the 2000 election, but he didn't make it to the general election. Oh, independent-minded politicians! We need more of you. Pennsylvania has one of those. His name is Arlen Specter, and someone is trying to get him out of office. Shame on that person! The opponent isn't memorable, so I'm not even going to mention his name. All I know is Specter's opponent in the primary election had a lot of Democrats wishing they could have voted Republican to help Specter. In the end, we Democrats and independents didn't need to. We may be needed come November's General Election. And my 2nd point: More recently, Bush stated that "we," as in him and his administration urlLink "never stop thinking about new ways to harm our country and our people." Tell me about it! I didn't see this comment live, but I wonder if he catches what he says, or if he reads about it later and says to himself, "did I really say that?" Hell, maybe he hears about it later, and it still doesn't faze him.

Rich Oil Companies/Struggling America ChevronTexaco Corp. last week urlLink reported record quarterly profits of $4.1 billion. You heard it. The company made four point one billion dollars in 3 months. The company had $37 billion in sales. With record profits, I don't know how these oil companies can justify hiking the price of gasoline so much. How American that these companies are fattening their balances sheets and executive paychecks, while fueling oil speculation and dependency fears. What turned this story into a post was additional information in The Wall Street Journal (which requires membership and is a hassle for a lot of people): But the real key to the future is finding new oil at a time when most of the energy-rich Middle East is closed off to foreign oil companies, and major oil deposits must be found in more remote and unstable regions of the world. All of which makes exploration an increasingly expensive enterprise. With the help of recent windfall profits, "We have the financial strength to make these big investments," says Dave O'Reilly, ChevronTexaco's chairman and chief executive. "These are multibillion commitments. This is not for the fainthearted." In an urlLink ABCNews science column , Lee Dye points out that companies rolling in cash don't have an incentive to look at alternative fuel sources. How true! They were built on oil and they will be oil until there isn't anymore oil left. Very short-sighted wouldn't you say? The column very interestingly points out the faults of government subsidy and taxing the wrong types of fuels. Unfortunately, U.S. energy policy (including that made behind closed doors with Vice President Cheney), seeks to boost oil output and feed current energy consumption. It does little to boost alternative energy production or research or work towards conserving energy. The energy bill, which ultimately failed in the Senate (go Democrats!), sought $23.5 billion in tax breaks for energy companies. The amount to go towards renewable resources pales in comparison to this amount. When the No. 2 oil company in the world posts a 3-month profit of $4.1 billion, why are more tax breaks needed? Oh, that's right, the oil industries connection with the Bush administration. For more information, the Freedom of Information Center at Missouri University provides a urlLink report on oil giveaways written by The Center for Public Integrity.
